title: Brooklyn Beckham pictured just hours wedding actress Nicola Peltz
story: Share this articleExude elegance like Victoria in a dress from her own collectionClick to buyWho better to showcase Victoria Beckham&#39s latest designs than the frontwoman herself?The singer-turned-designer&#39s beautiful dress has topped our wish list. Cut from an organic cotton-blend, it incorporates a square neckline, contrast straps and A-line skirt to create an elegant aesthetic.Love the look as much as we do? Click the product image to add Victoria&#39s dress to your basket. It retails for ¬£590, so might be pricier than your usual dress spend, but you&#39re bound to hold on to a piece like this forever.Alternatively, head to the carousel, where you&#39ll find gorgeous lookalikes by H&ampM, Reformation, &amp Other Stories and Staud. Prices start at just ¬£19.99. If you&#39re feeling spendy, why not treat yourself to her Bottega Veneta bag too?MailOnline may earn commission on sales from these product linksBottega Veneta chain bag at SelfridgesReformation &#39Vinny&#39 dress at NET-A-PORTERStaud &#39Wells&#39 dress at MyTheresa&amp Other Stories cut-out dress (now reduced to ¬£52.50)   BILLIONAIRE BRIDEBrooklyn and Nicola started dating in October 2019, after being introduced by Sofia Richie, the model daughter of singer Lionel.They went public in January 2020 and the engagement was announced in July the same year and sealed with a ¬£160,000 emerald-cut diamond ring.The pair are said to have signed a pre-nuptial agreement, meaning that they will exit the marriage with whatever they took into it should romance fade.¬†Nicola is the youngest of eight siblings, and one of three children by Claudia Heffner Peltz, Nelson Peltz‚Äôs third wife.She was a tomboy who dreamed of playing hockey for a living until she took a drama class when she was 12.Her screen debut was in a Miley Cyrus pop video when she was 13.Aged 15, she was cast as Katara in the 2010 fantasy adventure, The Last Airbender.She is best known for her role as Mark Wahlberg‚Äôs daughter in Transformers: Age Of Extinction. She has since appeared in the TV series Inhumans.Her exes include pop star Justin Bieber, whom she dated briefly in 2016, and Anwar Hadid, the brother of supermodels Gigi and Bella.They split ‚Äòamicably‚Äô after a year, but she unfollowed him and his entire family on Instagram after he was pictured kissing model Kendall Jenner.It has been widely speculated that she is the ‚ÄòHollywood mean girl‚Äô described by actress Bella Thorne in a 2015 interview.In it she said: ‚ÄòI have a mean girl. She‚Äôs in the business, and she‚Äôs very, very mean. I stay away from her at all costs.I never say hello to her. ‚ÄòHer siblings are not mean like she is. It‚Äôs just her. One of the reasons I don‚Äôt like her is because she‚Äôs been a billionaire since she was very little, and she‚Äôs never had to work for anything in her life.‚ÄôThorne knows Peltz because her boyfriend Gregg Sulkin also co-starred in the film Affluenza with Nicola Peltz in 2014.Nicola has never commented on the speculation.

title: Covid Brexit roles 40 000 jobs ministers aim slash civil service
story: Share this article 'Governments expand and contract all the time,' FDA general secretary Dave Penman said.'But it's whether they match resources with what the civil service is committed to do.'It's disappointing the Chief Secretary to the Treasury is fixated on this increase over the last six years, which is due to civil service demands increasing.'In a speech to the Institute of Economic Affairs in March, Mr Clarke said that Covid had shown ministers 'that some parts of Whitehall remain resistant to change and that it's sometimes easier to expand the state than it is to remodel or streamline it.'But he promised the government was 'alert to that' and - through 'efficiencies' and 'more streamlined processes' - would 'bring civil service headcount down to sustainable levels for the longer term'.'The reality is that some growth in the civil service was required to deliver Brexit and our Covid response.'But over the next spending review I want to see headcount levels fall back towards where they were before what were very much out-of-the-ordinary events.'¬†Up to 40,000 civil service jobs face the axe

title: SIX weeks Metropolitan Line mayhem TfL examines fleet Tubes
story: Share this articleLondon Tube closures on the District, Hammersmith &amp City, Northern and Docklands Light Railway lines will also make it harder travelling around the capital.More than 500 signalling and track upgrade projects across the country include the closure of London's Euston and Victoria stations to most services.It will cause chaos for the thousands of football fans travelling to the FA Cup semi-finals, between Manchester City and Liverpool and Chelsea and Crystal Palace, at Wembley Stadium.Trains into London from the North West and West Midlands will instead stop at Milton Keynes Central, meaning other routes into the capital face being overwhelmed.The FA is urging fans from the North to avoid the railways and use specially laid-on buses or travel before the weekend instead.And the issues on the Metropolitan line, which serves Wembley Park, will no doubt cause further problems for fans travelling to both semi-finals across the weekend.¬†All Southern trains between Victoria and East Croydon have been axed, also causing havoc for air passengers landing at or trying to reach Gatwick. It means passengers on trains erted via London Bridge face chaos.

title: donnelly reviewing watt report on holohan secondment
story: Robert Watt‚Äôs report to Minister for Health Stephen Donnelly is due to be  considered by the Government. File photograph: The Minister for Health Stephen Donnelly has received a report on the circumstances surround the proposed secondment of State chief medical officer Tony Holohan to an academic position in Trinity College Dublin. A spokesman for Mr Donnelly said he is currently reviewing the report from his department‚Äôs secretary general Robert Watt. Dr Holohan was appointed as professor of public health strategy at TCD on March 25th and announced on the same day he was stepping down as chief medical officer. While Dr Holohan had no intention of returning to the role, his transfer was described as an ‚Äúopen-ended secondment‚Äù. Mr Watt is understood to be the official who sanctioned the move.  Mr Donnelly only learned on April 5th that he would continue to remain a departmental employee on a salary of ‚Ç¨187,000 per annum. Following the disclosure, Taoiseach Miche√°l Martin announced that the appointment would be ‚Äúpaused‚Äù pending a report from Mr Watt. However, over the weekend, Dr Holohan announced he would not take up the TCD role but would retire from the department on July 1st. Once reviewed by Mr Donnelly, Mr Watt‚Äôs report is due to be considered by the Government. A spokesman said that it is the intention to publish the report but said the Department was not yet in a position to say when that would occur. Meanwhile, spokespeople for Mr Donnelly and the Taoiseach repeated that they had only learned of the secondment arrangement last Tuesday, April 5th, contrary to media reports at the weekend that suggested both were aware of the arrangement at an earlier date.

title: more than 100 mps resign as sharif becomes new pakistani prime minister
story: Newly elected Pakistani prime minister Shehbaz Sharif addresses the National Assembly  in Islamabad on Monday. Photograph:  APMore than 100 MPs loyal to Pakistan‚Äôs ousted prime minister Imran Khan resigned on Monday, creating a headache for the new, western-friendly incumbent, Shehbaz Sharif, as he tries to drag his country out of political and economic crisis. His departure from power sparked street protests and a mass resignation of MPs from Mr Khan‚Äôs Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf party in protest at the impending change of government. If the resignations are accepted by the speaker, Pakistan would face the prospect of more than 100 by-elections within two months, a major distraction for Mr Sharif and his coalition partners and a potential platform for Mr Khan (69) to mobilise his support.That in turn could ensure the nuclear-armed nation of 220 million people remains prone to political and economic turbulence. Mr Sharif has a reputation domestically as an effective administrator more than as a politician. He is the younger brother of three-time prime minister Nawaz Sharif. Analysts say Shehbaz, unlike Nawaz, enjoys amicable relations with Pakistan‚Äôs military, which traditionally controls foreign and defence policy.Economic malaiseAfter Monday‚Äôs vote, Mr Sharif vowed to tackle an economic malaise that has seen the rupee hit an all-time low and the central bank implement the biggest hike in interest rates in decades last week. ‚ÄúIf we have to save the sinking boat, what we all need is hard work, and unity, unity and unity,‚Äù he told parliament. ‚ÄúWe are beginning a new era of development today.‚Äù The younger Sharif emerged as the leader of a united opposition to topple Mr Khan, a former cricket star who has claimed that the United States was behind his downfall, which Washington has denied. Mr Sharif said in an interview last week good relations with the United States were critical for Pakistan for better or for worse, in stark contrast to Mr Khan‚Äôs prickly ties to Washington.In his maiden speech, he also spoke of improving relations with neighbours India and China. ‚ÄúWe want good relations with India but a durable peace can‚Äôt be possible without Kashmir‚Äôs solution,‚Äù he said, referring to the contested Himalayan territory the countries have fought several wars over. He said his government will speed up construction of the $60 billion China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC) ‚Äì a part of Beijing‚Äôs Belt and Road Initiative.Full termNo elected prime minister has completed a full term in Pakistan since it won independence from colonial power Britain in 1947, though Mr Khan is the first to be removed by a no-confidence vote. The military has ruled the country for almost half its nearly 75-year history. It viewed Mr Khan and his conservative agenda favourably when he won election in 2018. That support waned after a falling-out over the appointment of a military intelligence chief and economic troubles. Mr Khan remained defiant following his defeat in parliament. Thousands of his supporters in several cities held protests against his ousting. Nawaz Sharif was barred by the supreme court in 2017 from holding public office and subsequently went abroad for medical treatment after serving just a few months of a 10-year jail sentence for corruption charges. ‚ÄúThere can‚Äôt be any bigger insult to this country,‚Äù Mr Khan told reporters on Monday on the prospect of Shehbaz Sharif being elected. ‚Äì ReutersStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: russian forces ramp up efforts to gain control of mariupol
story: Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy, speaking in a video address to South Korean lawmakers, has said that the besieged city of Mariupol has been destroyed and that tens of thousands of people have been killed. Video: ReutersA Russian tank that was knocked out during fighting on a highway to Kyiv. Photograph: Efrem LukatskyAPRussian forces are pushing hard to establish control over the southern port city of Mariupol, the linchpin between Russian-held areas to the west and east and already devastated by weeks of siege and bombardment.Thousands of Russian troops were massing for a fresh offensive in the east, according to Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskiy on Monday. He added that Moscow said it would not halt its military operation in Ukraine for any further peace talks.British intelligence indicated that Ukrainian forces had already repulsed several Russian assaults in eastern regions. Britain‚Äôs defence ministry said Russian shelling continued in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions. But Ukrainian forces had beaten back several assaults and destroyed tanks, vehicles and artillery equipment, it said.For now at least, the invading forces have abandoned their attempt to capture the capital Kyiv but they are redoubling efforts in the east.The invasion ‚Äì which Russia calls a ‚Äúspecial military operation‚Äù ‚Äì has left a trail of death of destruction. Moreover, the attack has drawn condemnation from western countries and triggered concern about President Putin‚Äôs broader ambitions.Russian claimsRussia‚Äôs defence ministry said sea-launched missiles had on Sunday destroyed S-300 anti-aircraft missile systems which had been supplied to Ukraine by a European country. The batteries were concealed in a hangar on the outskirts of Dnipro in central Ukraine, it said.The United States did not have evidence that any S-300 missile defence system had been destroyed by Russia, said a senior defence official. Washington believes Russia has started reinforcing and resupplying its troops in Donbas in eastern Ukraine, the official added, but that the US does not believe this is the start of a new offensive in the region.President Zelenskiy appealed to South Korea‚Äôs parliament by videolink to provide his country with military aid to assist Ukraine‚Äôs struggle against the Russian onslaught.About one-quarter of Ukraine‚Äôs 44 million population have been forced from their homes, cities turned into rubble and thousands have been killed or injured, many of them civilians.Russian foreign minister Sergei Lavrov confirmed that the Kremlin would not halt its operation for any new round of peace talks. And he accused Kyiv of failing to reciprocate in previous sessions. Mr Lavrov told state television he saw no reason not to continue with talks. But although President Putin had ordered a suspension of military action during a first round in February, Moscow‚Äôs position had changed, he said.Austrian leader Karl Nehammer met President Putin in Moscow on Monday and was expected to call for an end to the conflict. It was Mr Putin‚Äôs first face-to-face meeting with a European Union leader since the invasion started. ‚ÄúThis is not a friendly meeting,‚Äù Mr Nehammer was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his office, reiterating that he had hoped to help bring an end to the war or improve conditions for civilians. ‚ÄúThe conversation with President Putin was very direct, open and tough.‚ÄùUrged to fleeMounting civilian casualties have triggered widespread international condemnation and new sanctions.Luhansk governor Serhiy Gaidai said shelling in the region was increasing day by day.He urged all civilians to evacuate. ‚ÄúThose that wanted to leave have already left, while now many are left in bomb shelters who are perhaps frightened to come out . . . or scared to lose their possessions.‚ÄùMoscow has rejected accusations of war crimes by Ukraine and western countries. It has repeatedly denied targeting civilians and says its aim is to demilitarise and root out dangerous nationalists in its southern neighbour. Ukraine and western nations have dismissed this as a baseless pretext for war.German foreign minister Annalena Baerbock, speaking before a meeting of European ministers in Luxembourg, said Berlin saw ‚Äúmassive indications‚Äù of war crimes in Ukraine.Meanwhile, French bank Soci√©t√© G√©n√©rale became the latest company to retreat from Russia. It agreed to sell its stake in Rosbank and the Russian lender‚Äôs insurance subsidiaries to Interros Capital, a firm linked to billionaire Vladimir Potanin.The invasion has triggered a wave of financial sanctions from the United States, Europe and Britain, prompting western companies to sell their Russian assets. Several European Union ministers said on Monday the bloc‚Äôs executive was drafting proposals for an oil embargo on Russia, although there was still no agreement to ban Russian crude.The World Bank forecast the war would cause Ukraine‚Äôs economic output to collapse by 45 per cent this year, with half of its businesses shuttered, grain exports mostly cut off by Russia‚Äôs naval blockade and destruction rendering economic activity impossible in many areas.The bank forecast Russia‚Äôs gross domestic product would contract by 11.2 per cent this year due to sanctions.Full coverage of the Russian invasion of UkraineStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: johnny depp and amber heard face off again in us libel trial
story: Amber Heard  and Johnny Depp are about to clash once more in court. Photograph: Getty ImagesThe latest chapter in Hollywood star Johnny Depp‚Äôs legal battle with ex-wife Amber Heard started on Monday as a US defamation trial began over allegations Heard made about domestic abuse.Depp (58) has sued Heard for $50 million (‚Ç¨46 million). He alleges she defamed him after writing a 2018 opinion piece in the Washington Post about being a survivor of domestic abuse.The article never mentioned Depp by name, but his lawyers have said it is clear Heard was referencing him and that the piece damaged his film career and reputation.Depp has denied all allegations of abuse. He notes in the lawsuit that his ex-wife‚Äôs claims were an ‚Äúelaborate hoax to generate positive publicity for Ms Heard and advance her career‚Äù.Jury selection is expected to begin on Monday.Depp and Heard both submitted long lists of potential witnesses whom they could call.Heard‚Äôs list includes her ex-boyfriend and Tesla chief executive Elon Musk, who she texted with about Depp. Also on the list of potential witnesses is actor James Franco, who Heard testified in the London case inquired about bruises on her face following an alleged abusive incident with Depp.Depp wants the Fairfax County jury to find that Heard knowingly made false claims.Heard, for her part, will argue that she is shielded, or ‚Äúimmune‚Äù, from liability because her 2018 opinion piece on domestic violence dealt with a matter of public concern.‚ÄúI never named him. Rather, I wrote about the price women pay for speaking out against men in power. I continue to pay the price, but hopefully when this case concludes, I can move on and so can Johnny,‚Äù said Heard on Saturday.The Washington Post is not a defendant in the trial. Depp‚Äôs lawyers have said they filed the case in Fairfax County, outside the District of Columbia, because the newspaper is printed at a facility there. Heard unsuccessfully tried to transfer the case to Los Angeles, where she and Depp lived.Heard‚Äôs lawyers alleged ‚Äúforum shopping‚Äù, saying Depp‚Äôs attorneys sued in Virginia because they perceived it as a more favourable venue than California.California has a more strongly worded ‚Äúanti-Slapp law,‚Äù a type of legal protection meant to shield journalists and others from frivolous lawsuits designed to silence them.The US trial comes less than two years after Depp lost a libel case against The Sun, which labelled him a ‚Äúwife beater‚Äù. A London high court judge ruled he had repeatedly assaulted Heard and put her in fear for her life.The United States is a difficult forum for libel plaintiffs, especially public figures like Depp, who faces several hurdles in the Virginia case. Depp must prove by clear and convincing evidence that Heard knowingly made false claims.Under English defamation law, the person being sued has the burden of proving their claims were true.Depp and Heard met while making The Rum Diary in 2011 and married four years later. She accused Depp of domestic abuse after filing for orce in 2016.Depp‚Äôs Hollywood careerDepp ascended to Hollywood stardom in the 1990s with portrayals of loners and outsiders in cult classics such as John Waters‚Äôs Cry-Baby and Tim Burton‚Äôs Edward Scissorhands.He became a household name with the swashbuckling Disney franchise Pirates of the Caribbean, playing fan favourite Jack Sparrow.Heard (35) is known for her roles in Aquaman and Justice League. She has brought her own libel claim against Depp, saying he smeared her by calling her a liar.Heard‚Äôs counterclaim will be decided as part of the trial, which could last for six weeks. Heard is seeking $100 million in damages from Depp, according to court papers.In her evidence to the London High Court, Heard said Depp would turn into a jealous alter ego, ‚Äúthe monster‚Äù, after binging on drugs and alcohol and had threatened to kill her.She detailed 14 occasions of extreme violence when she said the actor choked, punched, slapped, head-butted, throttled and kicked her.The London judge accepting 12 of these accounts as true.Following the November 2020 ruling in the London libel trial, Depp was replaced with Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen for the third film in the Fantastic Beasts franchise, a spin-off from the Harry Potter books and films. ‚Äì ReutersStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: perilous moment conservative party
story: And we have the ongoing police investigation into whether Boris Johnson himself broke lockdown rules by attending events in his flat and the offices within Number Ten. Here there is already a concerted attempt by loyalists to downplay the significance of the moment should the Prime Minister be fined by the police. Their job has been made easier by the strength Johnson has shown in arming Ukraine and standing up to Russia. They are aided too by the sense that Sunak‚Äôs recent difficulties mean he is less likely, for now at least, to win the race to succeed Johnson. And they will use Sunak‚Äôs example as a warning against taking a chance on other less experienced candidates.Regardless of their good fortune, however, the loyalists‚Äô arguments will not wash. It is not sustainable, for example, for Downing Street to keep the names of senior staffers or officials secret after they have been fined. Nor is it sustainable for fines issued in relation to events in the Downing Street flat to be kept secret. Nor can the Prime Minister or his spokesmen get away with refusing to accept that it will be established, if he is issued with a fine he accepts and pays, that he has broken the law.However much the loyalists may wish to convince themselves otherwise, the idea that a prime minister should survive a process that finds him guilty not only of breaking the law, but breaking extraordinary laws he imposed and implored the public to respect, is simply absurd. So too is the idea that he should survive after denying breaking those laws and issuing emphatic denials in Parliament.The Conservative Party might be capable of deluding itself thus, but if it does the public will draw very different conclusions. They will see a Government ‚Äì already struggling with inflation and finding it difficult to get things done ‚Äì closing ranks and showing appalling double standards.This is dangerous enough for the Tories, but if part of the strategy to prop up the Prime Minister is to limit and discredit potential successors, there follow two more problems. Keeping tall poppies away from high office will mean the quality of day-to-day government will continue to suffer. And it will risk a crisis of leadership following the Johnson premiership, whenever it ends, as the choices are narrowed unnecessarily. It is ridiculous that the likes of Tom Tugendhat and Jeremy Hunt remain on the backbenches, and ridiculous that some in Downing Street see only advantage in Sunak‚Äôs recent difficulties.With notable exceptions ‚Äì such as Nadhim Zahawi‚Äôs vaccine rollout, Ben Wallace‚Äôs work arming the Ukrainians, and Priti Patel‚Äôs forthcoming plans to establish offshore processing for asylum claims ‚Äì much of what the Government is doing is piecemeal, technocratic and often contradictory. The Tories want to intervene in the economy, but have junked their industrial strategy. They say they want lower taxes, but keep putting them up. They promise to level-up the country, but while Michael Gove has the ideas, he lacks the spending power for them to make a difference quickly enough.As with the questions of ethical standards in government, this lack of coherence can be explained in part by the Prime Minister‚Äôs style of leadership. Johnson has deliberately formed a third eleven cabinet, to avoid creating powerful rivals. He has set lofty targets, but neither formed detailed plans to achieve them, nor empowered ministers to do so. He has appointed a chancellor with whom he was always going to clash thanks to their contrasting methods of working and starkly different views of fiscal policy.Tired governments, made complacent by years in office, come to believe that their position of power will last forever. They lose sight of the bigger picture, drift into technocratic decision-making, and their fights with one another grow more important than those with opposing parties and vested interests.Unfortunately, this government now suffers all these ills.So now seems a good time for Conservatives to remind themselves of the binary nature of power in our parliamentary democracy. You either hold power, or you do not. You can change the country, or you can watch the other side change it in ways you dislike.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: archetypal lone wolf ali harbi ali went anonymous schoolboy
story: Ali Harbi Ali was the very definition of a dropout. A young man, who despite every advantage in life, had achieved precisely nothing in his 26 years.That was until October last year, when he achieved notoriety.The savage murder of the much loved and widely respected MP and father of five, Sir David Amess, means Ali‚Äôs name will forever be synonymous with hatred, ision and terrorist violence.The son of middle-class Somali migrants, Ali was born in Southwark and brought up in Croydon with his three younger siblings.His father, Harbi Ali Kullane, was the former director of communications for the prime minister‚Äôs office in Somalia.An outspoken critic of Islamist terrorism in the troubled east African region, Mr Kullane had himself been the subject of numerous death threats from the murderous al-Shabaab group.It was in the early 1990s that Mr Kullane relocated to London from Mogadishu, amid rising tension and violence in Somalia.He and his wife settled in Croydon where they adapted easily to the British way of life.Despite coming from a Muslim family, Ali attended the local Parish Church Infant and Junior School, where he was remembered by staff as a ‚Äúfriendly and polite boy‚Äù.He was a keen chess player and like his siblings, took part in the school‚Äôs annual Christian traditions.His family, while observant Muslims were not particularly religious and the children mixed well with youngsters from all backgrounds.One of Ali‚Äôs former primary school teachers, who did not wish to be identified, said: ‚ÄúHe wasn‚Äôt a high flier, but was a hard working child who was especially good at maths.‚ÄùWith a father who was a senior figure in the Somalian government and an uncle who was the country‚Äôs ambassador to Beijing, a lot was expected of Ali.From a young age his parents let it be known he wanted to pursue a career in medicine.School friends insist he never showed much ambition for anything.At the age of 11, he moved to Riddlesdown High School in Purley, where the supermodel Kate Moss had once been a pupil.Despite his parents‚Äô lofty expectations, his academic prowess did not quite match up. Fellow pupils remember Ali as being ‚Äúdistinctly average‚Äù and lacking any direction, drive or determination.He had friends but was not especially popular, enjoyed sport but was not particularly talented.One of his former classmates said: ‚ÄúHe was the sort of person who was easily forgettable. He didn‚Äôt have a big personality and didn‚Äôt make much of an impression on you. He just kept his head down.¬†‚ÄúI never remember him causing any sort of trouble but equally he never really stood out academically. He had a small group of friends who would hang around together and he would have a kick about, but other than that I can‚Äôt recall a single anecdote about him.‚ÄùIt was clear by his mid-teens that he was not going to achieve the grades to study medicine but he applied to do a radiography degree instead. He was accepted onto a course at City University in London in 2014.While it was not quite a medical degree, friends of the family ‚Äì particularly in east Africa ‚Äì were under the impression Ali was training to become a doctor.One source in Somalia told The : ‚ÄúAli was training in the NHS and it was a great source of pride for his parents. His father was especially proud when he was back in Somalia to tell people that his eldest child was working at a top London hospital.‚ÄùBy now his mother and father had separated and while she remained in the family home in Croydon, Mr Kullane began splitting his time between London and east Africa, where he retained homes in Somalia and Nairobi, Kenya.Ali moved into his grandmother‚Äôs home in north London and started attending lectures at university.But it was soon clear his heart was not in radiography and in 2016, part way through his second year, he dropped out altogether.He wrote to his course tutor and said he was leaving university because he had decided to take a ‚Äúdifferent path in life‚Äù. That different path was terrorism.By his own admission, Ali had become self radicalised in 2014, becoming completely obsessed with events in Syria.In 2013, British MPs had narrowly rejected a proposal to launch air strikes against Bashar al-Assad‚Äôs government to deter the use of chemical weapons.But as the Middle East continued to descend into violence Ali became more and more fixated by the rise of Isis and saw any attempt by the West to suppress it as a modern crusade against Islam.However, unlike many idealistic young extremists, he was not tempted to travel to the region to join Isis, preferring to wage jihad from his keyboard in the safety of his bedroom.¬†With no job to go to, Ali would often stay up all night looking at extremist websites. He idolised the British born Isil killers dubbed The Beatles, following their murderous exploits online.Around two years ago Ali moved out of his grandmother‚Äôs home in the Bounds Green area of north London and moved into a flat with a female relative in Kentish Town.One local resident, who would regularly see Ali smoking outside the flat, said he believed he had clashed with his father, possibly over the fact he did not appear to be doing anything with his life.By this stage he had become determined to wage a holy war or jihad in the UK, but was just not entirely clear how to go about it.Sources in the security services do not have any evidence that Ali was in contact with a wider network and he does not appear to have shared his intentions with anyone else.He was the archetypal lone wolf, poisoned by toxic Islamist material online. But unlike many of his fellow terrorists, he took an extraordinarily long time to put his plan into action.The knife he used to murder Sir David, was purchased a full five years before the attack.By May 2019, a year after MPs had voted for airstrikes in Syria and three years after the murder of Jo Cox, Ali settled on a politician as his target.He decided that any of the 317 MPs who had voted in favour of taking action against Assad were fair game.But even having come to that conclusion, it was another two years before he did anything practical about it.Whether his plans were frustrated by the lockdown or whether he was simply gripped by procrastination, we will probably never know.Between March 9, 2021 and July 5, 2021, he visited the home of Michael Gove, the cabinet minister, even drafting a plan of how he might attack him when he went out for one of his regular morning jogs.He also considered the possibility of simply kicking down his front door and bursting into his home late at night.By September last year he had changed his mind about Mr Gove and began looking instead at Mike Freer the MP for Finchley ‚Äì whose constituency office was an easy Tube ride from his Kentish Town flat.After losing interest in that idea, he then spotted a Tweet by Sir David Amess‚Äôs office, offering surgery appointments at his constituency in Southend.Never one willing to expend too much effort to pursue jihad, Ali realised he could travel to Southend relatively easily by train from the nearby Gospel Oak station and so he sent an email requesting an appointment.Providing a false address and lying about wanting to discuss the state of Christian churches in Southend, Ali was granted an audience with Sir David, who was desperate to meet constituents face to face following the isolation of lockdown.On the morning of October 15 last year, having been awake most of the night, Ali left the Kentish Town flat and made his way by train to Leigh-on-Sea, where Sir David was holding his constituent meetings.CCTV footage of his journey shows him calmly engaging with rail staff and fellow passengers, seemingly without a care in the world.At around midday he arrived at the Belfairs Methodist Church where Sir David was hosting his fortnightly surgery.After being introduced to the MP, Ali began questioning him about foreign policy, before suddenly standing up, apologising and then repeatedly stabbing him with a kitchen knife.There were no shouts of ‚ÄúAllahu Akbar‚Äù, but witnesses described him having a look of self-satisfaction.He immediately messaged a number of family members and associates to inform them what he had done and his younger sister rang him, screaming down the phone: ‚ÄúWhy have you done it?‚ÄùAli replied: ‚ÄúI‚Äôve done it because of Syria, I‚Äôve done it because of the innocent people. I‚Äôve done it because of the bombing. He deserved to die.‚ÄùHe told witnesses he wanted the police to shoot him so he could become a ‚Äúhero‚Äù.But in the event his ‚Äúheroism‚Äù departed him and he was tackled to the ground and arrested by two unarmed officers.During his police interview Ali calmly admitted to the murder, telling detectives he had done it for reasons of ‚Äúterrorism‚Äù and ‚Äúreligion‚Äù.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: calls sea eagle cull lambs torn limb limb
story: Sea eagles should be culled because a reintroduction of the predators to the UK has led to them terrorising rural communities and killing lambs, an MP has claimed. ¬†Angus MacNeil, who represents the Western Isles, claimed numbers of the raptors, which were extinct in Britain before they were brought back in the 1970s, were now ‚Äúout of control‚Äù following successful breeding programmes.He said plans to drastically expand the population further would drive crofters out of business due to rising cases of lambs being ‚Äútorn limb from limb‚Äù by eagles which had moved away from feeding on fish.¬†His call for a cull of the protected species provoked a backlash from conservationists, with the reintroduction of the birds seen as a major success story by wildlife bodies.The RSPB suggested the number of lamb deaths attributed to sea eagles had been exaggerated.However, the MP, who keeps 33 ewes, criticised city-based commentators who he claimed had little understanding of the impact the eagles were having on rural livelihoods.Two of his neighbour‚Äôs healthy four-day-old lambs in Barra had been ‚Äúripped apart‚Äù by eagles at the weekend, Mr MacNeil said.He posted gruesome images of the carcasses online, saying the birds would be more accurately named ‚Äúlamb eagles‚Äù.¬†¬†Mr MacNeil, a veteran SNP MP, said he had also heard reports of a woman in Fort William fighting off an eagle with her umbrella after it attacked her chihuahua, and another bird killing a Jack Russell on Uist, in the Outer Hebrides.Sea eagles were driven to extinction in the UK in 1918 but were reintroduced to the Isle of Rum in 1975.There are now believed to be more than 150 breeding pairs of the birds in Scotland, a number that experts say could rise to 400 in coming decades.Mr MacNeil claimed this would spell disaster for crofters and claimed there were already ‚Äútoo many‚Äù.‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying wipe them all out,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey are majestic birds. But clearly we need to manage it, and inidual birds are getting a taste for eating stuff provided by man.‚ÄúRather than searching for their food, they‚Äôre having a buffet laid on by farmers and crofters.‚ÄúA lot of crofters are just scraping by and are now facing a cost of living crisis.‚ÄúPeople sitting in their arm chairs with double glazing and central heating are saying a few lambs is a price worth paying. But would they be happy to take a pay cut or to live among rats, wolves and bears?‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúThis re-introduction has got out of control. They are taking people‚Äôs livelihoods. Crofters and farmers are losing hundreds of pounds and they are threatening crofting as a way of life.‚ÄùNature Scot, the Scottish Government agency, said the reintroduction had benefited tourism and ruled out a cull.¬†A spokesman said a scheme had been introduced to help businesses manage the problem, including offering equipment designed to deter eagles, although direct compensation is not provided for killed lambs.¬†The two lambs killed at the weekend had cost his neighbour ¬£168, Mr MacNeil said. He said he had challenged those opposed to a cull to meet the cost themselves but that ‚Äúno-one has come forward with a penny‚Äù.¬†In Argyll, crofters have claimed there are so many lamb-eating sea eagles that there is now one for every sheep farm in their area. Some have said they have been forced to move ewes to rented fields to escape the predators.¬†Patrick Krause, chief executive of the Scottish Crofting Federation, said the attacks were ‚Äúdefinitely‚Äù becoming more common and claimed conservation bodies were ‚Äúin denial‚Äù about the growing scale of the problem.‚ÄúThis is a very large and dangerous predator that has been reintroduced,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere aren‚Äôt the same number of fish so of course they are going to look for mammals on land. One of the reasons they are such successful predators is because they can eat a wide variety of¬† things. The number of complaints we are hearing of lost lambs are rising all the time.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not just lambs that are being attacked, it‚Äôs adult sheep as well. We believe there does need to be a reduction in numbers, but unfortunately I think a cull just isn‚Äôt going to happen.‚ÄùNFU Scotland said sea eagle reintroduction had been ‚Äúvery challenging‚Äù to the livelihoods of farmers and crofters because of lamb attacks. However, the organisation stopped short of backing calls for a cull.A spokesman said: ‚ÄúThe Sea Eagle stakeholder panel, which includes NFU Scotland, NatureScot, RSPB Scotland and others, is committed to working together to try and resolve all conflicts, balancing the conservation of sea eagles with the needs of farmers and crofters to sustainably rear livestock.‚ÄùMore from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: easter holidaymakers urged travel night country braced busiest
story: Easter holidaymakers have been urged to travel at night to avoid road chaos as travel woes are set to worsen.An estimated 21.5 million leisure trips will be made between Good Friday and Easter Monday, making it the busiest weekend on Britain‚Äôs roads in at least eight years, according to the RAC.As families seek to avoid chaos on the railway network, with 2,500 train routes due to be delayed or cancelled, and in airports, where Covid staff shortages continue to cause disruption, more are expected to travel by car for the first bank holiday in two years with no legal restrictions.Long delays are also expected to continue on roads in Kent because of a shortage of cross-Channel sailings caused by the suspension of operations by P&ampO Ferries after it sacked nearly 800 workers.The RAC, which began tracking motorists' Easter plans in 2014, has urged drivers wishing to avoid congestion this weekend to set off before 9am or delay their journeys until after 7:30pm.Around 2,000 roadworks will be in place over the Easter weekend, and the busiest single day on the roads is expected to be Good Friday.In addition to increased congestion, motorists also face the most expensive Easter on record when it comes to fuel prices.Latest government figures show the average cost of a litre of petrol at UK forecourts on April 4 was 161.9p, with diesel at 176.0p.Likely congestion spots will include the M25 clockwise from Junction 8 (Reigate Hill Interchange, Surrey) to Junction 16 (Denham Interchange, Buckinghamshire), the M6 north between Greater Manchester and the Lake District, and near Stonehenge, Wiltshire.Meanwhile, several airlines and airports are struggling to cope with staff sickness and shortages, prompting thousands of flights to be cancelled by easyJet and British Airways in recent weeks.Manchester Airport is warning departing passengers to expect delays of up to 90 minutes, whilst rail passengers are being warned of delays as Network Rail carries out 530 engineering projects costing a total of ¬£83 million.The West Coast Main Line will be closed between London Euston and Milton Keynes between Good Friday and Easter Monday because of upgrades of the existing line and HS2 work.This will affect football supporters as Liverpool and Manchester City meet in an FA Cup semi-final match at Wembley on Saturday.Rod Dennis, an RAC traffic spokesman, said: After two years of relatively quiet Easter bank holidays on the roads, our research suggests a return to traffic levels that are much more typical of this time of year.It's very possible this weekend could turn out to be one of the busiest for leisure journeys for many years.Add in the impact of disruption on the rail network and one of the biggest fixtures of the sporting calendar taking place this weekend, and you have all the ingredients needed for problems on the roads.Traffic volumes will likely be even higher if some warm spring sunshine makes an appearance.Mr Dennis urged drivers to make sure vehicles are prepared for getaway trips.This is even more important for anyone travelling longer distances than they have for several months, he said.A breakdown is much less likely if a car's oil and coolant levels, as well as tyre pressure and tread depth, have all been checked before setting out.A Network Rail spokesperson said: 2,500 train services over the four-day Easter weekend will be affected by works. Some will be running on alternative or shorter routes with buses.Over 95 per cent of our network is open for business but works will affect some routes. Please check before you travel.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: france should take leaf brexit britains book
story: Meanwhile, the centre-right candidates, debating the ‚Äúgreat replacement‚Äù theory that the growth of the Muslim population is an attempt to diplace whites, distanced themselves from the term, but not the premise. Val√©rie P√©cresse did not like it because ‚Äúit implies we‚Äôre already screwed.‚ÄùI‚Äôve been fascinated by the fate of the Safe To Be Me conference, which the Government was promoting as Britain‚Äôs first state-backed LGBT summit (Britain being evil, yet again) ‚Äì till the Tories decided not to ban trans conversion therapy and various groups pulled out. This failed venture cost taxpayers ¬£650,000. The projected budget was ¬£8.1 million.While Westminster is pretending to be desperately upset that this conference has been cancelled, some readers might be more surprised that it was ever taking place. We can infer from the decision of supporters to withdraw that you and I were paying big bucks to bankroll an event to promote policies that the elected Government is opposed to. According to a statement made in December, Safe To Be Me was being worked on by 8.25 members of staff ‚Äúwithin the international LGBT+ team in the Cabinet Office‚Äù, which raises the questions, what on earth is an ‚Äúinternational LGBT+ team‚Äù and why do we need one? Given that we cannot house our people adequately (16,000 families are being evicted each month), this doesn‚Äôt sound like a priority.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: frances populist revolt coming
story: What did they mean by that? The French public has delivered a first-round result in their presidential election that leaves political nerds unable to reach a consensus about where events are likely to go from here.On the one hand, a four-point margin for the incumbent Emmanuel Macron over Marine Le Pen was bigger than some polls had predicted. The Western world‚Äôs ‚Äúcentrist dad‚Äù brigade might have been inclined to breathe a sigh of relief and claim there is no discernible path to victory for Madame Le Pen in the second-round run-off in a fortnight‚Äôs time.But the centrist dads have been wrong before ‚Äì about Brexit, about Donald Trump and about Britain‚Äôs 2019 general election, to cite just a few recent examples. There is at least as strong a case for looking at yesterday‚Äôs result and concluding that the establishment-minded centre cannot hold and that it is now not a question of whether there will be a populist Right takeover of the apparatus of government in France, but merely of when.For a start, there is a simple comparison to be made with the first-round vote of five years ago. Back then the charismatic insurgent Macron won 24 per cent, to Le Pen‚Äôs 21 per cent. Half a decade has added an unspectacular two or three percentage points to the vote shares of both and the same to Jean-Luc Melenchon, the far-Left populist who scored 19.5 per cent five years ago and 22 per cent last night.But look at what has happened to the traditional establishment parties of centre-Left and centre-Right, the Socialists and the Republicans. Five years ago the former was thought to be at its lowest possible ebb when its candidate won just six per cent, while the latter was deeply disappointed with a 20 per cent share. Last night those scores slumped to two per cent and five per cent respectively.So France is in a vigorously anti-establishment mood and it is hard to see how five years of incumbency and presidential peacocking will enable Macron to harness that as well as he did in 2017. There is a widespread feeling that he is a ‚Äúpresident of the rich‚Äù with an entourage dominated by privileged young Parisians swanning around in made-to-measure suits and harbouring luxury liberal beliefs.Le Pen, by contrast, has sought out the populist sweet spot of being to the Right on cultural issues and to the Left on economic ones. Her campaign has taken her around the market towns of France, speaking to the common people who formed the bulk of the ‚ÄúGilet Jaune‚Äù protestors and who care more about the price of petrol than the high politics of EU summits or even the suffering of Ukraine.In the first round this time, Le Pen has not only established a strong lead among working class voters but also among the young, with a radical plan to scrap income tax for the under-30s being the core of of her economic offering.Macron himself appears to understand that he will not win the run-off as a conventional capital city centrist given the current public mood and last night pledged to represent the aspirations of those who voted for Le Pen and her fellow Right populist Eric Zemmour, the bulk of whose seven per cent vote share is surely currently heading her way.The decisive factor now will be where the voters of Melenchon end up. Many despise the values of the Paris-based elites just as much as Le Pen‚Äôs supporters do and many also are firmly traditionalist on social and cultural matters. Last night Melenchon did Macron a favour by urging them not to vote for Le Pen, though he could not bring himself to endorse the French president.The next two weeks will see French elites attempt to kill Le Pen‚Äôs ambitions in the usual way ‚Äì using her surname and previous leadership of the Front National against her, as well as her unwise past praise for Vladimir Putin, in a bid to persuade voters that she is simply not a respectable choice.But Macron himself seems to understand that, barring Le Pen malfunctioning disastrously again in a televised debate as she did last time, this will not be enough. During his first term Macron has tried hard to keep onboard voters who are anxious about the state of French society and has made a series of speeches about enforcing integration into the French way of life for migrant communities.If he holds on in two weeks‚Äô time ‚Äì as he is just about favourite to do ‚Äì it will surely be because he remains a sufficiently canny campaigner to keep one foot in the populist camp himself rather than because the French public are gravitating back towards establishment norms.Nobody expects anything like the crushing two-to-one drubbing he gave Le Pen in the run-off last time. Even if they beat her this time, how the French establishment would fend her off again in 2027 is very difficult to see.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: gallery highlights male gaze manet masterpiece woke attempt
story: The ‚Äúmale gaze‚Äù in a Manet masterpiece has been highlighted by the Courtauld Gallery after curators introduced new labels addressing ‚Äúmisogyny‚Äù in art.The London gallery, which holds the UK‚Äôs foremost Impressionist collection, reviewed the labelling of all of its paintings as part of a three-year, ¬£57 million refurbishment, and some information panels now address issues like artists‚Äô racism and sexism.Manet's masterpiece, A Bar at the Folies-Berg√®re, has been reinterpreted with a new label which suggests that the painting has an ‚Äúunsettling‚Äù quality because of the presence of a man on the canvas.The 1882 work depicts a barmaid staring out at the viewer of the painting and - in a mirrored image - towards a male patron of the eponymous Folies-Berg√®re (a Parisian cabaret club) who returns her gaze.The female subject‚Äôs ‚Äúenigmatic expression is unsettling‚Äù, a new information panel states, ‚Äúespecially as she appears to be interacting with a male customer‚Äù.The suggestion that an ‚Äúunsettling‚Äù quality of the painting is enhanced because the woman talking to a man has been criticised for unwitting ‚Äúmisogyny‚Äù because it diminishes the position of the female model in the work.Ruth Millington, a historian whose book Muse chronicles the female inspirations for great art, said: ‚ÄúIt completely shifts the viewer‚Äôs attention away from her and onto the man in the picture.‚ÄúThis interpretation, in a woke attempt to call out misogyny, unwittingly centres the male gaze.¬†The writer implies that the woman is unsettled by the man‚Äôs presence, framing her as a passive victim of her circumstances.‚ÄúCurators must stop trapping female muses and models with male-centred interpretations such as this.‚ÄúIn a painting of multiple gazes, it‚Äôs unfair and misogynistic to emphasise the male perspective.¬† I‚Äôd rather read a fresh new label which invites viewers to imagine what the woman is thinking.‚ÄùThe model Manet used for the painting was a real-life woman called Suzon who worked at the Folies-Berg√®re, a venue frequented where prostitutes plied their treade, and it has been suggested that a subtext of the painting is the exploited barmaid‚Äôs availabilty to male customers, along with the alcohol she is selling.The Courtauld holds the UK‚Äôs leading collection of Gauguin works, but the French painter known for his time in Tahitian subjects - and teenage brides - ¬†has now been reappraised by curators for ‚Äútaking advantage of his position as a European coloniser‚Äù.A label on his Post-Impressionist work Nevermore states the painting depicts ‚Äúone of several teenagers that he took on as ‚Äòwives‚Äô‚Äù, adding that ‚Äúthe widespread racist fantasy of Tahitian girls as sexually precocious led to their unabashed exploitation‚Äù.An information panel for his 1897 painting Te Rerioa now informs visitors that its subject matter was intended to ‚Äúappeal to a white European audience‚Äù by ‚Äúexoticising‚Äù Polynesians.Further information on Gauguin‚Äôs memoir Avant et Apres - recently acquired by the Courtauld - states that the 213-page manuscript is ‚Äúpeppered with examples of his own racism and misogyny‚Äù.The treatment of other cultures as ‚Äúprimitive‚Äù has also been addressed in a new label for the self-portrait of Roger Fry, the Bloomsbury group painter, known for his advancement of Gauguin-inspired ‚ÄúPrimitivism‚Äù in Western art.Updated information on the portrait states: ¬†‚ÄúFor modernist artists and writers, African art belonged to an earlier stage of civilisation known as ‚Äúprimitivism ‚Äú‚ÄúThis reveals the reactive ideas of the time, which underpinned even the views of progressives like Fry‚ÄùThe Courtauld‚Äôs relabelling comes following widespread reassessment of problematic artists, with the Picasso Museum in Paris recently inviting artists to critique the painter‚Äôs personal life, and the National Gallery highlighting Gauguin‚Äôs sexual proclivities in a 2019 show.Manet has also faced reappraisal over works like Olympia, a bold nude that scandalised the Paris Salon in 1865, and which has invited more recent criticism at the Mus√©e d‚ÄôOrsay for its sidelining of a black woman in the painting.The Courtauld has been contacted for comment.More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron will of the railway workers keeping Ukraine runningExtinction Rebellion protests threaten Easter getaway... but police too helpless to stop themMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsBroadband and Mobile DealsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pre booking take rubbish dump may finally binned
story: Booking a slot for the dump may come to an end after the Government urged councils to drop the pandemic practice and ‚Äúmove back to normality‚Äù, as it tries to tackle fly-tipping.¬†Many councils introduced a booking system for households to leave their rubbish at their local dump during the pandemic, citing the need to maintain social distancing.¬†But the practice could be increasing fly-tipping, the Government has warned, as people find they cannot book a slot to get rid of their waste for months.¬†Government guidelines said council waste disposal should be available ‚Äúat all reasonable times‚Äù, which it said is hard to reconcile with booking systems.¬†It asked councils to confirm why they had introduced booking systems and committed to reviewing the number.¬†The move is part of the Government efforts to clamp down on fly-tipping, which has grown 16 per cent since the start of the pandemic and costs the UK nearly ¬£400 million annually.¬†Among the councils that have brought in booking slots for their rubbish dumps since the pandemic is Kent, which last year voted to make the changes permanent.¬†This was despite strident local opposition, with one councillor arguing the issue had become ‚Äúmore isive than Brexit‚Äù.¬†Craig Mackinlay, South Thanet MP, called for the decision to be reversed.¬†These outdoor sites present no risk and doubt ever did,‚Äù he said.¬†Defending the decision to extend the scheme, the council said it had brought ‚Äúenvironmental, operational and communication benefits‚Äù.¬†Under the Government‚Äôs latest plans, households will also no longer have to pay to get rid of DIY waste including plasterboards, bricks and bath units, which it argued were being unfairly classed as construction waste.¬†The move could save households around ¬£10 a year and help stop around 60,000 annual fly-tipping incidents with construction, demolition and excavation material.¬†The Local Government Association argued that getting rid of the payments for collecting household DIY waste would put a strain on council resources and could be abused by builders dumping their waste.¬†Councillor David Renard, environment spokesman, said: ‚ÄúSome councils have had to introduce charges for this waste due to the rising costs of providing the service and the financial pressure they are under.‚ÄúMoney raised from charges goes back into services so councils can continue to offer disposal facilities for these materials to residents, who would otherwise find them difficult to get rid of and will ensure that the system is not abused by those seeking to dispose of trade waste for free.‚ÄùUnder the plans, the Government will also provide ¬£450,000 in grants to 10 councils to measures to tackle fly-tipping, including CCTV and artificial intelligence.¬†The Country Land and Business Association (CLA) welcomed the move, but said not enough was being done to help private landowners, who have to bear the cost of any waste dumped on their land.¬†Mark Tufnell, president of the CLA, said. ‚ÄúOne CLA member, who is a regular victim, is having to pay ¬£50,000 each year to clear waste dumped on their land.‚ÄùJacob Hayler, executive director of the Environmental Services Association, said: ‚ÄúThere is no single ‚Äòsilver bullet‚Äô to tackle the scourge of fly-tipping, so we are pleased to see the Government announcing a range of new measures to help deter this deeply anti-social criminal behaviour.‚ÄúOf particular importance is stopping this material from falling into the hands of organised waste criminals, leading to larger scale fly-tipping.‚Äù¬†More from NewsRussia-Ukraine latest news: Russia issues new warning against Finland and Sweden joining Nato‚ÄòWe are holding back the horde‚Äô: Mariupol fighters battle on weeks after experts said city would fallBritish scheme to take in Ukrainians needs enhanced ‚Äòmatching‚Äô elementCharities and MPs call for urgent rollout of mental health nurses in GP surgeriesThe iron title: 5 questions rishi sunak must
story: questions Rishi Sunak must answer as he demands probe into his own conductMr Sunaks family finances have been in the spotlight since it emerged his we Akshata Murty had non-domicile tax status, allowing her to legally avoid paying UK taxes on overseas incomeChancellor Rishi Sunak Image: Getty ImagesByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsCrisis-hit Rishi Sunak will undergo an investigation by the Prime Ministeraposs sleaze watchdog as he battles to save his political career. Downing Street confirmed that Boris Johnson had ordered his ethics adviser Lord Geidt to probe the Chancelloraposs conduct after a request from Mr Sunak himself.Mr Sunakaposs family finances have been in the spotlight after it emerged that his we Akshata Murty had non-domicile tax status, allowing her to legally avoid paying UK taxes on overseas income. She U-turned on Friday to save her husbandaposs job by vowing to pay UK tax on herforeign income, which includes an estimated ¬£. million-a-year in shares from the Indian IT giant Infosys - founded by her billionaire father Narayana Murty.Mr Sunak attempted to defuse the row by asking Lord Geidt to investigate, as he said he was confident he had declared everything properly.  The Prime Ministeraposs deputy spokeswoman said: Iaposm not aware of whether Lord Geidt himself has begun his work. But I can confirm that the Prime Minister has agreed to the request from the Chancellor for Lord Geidt to undertake this work. Here are some of the questions the Chancellor needs to clear up. How much has his we saved in UK tax through non-dom status  Mr Sunakaposs nightmare week began when it emerged that his we held non-dom status, potentially saving her millions of pounds in tax. The arrangement, which is legal, allows people who are domiciled abroad to avoid paying UK tax on their overseas income. Her spokeswoman initially tried to claim it was because she was an Indian citizen but she then admitted that Ms Murty paid the British Government ¬£,-a-year to keep the status.Ms Murty was forced to into a U-turn on Friday and said she would now pay UK tax on her foreign income. This includes a .% stake in Indian IT giant Infosys, founded by her billionaire father Naranya Murty. Her share is worth an estimated ¬£ million and provides around ¬£. million in idends per year. Under non-dom rules, Ms Murty was not obliged to pay UK tax on this income - and it is unclear how big her tax bill could have been.The BBC estimated she would have saved ¬£. million in UK tax based on these figures.Ms Murty remains domiciled in India where she eventually wants to . What did Rishi Sunak declare about it  Mr Sunak is understood to have declared his weaposs tax status to the Cabinet Office when he first became a minister in . Sources said the Treasury was also aware, so as to manage any potential conflicts of interest. However, what happened after he made the declaration is not clear, because her status is not on his public declaration of ministerial interests.  Mr Sunak has asked for Lord Geidt to review all his declarations of interest since he became a minister in  to ensure they had been properly stated. He said he was confident he had acted appropriately at all times, but his overriding concern was that the public should have confidence in the answers. Guidance to ministers says the list is not an account of all the interests or financial arrangements held by a Minister or members of their close family, adding: Rather it is a list of any such interests, which are, or might reasonably be perceived to be, directly relevant to that particular minister‚Äôs public duties. Why did he hold a US green card until last year  Mr Sunak confirmed on Friday that he held a US green card for more than a year while he was Chancellor. A spokeswoman said he sought guidance ahead of his first US trip in a Government capacity in October - despite taking on the top Treasury job in February . People with green cards are treated as lawful permanent residents by US tax authorities, and it is seen as a step towards full citizenship.  Mr Sunakaposs spokeswoman said he filed US tax s, but specically as a non-resident, in full compliance with the law. The Sunaks met at Stanford University and worked in the US before moving to the UK to pursue Mr Sunakaposs political career. They are understood to have a holiday home in Calornia.At a Downing Street press conference, Boris Johnson said he was unaware of Mr Sunak holding a US green card, but stressed that the Chancellor had done absolutely everything he was required to do. Is he a beneficiary in tax havens  The Independent reported on Friday that Mr Sunak was listed as the beneficiary of trusts set up in the British Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands to help manage the tax and business affairs of Ms Murtyaposs family interests. But a spokeswoman close to the Sunak family said: No-one in Akshataaposs family is aware of this alleged trust. Labour called on Mr Sunak to explain the situation.Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves said: We need full disclosure now. Has he broken the ministerial code  Labour has accused the Chancellor of breaking the ministerial code, the set of guidelines that top politicians must follow.It states that outside interests must be reported to the Permanent Secretary of their department. It is understood Mr Sunak did report his weaposs status to the Cabinet Office and the Treasury was also aware. The ministerial code says the register of interests should also cover interests of the ministeraposs spouse or partner and close family which might be thought to give rise to a conflict. Lord Geidt will examine this as part of his investigation. Politicians who break the ministerial code are traditionally expected to resign. news politics chancellor-rishi-sunak-asks-prime-"Rishi Sunak faces a whole list of concerns amid tax rowByRachel WearmouthSenior Political CorrespondentRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsRishi Sunak has asked the Prime Minister for a probe into his own financial affairs. The under-fire Chancellor tonight took the dramatic step of referring himself to Boris Johnsonaposs independent adviser on ministerial interests, Lord Geidt, following a growing row over his familyaposs financial arrangements. It comes hours after he had ordered a Whitehall inquiry into how his weaposs tax arrangements were leaked to the media. Mr Sunakaposs political future hangs by a thread as he faces fresh calls to come clean over his tax affairs and US immigration status. The Tory minister tried to claim his we Akshata Murty was the victim of a smear campaign, after it emerged she held non-domiciled tax status, which allows people to avoid paying UK tax on overseas income.  The Chancellor, whose Spring Statement last month failed to help struggling families cope with the UKaposs biggest fall in living standards since the time of rationing, was reportedly weighing up whether to quit after a string of damaging stories. His team has previously argued all declarations to the register of ministerial interests were above board. In a statement posted on Twitter on Sunday evening, Mr Sunak said: ‚ÄúI have always followed the rules and I hope such a review will provide further clarity.‚Äù In a letter to Mr Johnson, Mr Sunak said his ‚Äúoverriding concern‚Äù was to maintain public confidence.  ‚ÄúMy overriding concern is that the public retain confidence in the answers that are given and I believe the best way of achieving this is to ensure those answers are entirely independent, without bias or favour,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTo that end I would recommend that Lord Geidt makes all his conclusions public. ‚ÄúI am confident that such a review of my declarations will find all relevant information was appropriately declared. ‚ÄúI have throughout my ministerial career followed the advice of officials regarding matters or propriety and disclosure and will continue to do so.‚Äù  The White House has been urged to investigate after Mr Sunak admitted holding a US green card until October  - while he was the Chancellor.Mr Sunak has been hit with reports that he is listed as a beneficiary of tax haven trusts in the Cayman Islands and British Virgin Islands, despite pledging to close tax loopholes. Meanwhile, Infosys, an Indian firm founded by his weaposs billionaire father, where Ms Murty holds ¬£m of shares in, is urgently reviewing its base in Moscow. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was a matter of ‚Äúbasic fairness‚Äù that the Chancellor‚Äôs family should pay tax in the same way as everyone . ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the Chancellor gets that. That raises real questions about his judgment,‚Äù she told BBC‚Äôs Sunday Morning programme.  Policing Minister Kit Malthouse admitted Ms Murtyaposs status as a non-dom - something she gave up last week amid public fury - was ‚Äúnot ideal‚Äù, but nonetheless rushed to defend Mr Sunak from colleagues who declared the Chancelloraposs career to be toast. He said the Chancellor was a ‚Äúsmart, clever, committed politician‚Äù who had helped steer the economy through the worst of the pandemic. Ms Murty, who is an Indian citizen, dramatically announced on Friday that she would now pay UK taxes on all her worldwide income as she did not want her tax status to be a distraction. It has been estimated that her non-dom status could have saved her ¬£ million in taxes on idends on her shares. Mr Malthouse admitted it was ‚Äúnot a brilliant time‚Äù for the details to come out when the country was struggling with a cost of living crisis. ‚ÄúRishi Sunak has been a remarkable force for good in this country over the last two years, he said.‚ÄúHe put in place some incredible support schemes during the pandemic at enormous speed. ‚ÄúIt is not ideal, but we all when we sign up for this job know that there is going to be rough times and smooth times,‚Äù he added. Meanwhile sources close to Mr Sunak have played down reports that he was moving his we and two daughters out of Downing Street to escape the glare of the media. The Sunday Mirror published pictures of removal vans arriving in the street on Saturday to take their belongings away. One source said however they had always intended to spend more time in their west London home as their elder daughter, Krishna, entered her final term of primary school before moving on to secondary school. Mr Sunak is still expected to stay in Downing Street during the week while joining them at weekends. Labouraposs Angela Rayner said: ‚ÄúThe chaos caused by the Conservatives over the last week must be brought to an end. ‚ÄúA fish rots from the head. It is the Prime Minister‚Äôs responsibility to bring this debacle to a close by ensuring that standards are upheld across his Cabinet. When it comes to the Tories hiking up taxes on working people, it seems it is one rule for them and another for the rest of us.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Breaking NewsRishi Sunak" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: fishy rishi beached chancellor struggling
story: Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor struggling to survive and considering quittingChancellor Rishi Sunak seems unlikely to ever succeed the morally corrupt incumbent Prime Minister Boris Johnson - all down to the ongoing non-dom scandal related to his we, Kevin Maguire says" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _The-Prince-Of-Wales-And-Duchess-Of-Cornwall-Celebrate-The-British-Asian-Trust.jpg" width"" "" The Tory minister and his billionaire heiress we Akshata Murthy were the victims of a smear campaign this week Image: UK Press via Getty ImagesopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Apr |commentsFish rot from the head down and the stench of contempt in Downing Street is seeing scales falling from voters‚Äô eyes. Fishy Rishi is a beached Chancellor without credibility, struggling to survive and contemplating resignation over the Rishi Notax scandal. The nets trawling the sordid financial affairs of his incredibly wealthy family may yet produce another jaw-dropper that will force the Tory moneybags to resign in disgrace. And the morally corrupt Prime Minister he‚Äôs now unlikely ever to succeed ‚Äì charlatan Boris Johnson, who presided over widespread law-breaking during Covid, his head on the chopping block until Putin spared him ‚Äì remains a rotten man. Downing Street‚Äôs decaying neighbours represent a Conservative government decomposing rapidly, with ministers mocked for regurgitating on the airwaves pathetic excuses for indefensible behaviour.  Draw a Venn diagram and the fools spouting drivel to shield slippery Sunak and an heiress we, Akshata Murty, who‚Äôd pay ¬£, to avoid millions of pounds in British tax, overlap with idiots who ly claimed Johnson didn‚Äôt hold parties and is innocent of all charges. Whether what non-dom Murty and Green Card Sunak did was legal misses the point that it is unacceptable for a Chancellor to put up taxes for the little people while his family lawfully dodge them. Sleaze taking the Tories back to the John Major era is a glorious opportunity for Labour ‚Äì and a challenge. Leader Keir Starmer is receiving conflicting advice. Either he sticks with Ed Miliband and Jeremy Corbyn‚Äôs proposals to end the non-dom scam, or he listens to those who say it would be seen as anti-business. Championing fairness could draw a thick red line between Labour and the Tories at the election. The Conservative fish is rotting... Labour needs to use its head.
