title: oscars now open accusations double
story: Oscars are now open to accusations of double standards over Will Smith slap responseDarren Lewis says consistency is clearly lacking in the wake of Will Smith slapping Chris Rock on stage at the Oscars - sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs awardsWill Smith and we Jada Pinkett Smith at the  Vanity Fair Oscars Party after he slapped Chris Rock Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDarren Lewis:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsIn their rush to be seen to be doing something about Will Smith, the Oscars board of governors ended up doing nothing more than leaving themselves open to accusations of double standards.They couldn‚Äôt take away Will Smith‚Äôs Best Actor Oscar for slapping Chris Rock when sexual predators Harvey Weinstein and Roman Polanski still have theirs.They couldn‚Äôt expel Men In Black star Smith because he‚Äôd moved far more quickly to take control of the story and resign from the Academy.So they banned him from all their events, including the Oscars, for  years.Fair enough. We are all agreed that you can‚Äôt go around slapping people, even though this column remains of the opinion that we are in a weird place with so-called comedians at awards nights: Dead set against violence but prepared to normalise the kind of bullying and humiliation of iniduals at these types of events that would probably earn you a trip to HR in the workplace. Again, shame on Rock who made Smith‚Äôs we Jada the butt of his jokes because of her shaven head. It is well known she suffers from alopecia. Would she have been fair gameshe‚Äôd had breast cancer  Reading Smith‚Äôs autobiography on holiday last week , I was also struck by this in the second chapter. ‚ÄúWhen I was nine years old, I watched my father punch my mother in the side of her head so hard that she collapsed. I saw her spit blood. That moment in that bedroom, probably more than any other in my le, has defined who I am today. ‚ÄúWithin everything that I have done since then ‚Äì the awards, the accolades, the spotlights and the attention, the characters and the laughs ‚Äì there has been a subtle string of apologies to my mother for my inaction that day. ‚ÄúFor failing her in that moment. For failing to stand up to my father. For being a coward.‚Äù None of that excuses his actions two weeks ago. But it does explain why he snapped on that night. His book also details a string of examples he would come to recognise as double standards in his negative treatment over the years. A furious debate is understood to have raged within the Academy‚Äôs , members in Whats App groups in the fortnight after Smith‚Äôs slap.It would be fascinating to see a Venn diagram of which members were dead set on Smith‚Äôs suspension and which ones signed a  petition calling for Polanski ‚Äì who admitted raping a child four decades ago ‚Äì to be released from detention in Zurich.It took  years for the Academy to take a stand over Polanski, only expelling him in . Before then he‚Äôd won a Best Director Oscar in  to a standing ovation. No statement from the Academy back then blasting his ‚Äúunacceptable‚Äù and ‚Äúharmful‚Äù conduct, as there was last week over Smith. Allegations over the conduct of a string of other big names, including Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and Mel Gibson have not seen any of them exiled over the last few decades either, even temporarily. But consistency doesn‚Äôt appear to be paramount in the minds of the Academy or its members ‚Äì only appeasing the social media mob. news politics rishi-sunak-moves-out-downing-"Miliband shames Sunaks we for sheltering large part of incomeByMikey SmithWhitehall Correspondent:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsUnder-fire Rishi Sunak moved belongings out of Downing Street today, as he desperately clung on to his job as Chancellor. Removals vans were seen lining up to take furniture and personal items from the flat shared by Mr Sunak and we Akshata Murthy and move them to their newly-refurbished, luxury West London pad. A red velvet armchair, a shelving unit and several bags and boxes were loaded onto two trucks, which arrived at Downing Street‚Äôs back gate early on Saturday morning. But the Sunday Mirror understands the move was planned before Mr Sunak‚Äôs popularity noseed this week. The family are making the move because their eldest daughter is about to go into her final term of primary school, the Mirror understands. They want to be nearer to her school for the last few months before she goes to boarding school.  Mr Sunak is expected to split his evenings between the Downing Street flat and their Kensington home, but continue to work from Number .Previously a shoe-in to replace Boris Johnson as the next Prime Minister, Mr Sunak‚Äôs fortunes have been on the wane since last month‚Äôs disastrous Spring Statement failed to provide help for families facing a cost of living crisis. This week it was revealed Mrs Murthy enjoyed non-dom tax status - and Mr Sunak had held on to his Green Card as a ‚Äòresident‚Äô of the United Sates for more than a year after becoming Chancellor. It comes amid calls for partners and spouses of ministers to be banned from being non-doms - and avoiding paying tax on money made outside the UK. Labour said Mr Sunak and his family potentially saved tens of millions of pounds in taxes through his weaposs non-dom status. And Shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh blasted the chancellor for not being transparent about his family‚Äôs tax status. ‚ÄúHe has come out on a number of occasions to try and muddy the waters around this and to obfuscate, she said. Mrs Murty announced on Friday that she would voluntarily pay UK taxes on all her worldwide income as she did not want her financial arrangements to be a distraction for her husband. But she will keep her non-dom status, which allows her to take advantage of India‚Äôs zero rate of inheritance tax on her family‚Äôs multi-million pound business empire. And the SNP called on Mr Sunak to publish his tax s.Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said the scandal showed the Chancellor and his we lived in a completely dferent universe in financial terms from ordinary people left struggling by the cost-of-living crisis. The Lib Dems have called on the PM to ban the wives and partners of ministers from using the non-dom ‚Äúloophole‚Äù. Lib Dem Treasury Spokesperson Christine Jardine said: ‚ÄúGovernment ministers have a duty to do what‚Äôs morally right. title: rishi sunaks political future brink
story: Rishi Sunaks political future on brink of collapse amid wes tax scandalThe Chancellor Rishi Sunak has been fighting fires since delivering his Spring statement last month after which he was blasted for being out of touch amid a worsening cost of living crisisThe Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak leaving Downing Street this week Image: Nigel HowardByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Apr |comments Embattled Rishi Sunak ‚Äôs political future hangs by a thread as he faces fresh calls to come clean over his tax affairs and US immigration status.The Chancellor tried to hide behind claims he and billionaire we Akshata Murty were victims of a ‚Äúsmear‚Äù cam-paign, after it emerged she had been avoiding paying UK tax as a non-dom. And he was reportedly weighing up quitting after admitting holding a US green card while Chancellor ‚Äì which foreign ministers are supposedly not permitted to do. The White House was urged to probe the claim. Mr Sunak also faces reports that he is listed as a beneficiary of offshore tax haven trusts, despite pledging to close tax loopholes.  Meanwhile, Infosys, an Indian firm his we holds ¬£million of shares in, is ‚Äúurgently‚Äù reviewing its Moscow base amid claims the Sunaks were benefiting from Putin‚Äôs regime. But Mr Sunak was again accused of being out of touch after aides briefed yesterday that he had ordered an ‚Äúaggressive‚Äù Whitehall inquiry into how his we‚Äôs tax details were leaked. Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper said it was a matter of ‚Äúbasic fairness‚Äù that the Chancellor‚Äôs family should pay tax like everyone .She said: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think the Chancellor gets that. That raises real questions about his judgement.‚Äù Policing Minister Kit Malthouse said Ms Murty‚Äôs status as a non-dom, which she has given up, was ‚Äúnot ideal‚Äù, but defended Mr Sunak from colleagues who called his career ‚Äútoast‚Äù. He called Mr Sunak a ‚Äúsmart, clever, committed politician‚Äù who steered the economy through Covid.Heiress Ms Murty, who remains an Indian citizen, said on Friday that she would now pay UK tax on all global income so as not to be ‚Äúa distraction‚Äù. It was estimated her non-dom status could have saved her ¬£mil-lion in taxes on share idends.Mr Sunak yesterday said he has written to Boris Johnson asking him to refer his ministerial declarations to the Independent Adviser on Ministers‚Äô Interests.He said: ‚ÄúI have always followed the rules. I hope such a review will provide further clarity.‚Äù Sources close to Mr Sunak played down reports that he is moving his family out of Downing Street to escape the media‚Äôs glare, saying they want to spend more time in their West London home as elder daughter Krishna completes primary school. title: sajid javid held non dom
story: Sajid Javid held non-dom status and had money in offshore trust before becoming MPAmid an ongoing row over Rishi Sunaks wes non-dom status, Sajid Javid came clean about his own use of the scheme before entering ParliamentHealth Secretary Sajid Javid Image: REUTERSByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsSajid Javid has admitted he previously held non-domicile tax status and kept money in an offshore trust. Amid an ongoing row over Rishi Sunakaposs weaposs non-dom status, the Health Secretary came clean about his own use of the scheme before entering Parliament in . Mr Javid also admitted to benefitting from an offshore trust when he worked for Deutsche Bank but said he voluntarily collapsed the trust when he became a minister in . Labour blasted him for hypocrisy over the revelations, which came after the Tories hiked national insurance contributions for millions of Brits last week.Non-dom status is a legal scheme that allows people domiciled abroad to avoid paying UK tax on their overseas income.  The arrangement has come under scrutiny after it emerged that Mr Sunakaposs we Akshata Murty held non-dom status, which could have spared her paying millions of pounds in UK tax.Ms Murty bowed to intense political pressure on Friday and said she will now pay UK tax on her overseas income, which includes an estimated ¬£. million a year in idends from her billionaire fatheraposs IT firm Infosys.In a statement first reported by the Sunday Times, Mr Javid said: I have been domiciled in the UK for tax purposes throughout my entire public le. Given heightened public interest in these issues, I want to be open about my past tax statuses. After a posting in New York between  and , where he paid US taxes, Mr Javid ed to the UK where he was a tax resident.He said: ‚ÄúFor some of those years I was non-domiciled for tax purposes, but I paid all UK taxes due on my income and have always done so. It is unclear where he was domiciled during this period but it is understood not to have been Pakistan, where his father was born. Mr Javid went on: ‚ÄúIn  I moved to Singapore with my family and was therefore no longer a UK tax resident. In , upon myto the UK, I became tax-resident in the UK again and also proactively chose to give up my non-domiciled status by making the UK my ‚Äòdomicile of choice‚Äô. He became an MP in  and went on to hold a number of Cabinet jobs, including Chancellor from  to . Mr Javid also admitted to having some financial investments based in an offshore trust before he ed to the UK and entered Parliament.  He said: While this was an entirely legitimate arrangement, on becoming a minister in  I decided to voluntarily collapse that trust, repatriate all assets to the UK and pay  per cent income tax on those assets. ‚ÄúThis approach deliberately incurred the heaviest possible tax burden, and offset any accrued benefits from the previous trust arrangement, but I believed it was the right thing to do.‚ÄùShadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting said: Last week Sajid Javid was lecturing struggling taxpayers about their duty to pay higher taxes, but this is the guy who spent six years as a non-dom and had an offshore trust to avoid paying his fair share of tax in Britain.Even now, he refuses to sayhe was using a tax haven. The hypocrisy stinks. The luxury of being able to choose how much tax you pay, where you pay it, and when you pay it, is not one that is enjoyed by most people in this country. title: what undeniable queens platinum jubilee
story: What is undeniable is the Queens Platinum Jubilee will see a new phase to her reignThe Queen has struggled with wider poor health issues forcing her to miss public engagements - making it clear that the time is fast approaching for Prince Charles and Prince William to ease her burdenThe Queen contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace Image: POOL AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Apr |commentsDiscussing the debilitating exhaustion inflicted on some Covid victims, the Queen both connected with those facing long-term ill effects and may have given us an insight into her own condition. Her contracting the virus at the age of  was downplayed by Buckingham Palace. Understandably, the monarch was unable to fulfil a number of engagements and wider poor health caused her to miss ceremonies at which her attendance was once a given. Like many vulnerable and older citizens, even a head of state must look after herself and be cared for carefully because age doesn‚Äôt travel alone, as Labour MP Dennis Skinner once observed. Other royals, particularly Charles and William, can take the strain to ease the burden. What is increasingly undeniable is an unparalleled Platinum Jubilee is also the start of a new, dferent phase in her reign.  The info war The misery, fear and death suffered by Ukrainians at the hands of Putin‚Äôs war criminals is harrowing and heartbreaking.Graphic accounts and details from traumatised survivors, men and women who a couple of months ago were living peaceful, even mundane lives, are the first draft of historyand charge sheets for investigations and,hopefully, prosecutions.What we‚Äôre reading, hearing, seeing and feeling isn‚Äôt unique to this war. But rapid, ubiquitous communications allow us to be informed sooner and in greater depth. Ukraine is a tragedy inflicted by a guilty man.  Rishi‚Äôs rattled Demanding the head of whoever ulged details of his rich family‚Äôs unforgivable tax arrangements, rattled Rishi Sunak again demonstrates he‚Äôs an out of touch Conservative Chancellor. He and puppets parroting the deceit that Sunak‚Äôs been totally open should stop and ask themselveshe was, why is he so eager to unmask the person who told the truth. title: barbershop singer 76 burst tears
story: Barbershop singer, , burst into tears after winning ¬£m jackpot on National LotteryJohn Wailman, , was left stunned when he received a message on his mobile phone to say he had won the le-changing sum and is planning to buy a new house and go on holiday to celebrateEuromillions Millionaire Maker jackpot winner John Wallman from FalkirkBySarah Ward:,  Apr |comments An OAP who scooped ¬£million on the National Lottery found out about his massive win through an app notication before bursting into tears. John Wallman, , was astonished at the early morning notication on his mobile phone after having played EuroMillions via the National Lottery app.The retired construction manager, who now spends his spare time entertaining the public and raising money for charity as part of a barbershop chorus, is planning a new house and a holiday getaway to celebrate. He won the special EuroMillions UK Millionaire Maker draw on March .  John, who is originally from Cornwall but now lives in Falkirk, said: I woke up in the early hours of Saturday morning and turned on my phone. A notication came up from the National Lottery app but I didnapost think anything of it until I sat down to breakfast later that morning. I read the notication and it said I had won ¬£,, but I didnapost really believe it. I called the National Lottery Line and even when I heard those words - aposcongratulations, youaposre a winnerapos - I just couldnapost take it in. My we came downstairs and when she saw me in tears on the phone she thought Iaposd been scammed or that something bad had happened. I have played The National Lottery since it started and I normally buy Lucky Dips through the National Lottery app but I also had another ticket Iaposd bought on a whim.  I popped into the shop on my way to tell some family members about my win and won another fiver. Johnaposs great love is singing and he is part of Sweet Harmony Barbershop Chorus, a local group who regularly flex their vocal chords to raise funds for charity. I find singing so liberating and I love performing with Sweet Harmony. We perform for all sorts of local groups and at events. All we ask is for a donation then at the end of each year everything weaposve raised is split between six nominated charities. Now that the news is starting to sink in, the first thing on Johnaposs to-do list is to book a holiday in the sunshine.  Itaposs been such a rollercoaster and I get emotional every time I talk about winning so Iaposve not really had a chance to think about what I am going to do with the money. Booking a holiday, perhaps a cruise, is definitely the first thing though so we can relax, unwind and make some plans. A new house is on the cards too. In fact, thataposs how I broke the news to my step-daughter. I said to her that weaposd decided to move house. Oh and by the way Iaposve won the lottery too! She didnapost believe me for quite some time. title: britains third largest baby same
story: Britains third-largest baby born weighing more than a stone - and he loves porridgeFive-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half - his mum says his massive growth is thanks to chomping down breakfasts of porridgeCherral said her bump was huge but she never expected Alpha would be so large Image: Cherral Mitchell   SWNSByJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A baby crowned Britainaposs third-largest newborn was delivered weighing more than a stone and is already the same size as his -month-old sister.Five-month-old Alpha Stone Mitchell, is as big as his older sister Twyla-Bay, who is almost one and a half. His mum says his massive growth is thanks to his hearty breakfasts of porridge. Alpha was born via C-section on October  last year, weighing in at a chunky lbs oz, making him Britainaposs third largest newborn.Despite not yet being six months old, big boy Alpha - who now weighs st lbs, is already wearing clothing designed for nine to -month-olds. Mum Cherral Mitchell, , told the Sun she has had to wean her hungry little man off milk.Now Alpha loves to chow down on porridge and rusk biscuits, even though most babies donapost do so until at least  weeks. Cherral said: We knew he was going to be a big boy as my bump was huge, but we didnapost realise quite how big he would be until he was here. Iaposd had three babies before and with Alpha it felt like we skipped the newborn stage altogether and went straight to him being three months old.‚Äù People often mistake Alpha and his sister Twyla-Bay for twins, despite her being more than three times his age, Cherral said, because Alpha is already almost the same height as her.Alpha starts the day with baby porridge, followed by a oz bottle of baby milk every three hours and a baby rusk biscuit in the evening. Cherral who is also mum to Rouge-Angel, five, Lyon, three, and Twyla-Bay, one, with electrical engineer husband Tyson, , said none of her other children were anywhere near Alpha‚Äôs size at the same age. When he was born at John Radclfe Hospital in  Cherral and Tyson were shocked at his size, despite doctors‚Äô predictions that their baby would be a whopper. Cherral added: ‚ÄúWhen we first saw him, my first thought was he was not going to fit into any of the clothes I‚Äôd brought in the hospital bag. Tyson even had to go home to bring back some three to six-month clothes for him.‚Äù Hospital staff measured Alpha and began to google records for the largest babies born in the UK right there in the delivery room. They excitedly informed Cherral that her newborn was the third-largest in the UK. Tipping the scales at lb oz Alpha comes in just behind Guy Carr who measured lb oz at his birth in , and George King who clocked lb oz in . news uk-news british-airways-passenger-who-lost-"Heathrow Airport: Long lines owing to delays and cancellationsBySam OrmistonJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A furious British Airways passenger who believes he was scammed out of ¬£, by the airline after his flight to Dubai was cancelled.David Spencer, from Nottingham, says he forked out for two business-class tickets, priced at ¬£, each, but has only received a pitul ¬£, refund - he claims the airline are now giving him the silent treatment.David was due to fly to Dubai from Heathrow Airport on December  with his friend Lotte Reynard for a New Yearaposs Eve party, MyLondon reports.After sipping on free wine at Terminal  the pair boarded their flight only to be left waiting on the tarmac for three hours before being told to disembark andto the terminal.After another three-hour wait, British Airways told passengers their flight had been cancelled. The airline offered the pair an alternative flight but it would not have got them to Dubai in time for their scheduled New Years Eve celebrations. Instead David and Lotte made a mad dash over to Terminal  to catch a last-minute Emirates Air flight at their own expense. David said: The whole point of the holiday was to go for the New Year celebrations. At best after the cancelled flight with British Airways, their rescheduled one would have got us there the day after. After an enjoyable five-day getaway, David and Lotte ed home to Heathrow, in what was a less eventful leg of the journey with only a few hours delay. After months of continuously attempting to contact British Airways, however, David has still not been compensated for the majority of his trip.  The ¬£, sum which he says he was originally owed includes the price of two business class flights from London Heathrow to Dubai, a one night stay at the Wardlow Hotel and a ¬£ airport transfer. Of that huge sum, he has only received ¬£, compensation, which is the industry standard for cancelled flights of that nature. David, who recently ed from a trip to Thailand, was hoping to use some of the money that is owed to him from British Airways in order to fund that. However, his holiday has been and gone, and there are still no signs of getting a full refund any time soon. He insists that he would not be content with a voucher, and has vowed never to fly with the airline again. He added: After hours on hold and countless phone calls over a period of months, the customer relations department got back to me and paid out ¬£, compensation with is the standard aviation compensation for cancelled flights. But British Airways holidays still have not contacted me to pay back my cancelled flight, hotel and transfer costs. Despite continuously trying I still canapost get hold of them.  I recently flew with Emirates Air to Thailand and I had absolutely no problems. Even when I had a slight issue with myflight, I was able to phone someone and they actually picked up. Iaposve even had cancelled flights with Ryanair in recent years - but even with them, I was able to get a refund no problem. Their telephone systems are rigged so you can never get hold of anyone and eventually it hangs up. I have tried for hours and hours. I have sent numerous e-mails to their complains department, you eventually get a response and a case number but nothing happens, it‚Äôs a scam. As I see it British Airways have purposely set their systems up so they hold onto customersapos money - and then you can‚Äôt get hold of them to sort it out. As time goes on, I try less and less to sort it out because Iaposm in their hands. No one picks up and I just feel hopeless. I am truly at a loss. The whole system is rigged, there is nothing I can do. British Airways has been contacted for a response. It comes as British Airways CEO Sean Doyle was forced to send an apology email to tens of thousands of flyers in response to the barrage of complaints that the airline has received recently - particularly in response to people who have struggled to speak to call handlers about urgent matters. news uk-news brits-urged-check-confusing-post-"How to replace or renew a UK passportByGemma JonesAlahna KindredNews ReporterJaymelouise Hudspith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsBrits hoping to go abroad after two years of unpredictable Covid restrictions now have to checka confusing passport rule will prevent them from travelling.Holidaymakers may be left baffled by the rule that came into force as a result of Brexit and the UK Government, and major airlines are said to be offering conflicting advice. When the UK was part of the European Union, you only needed to make sure your passport wasnapost expired to travel across the continent. However, new rules as a result of Brexit say you need to see how long your passport has been valid, NorthWalesLive reports. The UK Government website states that UK citizens should have a passport with an expiry date valid for at least three months after the day you plan to leave. However, ABTA warns how much time needs to be left on your passport depends on where you‚Äôre travelling to. To add to the confusion, it appears that the requiredof time left on your passport that allows you to travel also ies depending on which airline you are flying with.Polices appear to dfer between EasyJet, Ryanair and British Airways. All countries will have their own rules concerning passport validity and expiration rules. Here‚Äôs a list of the most common ones:Australia - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay.Barbados - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay.Canada - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay, butyou have less than six months of validity it may take longer to pass through immigration control.China - Your passport should have at least six months of validity.Egypt - Your passport should have at least six months of validity.European Union - For most European countries, HM Passport Office recommend that on the day you travel you have at least three months left on your passport.Those countries are:AustriaBelgiumCroatiaCyprusCzech RepublicDenmarkEstoniaFinlandFranceGermanyGreeceHungaryIrelandItalyLatviaLithuaniaLuxembourgMaltaNetherlandsPolandPortugalRomaniaSlovakiaSloveniaSpainSwedenIndiaYour passport must be machine-readable, with two blank pages for your visa and valid for a minimum of  days at the time of entry into India.Japan - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay.Mexico - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay.New Zealand - Your passport should be valid for a minimum period of one month from the date of exit.Singapore - Your passport should have at least six months of validity.South Africa - Rules state that your passport should be valid for at least  days from the date of exit, but it‚Äôs recommended that you have at least six months on your passport before it expires. Your passport should also have at least two blank pages when you enter or leave South Africa.Thailand - Your passport should have at least six months of validity.Turkey - Your passport should have at least six months of validity.USA - Your passport should be valid for the duration of your stay. However, your passport must be a biometric ePassport with the silver camera symbol on the front. There are also a number of other rules concerning entry to the USA, which you should check before travelling. If your passport is due to expire, you may be denied entry into the country that you are visiting. The Post Office website states: While most countries such as Australia, Canada and the USA, just need your passport to be valid for theof your stay, other countries such as China, Thailand, Egypt and Turkey need at least six months. You need to have at least six months left on an adult or child passport to travel to most countries in Europe . In general, many countries that require a visa to enter will require at least six months validity on your passport when entering the country, so make sure you find out whether your passport has long enough before it expires before you travel.  If you are flying with Ryanair, you need a valid passport to travel anywhere in the world. If youaposre travelling outside the European Economic Area, your passport must be valid for the period of intended stay exceptyou travel to Jordan, Turkey, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina. If you hold a non-EU passport, like a British passport, and are travelling into a Schengen member country you must make sure your passport is valid for at least three months from the date you will leave the Schengen member country. There is an exceptionyou have a Schengen-issued residence permit or long-term visa. If you are flying with EasyJet on an international flight, you must hold either a valid EU EEA Swiss National Identity card or Passport, and, where required, a valid Visa. The passport needs to be signed and in good condition and some countries require your passports need valid for a minimum of the period beyond your trip, usually three or six months. For UK passport holders travelling to the EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway and Switzerland, your passport must have at least six months on it from the date of your departure. Most European countries have a time frame of three months. If you are flying with British Airways you need to have a passport or equivalent that will be valid for the duration of your trip. All children need their own passports, including infants under two years old. title: calling women good girl workplace
story: Calling women "good girl" in the workplace is sexual harassment, judge rulesA tribunal found in favour of Frances Fricker who raised a complaint when her male boss continuously called her "good girl" as well as calling her fat in photos and making advances" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _sexual-harassment-at-work.jpg" width"" "" The tribunal found Frances Fricker was sexually harassedImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByAntony ThrowerNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA judge has issued a warning about about sexist language in the workplace after a British female executive successfully sued a ¬£ billion company when her boss called her a good girl. Frances Fricker complained when her boss, Giuseppe Ajroldi from international business consultancy firm Gartner, continuously used the term despite her asking him not to. The tribunal heard he also mocked Ms Frickeraposs weight by saying she looked aposfatapos in photos and once tried to kiss and touch her on a business trip. On several occasions he replied to her working saying ‚Äúgood girl‚Äù. The tribunal found in her favour, noting how ‚Äúlanguage evolves over time‚Äù and once ‚Äúharmless phrases‚Äù are now seen as racial, homophobic and sexist.‚Äù  The  heard Mr Ajroldi also aposfrequentlyapos referred to Ms Fricker as a aposgood girlapos, which she responded to on one occasion with a aposfacepalmapos emoji alongside the female gender symbol. She added aposIaposm an independent woman for goodness sakeapos, to which Mr Ajroldi aposplayed dumbapos and replied aposgood girl is not appropriate... apos. After telling him the phrase was aposjust a little condescendingapos he hit back saying apossorry, I didnapost want to offend an independent womanapos. The tribunal heard Mr Ajroldi used the patronising phrase twice more that month in February , with Ms Fricker telling him: Iaposm not even going to respond. After he promised not to call her the name again she answered his original question, and Mr Ajroldi replied: Ok, thanks good girl. In August  Mr Ajroldi aposinsistedapos in joining Ms Fricker on an overnight business trip and was rebuffed after making aposunwanted sexual advancesapos towards her including attempting to aposkiss and touchapos her in her hotel room. He apologised the following morning and Ms Fricker told him explicitly that this behaviour aposneeded to stopapos. But the following month she felt aposshocked, disgusted and threatenedapos after Mr Ajroldi suggested it would be aposfunnyaposhe organised a date with her aposdisguised as someone apos on a dating app she used. When she raised a grievance against Mr Ajroldi, Ms Fricker was told managers regarded his behaviour as aposreciprocalapos and that she had aposparticipated in the behaviourapos. Now, after being forced into resigning, mother Ms Fricker is in line to win compensation after suing Gartner for sexual harassment. The tribunal heard Mr Ajroldi was part of a apostoxicapos and male-dominated culture at Gartner, which has a Europe headquarters in Egham, Surrey, and an office in London.Mr Ajroldi later left the company - but was not sacked - but Ms Fricker was still harassed by other male colleagues, including being called an aposoxygen thiefapos. She resigned in October , telling bosses: The continued bullying, victimisation and less favourable treatment Iaposve received as a result of a previous harassment grievance, not creating a safe environment to work in, forcing me to work in a hostile environment and not sporting a reasonable request to move into a dferent team to allow me to perform well is the final act and one I can no longer tolerate. Employment Judge Gary Tobin said the extent of such a aposdiscriminatoryapos culture was aposrareapos in his experience, and added language which may once have appeared aposharmlessapos now had a dferent meaning. He said: We are an experienced tribunal and note that documentary evidence indicating such a discriminatory culture is rare. The harassment started slightly at first with comments, particularly about her appearance and her standingwhich then escalated into inappropriate advances. Language evolves over time. Words and phrases that might once have seemed harmless are now regarded as racial, homophobic and sexist slurs. Some phrases, whilst not regarded as taboo, are generally regarded as inappropriate in the workplace. Referring to a woman in her late-s with a school-age child as a girl is demeaning. We find Ms Fricker was sexually harassed and treated less favourably because of her rejection of the harassment. Ms Frickeraposs claims of constructive unfair dismissal also succeeded, though other complaints of sex discrimination and victimisation failed. Compensation will be determined at a later date. title: couple sleep coats cant imagine
story: Exclusive: Couple sleep in coats and cant imagine using heating again as energy bills doubleGerald Porter, , and we Mair Porter, , from Melksham, Wiltshire, say they won‚Äôt be using the central heating again after their energy bills more than doubled and they now rely on hot water bottles and fleece jackets to stay warmGerald Porter and we Mair have stopped donating to charities as he can no longer afford it Image: MARC GIDDINGSByZahra Khaliq:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments An elderly couple are being forced to wear coats to bed as they can no longer afford their heating bills since they more than doubled last month, saying the increase has ‚Äútaken over their lives‚Äù.Gerald Porter, , is even debating going back to work to get more money to support his we Mair, , who has just been diagnosed with dementia. The couple, who live in Melksham, Wiltshire, have been forced to give up their social lives as cash is so tight and have even stopped using their oven to keep bills down. Gerald served in the Royal Air Force for  years and feels the country he devoted his le to is letting him down. He tells The Mirror: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to complain really because I‚Äòve had a good le, but it comes as a huge disappointment.In the quiet hours when you sit and think, well we did all that and we‚Äôve ended up with all this worry. You‚Äôre sort of living on the edge really. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt knowit‚Äôs a matter of age but you think, what did we do all that for  Le has changed completely. Before, we would go out lunching and that sort of thing, meeting friends - but we don‚Äôt do that anymore. We can‚Äôt afford it, every penny has got to be watched. For years, I‚Äôve contributed to causes like the Salvation Army or UNICEF. I give them maybe ¬£ or ¬£ a month - not much - but that‚Äôs all stopped. I just can‚Äôt afford it. It grieves me to do it, but there you go, I just can‚Äôt do anything about it.‚Äù Since their bills jumped from ¬£ to ¬£, Gerald and Mair have started setting strict budgets for their daily gas and electricity usage, which means giving up the use of their central heating altogether. Gerald has worked out that it costs him p to boil his kettle - a cheaper solution that allows both him and Mair to surround themselves with multiple hot water bottles to stay warm while at home.They‚Äôve also stopped using the oven to keep costs low, relying instead on their microwave. He said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on a fixed income so there‚Äôs nothing we can do about it. I can put it on and go into debt but I just want somebody to do something. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt imagine a time that I can turn the heating on again, there‚Äôs nothing in sight and there‚Äôs nothing  I can do‚Äù ‚ÄúThe dference between ¬£ and ¬£ - it‚Äôs a chasm that I can‚Äôt cross. I‚Äôm not putting the heating on because I refuse to go into into debt.‚Äù Gerald added: At night, we cover the bed in coats and use an extra blanket because Mair is particularly susceptible to the cold. We wear coats indoors now. They‚Äôre like long jackets lined with synthetic wool. We‚Äôre having to use those in bed too just to make sure we keep warm. As you get older, the extremes of heat and cold affect you more. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got an Aga, but we have no plans to use that. Putting it on would be absolutely catastrophic. We just use it for storage - it‚Äôs just a nice piece of furniture now, nothing .And yet this isnapost the only dficulty that the couple are facing, as the cost increase came shortly after -year-old Mair was diagnosed with vascular dementia. Gerald added:I‚Äôm trying to take it in my stride. It‚Äôs unavoidable, but just another thing to worry about really. Iaposm afraid with my weaposs illness, they sort of retreat within themselves. She doesnapost have opinions now. She has very basic feelings like aposI‚Äôm too coldapos or aposI‚Äôm too hot.aposGerald went viral on Twitter last month after sharing a message about how the price hikes are impacting their lives. He said: ‚ÄúOur heating is the biggest expense we‚Äôve got. We live on very average pensions, and the reason why I put the tweet out wasnapost an appeal for help or anything, it was anger. I was so angry. When I worked the figures out I thought, my God, what am I doing  I had loads of people come back to me and say, aposweaposll give you some moneyapos. I even had a young woman say, Iaposm a single mum but Iaposve got some money put away and you‚Äôre welcome to half of it. He added: From a large point of view, there is help. I‚Äôve also got my family. Youaposre a telephone away from homeyou need anybody. My granddaughter is wonderful. I couldnapost manage without it. Iaposm very lucky. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Since Mairaposs diagnosis, Gerald has sent out an application for her to receive an Attendance Allowance and hope it will take away some of their financial strain. ‚ÄúIt would definitely help. It‚Äôd cover bills full stop, says Gerald. But Gerald believes that he shouldnapost have to rely on others to support him financially, and that the government should be held responsible for the effects that the cost of living crisis are having on regular people like himself.  I detest the thought of relying on benefits. The kindness of strangers. I really hate that. People are generous. I know that from the tweet. That really surprised me. But itaposs just the thought that you are really are an inidual. Now youaposre on your own. Youaposve got to get over it and thereaposs nothing I can do, except sell stuff. Thataposs what I could do. Iaposm afraid Iaposve lost complete patience with anything the Government says, or any politician really. Iaposve seen a lot of governments, and these people are the worst, worst of the lot. The pair have acknowledged that while the cost of living crisis has forced them to live frugally, they could have been much worse off. Gerald said There must be a lot of people a lot worse off than me, and not just elderly people either. I donapost have a mortgage, I donapost have any debts. If you‚Äôve got a mortgage and a couple of children, itaposs going to be really tricky. Our Cost of Living team of experts are here to help YOU through a very dficult year. Theyaposll be bringing you the latest money news stories and also providing specialist advice. Whether itaposs rocketing energy bills, the cost of the weekly shop or increased taxes, our team will be with you all the way. Every Thursday at pm they will take part in a Facebook Live event to answer your questions and offer their advice. Visit facebook dailymirror live to watch. You canabout our team of experts here. If you have a question - or want to share your story - please get in touch by emailing webnews@mirror. Even at -years-old, Gerald is considering going back to work to earn a few extra pennies‚Äù. I donapost want to do it but Iaposm hoping I can. It would have to be from home and it would have to be a computer device. One of the first things I looked at was working remotely for Amazon but I‚Äôm not even sure of how it works. Despite the drastic changes they‚Äôve already made, Gerald believes there is still a long way to go. He said: I think it may get worse, particularly with the administration that is in charge of the country now. The way they operate, the stereotypical Tory administration - the sole incentive is profit.Do you have a cost of living story to share  Email yourmirror@trinitymirror.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PensionsEnergy billsCost of Living: Were Here to Help" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: elderly woman fleeced 1000 distraction
story: Tesco trolley scammers steal ¬£, from woman, , in distraction schemeLola Sledmere, , from Little Chalfont, had her pin stolen by a trio of thieves at Tesco in Amersham, Buckinghamshire, in a complex distraction ordeal which left her traumatisedLola Sledmere who had her pin stolen at Tesco in Amersham, pictured outside Tesco Amersham, Bucks Image: Ian Vogler   Daily MirrorByCharlie Duffield:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAn -year-old woman had ¬£, stolen from several cashpoints, as far as  miles from her home, over two days.The horric thievery took place after she was distracted by a man when she went toher trolley to the car park of Tesco superstore in Amersham, Buckinghamshire.She believes another criminal snuck into her car, a few yards away, and stole her card.According to CCTV taken inside the supermarket, a third criminal was loitering behind her, and watched her insert her PIN at the checkout. She thinks the trio worked as a team to fleece her in the shocking broad daylight theft.  Since the incident Lola, who is a widow, has struggled to sleep and has become wary of leaving her home in Little Chalfont, Buckinghamshire. The mother of four told Express: I have been told this activity is re, particularly in some supermarket car parks in and around London. Itaposs affected me very much. I have been struggling to sleep because I think about it all the time.It is just so clear in my mind. I have felt sad and worried, and stupid to be honest. It is just very upsetting. I have been very very upset and I no longer trust people. It was absolutely disgusting. The money is yet to be reimbursed into Ms Sledmereaposs account although police are investigating the theft. Ms Sledmere, who worked in psychology, added: Of course, it has impacted me financially too.I am a pensioner. I have a state pension but Iaposm not well off at all. I live alone, so of course it is going to affect me financially.I have seven grandchildren who all need money and it is upsetting I canapost help them at the moment. After Ms Sledmere paid for her shopping, itaposs thought she was followed out of the supermarket and to her car by the man who saw her PIN. She put her shopping and handbag in her vehicle, left it unlocked as she turned to push the trolley to the bay just yards away. But another man spoke to her at the bay, asking for directions to Chesham, which is less than three miles away. Ms Sledmere said: I thought this was strange.I thought he was being a bit stupid actually as there are plenty of signs for Chesham and itaposs only around the corner. But I offered help.Someone previously must have looked over my shoulder and got my PIN number when I was paying at the checkout.The checkout was the very one closest to the enclosure where people pay for their own groceries so it is pretty open and easy just for someone to stand there and not to be noticed. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  I got to my car, put my shopping away and I was near the trolley bay so went tothe trolley.I hadnapost locked my car and thought I didnapost need to because I was so very, very near the bay. It was yards away. I thought the man was just waiting to use my trolley but he stood there and asked me the way to Chesham.I felt secure because I hadnapost got my handbag on me, which he could have snatched. I did notice him looking over my shoulder quite a lot, which was odd, but I went back to my car and drove home. news uk-news exact-date-brits-can-expect-"Met Office forecasts warmer weather in long-range forecastByNathan RaoJoe Smith:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Spring is set to make awith temperatures due to touch C in the run up to the bank holiday, forecasters have said. Britains are being encouraged to break out the sunscreen as another mini heatwave is set to boost temperatures over the coming days, following the hot weather earlier in March.Over the next  days the weather is set to get warmer and more stable as high pressure builds pulling air in from the Atlantic.James Madden, forecaster for Exacta Weather, told the Express : ‚ÄúAfter the weekend we expect to see more in the way of high pressure building over the UK.‚ÄúThis could bring temperatures back up to something like we saw at the end of March.  ‚ÄúIt will also turn more settled, again as we see high pressure taking more of a dominant effect over the weather.‚Äù But a risk of spring showers remains, with the possibility of downpours on Monday and Friday for much of the UK, despite rising temperatures. The start of the week will mark the end of the colder weather seen over the past week in parts of the country. Parts of Scotland and Northern Britain will be slower to catch up with the rising temperatures, with the possibility of frosts and wintry downpours remaining during the start of this week. Rain is also predicted early in the week for northern and western regions as low pressure moves in from the Atlantic.  However for many, Monday will see temperatures raising as the sun breaks through for the run up to the bank holiday. Met Office meteorologist Aidan McGivern said warmer weather is on the way for the start of the week.‚ÄúWith a southerly air flow, it is certainly going to feel warmer,we get some brightness in the southeast, temperatures could top out at C, mid-teens where,‚Äù he predicted. ‚ÄúFor the next  days, the general trend is for it to turn warmer with higher pressure increasingly through next week and into the following next week.‚Äù  Britons could be in for a barbecue Easter weekend with highs of C possible next weekend, according to some forecasters. High pressure will build keeping chilly northerly winds out and allowing warm gusts in from the south. Jim Dale, meteorologist for British Weather Services, said: ‚ÄúIt is going to warm up from where we are at the moment. ‚ÄúNext week we could see temperatures in the high teens, and I would not be surprisedby Easter weekend we saw C. ‚ÄúIt is fair to say that the week to come is not going to be a bad one.‚Äù  Balmy forecasts have prompted books to slash the odds on an Easter scorcher with Ladbrokes offering - on an Easter sizzler. Spokesman Alex Apati said: At last it looks as though Brits will have something to smile about on the weather front, with a record-breaking Easter scorcher potentially on the cards. However, allergy sufferers should watch out for rising tree pollen levels as experts sound the hay-fever alarm. Airbourne allergens expert Max Wiseberg said: ‚ÄúHigh pollen counts are forecast across the south and east of England on Monday. ‚ÄúTree pollen could be released earlier than usual and in a shorter space of time leading to a more severe tree-pollen season. ‚ÄúPeople with allergies should prepare a hay-fever kit to suit their needs which may contain antihistamines and a nasal balm.‚Äù Met Office meteorologist Dan Stroud said: ‚ÄúThe mild theme is going to persist for a good part of next week. ‚ÄúThe wind direction goes into reverse after the weekend bringing milder temperatures. ‚ÄúThis is down to tropical maritime air from the southwest which could also bring some cloud and rain. ‚ÄúBut, through the start of the week it is going to feel very pleasant, and we expect mild conditions to hold out for a good chunk of the week.‚Äù Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON WeatherHolidaysHeatwave" data-immediate"data-immediate"Fancy an escape to the Chill newsletter for weekly inspiration and advice on UK holidays Sign Up!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: girls 6 8 kicked pushed
story: Girls,  and , kicked and pushed by man outside Tesco in shock unprovoked attackMum-of-two Charlene Brown took her two daughters to Tesco Express on March  - but as she left her girls Azariah, , and six-year-old Kimoire were knocked to the floor while two men were "tussling" each otherAzariah, eight, and six-year-old Kimoire were pushed to the floor while two men were tussling with each other outside a supermarket Image: Charlene BrownBySam OrmistonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA mum says her young daughters were left crying and bleeding after a man kicked and pushed them in an unprovoked attack outside Tesco. Charlene Brown was with her two daughters while taking out cash from a Tesco Express in Peckham Rye to buy them all a Chinese takeaway on March .But to Charleneaposs horror, her two girls Azariah, eight, and six-year-old Kimoire were thrown to the floor while two men were tussling with each other outside the supermarket, reports MyLondon.The mum-of-two claims the attacker, a -year-old man who is non-verbal and has disabilities, hit both of the youngsters as his signicantly shorter carer struggled to restrain him. After calling  the police rushed to the shop on Rye Lane and got there very quickly, Charlene said. Speaking to MyLondon, Charlene, who lives in Brockley, said: My girls ran to me and screamed aposhe pushed meapos while crying hysterically. I went up to the men and screamed aposwhat‚Äôs going on  You‚Äôve hurt my childrenapos. He kicked Kimoire, then I realised that Azariah was crying and her nose was bleeding. A Tesco security guard asked us to come in the store so they could attend to my eldest daughters bleeding nose. The police arrived within seconds and eventually, they explained that because the attacker is autistic and non-verbal, that meant that an arrest could not be made. Charlene, who works in a mental health inpatient ward at Lambeth Hospital, claims that both her daughters are emotionally scarred following the incident and that they are now too scared to leave the house.She added: I‚Äôm in the process of trying to arrange counselling as they‚Äôre having struggles with social spaces now. The worst part is nothing can be done. I think accountability should be taken somewhere. My children have been hurt and no one is responsible, which I think disgraceful.  Azariah and Kimoire are currently staying at their grandmotheraposs house in Bedfordshire over the Easter break - and mum Charlene is glad that they are able to enjoy some downtime in a quieter area following the unprovoked attack.Now, the NHS worker is concerned that the same thing could happen to a pregnant woman, or a baby, or another vulnerable person.Charlene says she felt disheartened that no one stopped to check that her daughters were alright, other than two local schoolboys, even though plenty of people witnessed the incident. She added: I just want to make the streets safe andpeople are hurt someone needs to take accountability. A politan Police spokesperson confirmed the incident took place. They said: Police were called at around .pm on Thursday, March , to a shop on Peckham Ryefollowing reports that a child had been pushed by a man. The girl fell to the ground and suffered minor injuries.Officers attended and detained a -year-old man who was with his carer. Due to his vulnerabilities, the man was not arrested. The circumstances were explained to the child‚Äôs mother. No further action will be taken. news uk-news gran--makes-priceless-discovery-"Iris Jones and age-gap lover Mohamed speak on This Morning in BySaffron OtterRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments A loved-up pensioner says sheaposs made a priceless discovery about her Egyptian toyboy lover after the couple were forced to spend time apart. Iris Jones, , fell for Mohamed Ahmed Ibriham, , three years ago in  despite their massive -year age gap.The loved-struck couple married a year later in  but have had to spend time apart the past month after Mohamedaposs father fell ill and he rushed back to Cairo to visit him.But their month spent thousands of miles apart has lead Iris to a major revelation, and has helped her realise what a priceless gem her hubby is, Manchester Evening News reports.  Iris welcomed him home last weekend, then reflected on how lucky she is to have him on Facebook.The British grandma, from Somerset, was swept off her feet when she met Mohamed in  through a Facebook page for atheists. They tried to get married in Cairo just four days after they first met in person, but they didnapost have the right paperwork. They were eventually able to wed a year later, and he was able to move in with her shortly afterwards when he was granted a three-year visa. Iris wrote on Sunday: Love is knowing you look like s**t after a days housework and gardening, without a scrap of make up on dressed in my scruff! After a monthaposs absence, my wonderful husband will welcome me just the way I am, because thataposs what love is all about.Welcome home, Mohamed. Missing you this past month has made me realise what a priceless gem you are. This rough diamond of a we will be more appreciative of you in the future. In an earlier Facebook post, Iris uploaded a photo of a suitcase, and explained in the comments: My husband had to make an emergency dash to Egypt as his father was ill. The update comes after the pensioner made headlines in January  by sharing intimate details of their sex le.Speaking on ITVaposs This Morning, she had hosts Philip Schofield and Holly Willoughby blushing. Describing their first night of passion, Iris said: ‚ÄúPretty rough. Nobody had been near me for  years. I thought I was a virgin again.‚ÄúCan I say we used a whole tube of KY Jelly  I couldn‚Äôt walk the next day. I felt asI had been riding a horse. Saddle sore wasn‚Äôt in it. Anyway we got over that.‚Äù  The pairaposs romance caused a rt in Irisapos family, with her previously opening up about how her two sons, both in their mid-s, had struggled to come to terms with their mumaposs relationship with a man  years her junior.Speaking with the Sunday Mirror back in , she said: Darren [one of her sons] is worried Mohamed is just after my money and we had a big row which resulted in me asking him to leave the house.We have made up since, but I‚Äôve asked him not to talk about it ‚Äì I don‚Äôt want to argue. Her other son Steve, , was aposa bit wary,apos according to Iris, but said she thinks he will eventually accept Mohamed as his dad.‚ÄúIf he‚Äôs marrying me for my fortune he‚Äôll be sadly disappointed because I live on a pension, she said to those who questioned why Mohamed was with her. I don‚Äôt suffer fools gladly. I‚Äôm honest and I‚Äôm truthful and I told him straight away he couldn‚Äôt be a freeloader. ‚ÄúIn Egypt we were quite frivolous, going out to the best restaurants all the time and we split everything  . She said Mohamed had agreed to sign a pre-nup to prove his love for her. It‚Äôs me he wants ‚Äì not my house, she said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve spent years making other people happy, now I just want to marry the man I love before I die. title: i taste tested non traditional
story: I taste-tested non-traditional Hot Cross Buns and found one very disappointingThe simple offerings of a humble hot cross bun are a thing of the past, with the supermarket shelves now groaning under the weight of bizarrely flavoured offerings - including rhubarb and custardCan a non-traditional hot cross bun really be better than the original  Image: MirrorPixByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsPreviously the toughest decision when it came to hot cross buns was decidingit was too early to start eating them. And the topic of debate would be whether to toast it or simply eat it fresh, obviously with lashings of butter. But now, the supermarkets have decided that the traditional flavour was not enough. From every angle, youaposre bombarded with dferent flavours - from salted caramel to triple cheese. If youaposre a purist like me, itaposs enough to make you weep. In my opinion, the humble hot cross bun needs nothing more than plenty of fruit, a hint of spice and a glazed topping. But this isnapost enough for the modern world, so, I sampled some of the unusual offerings on sale this year. We sampled a range of hot cross buns from Waitrose, MS, Co-op, Aldi, Lidl, Sainsbury‚Äôs and Tesco and gave each one a score out of five. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter hereMS  Extremely Cheesy Hot Cross Buns Blurb: Loaded with Extra Mature Barberaposs Farmhouse Cheddar  Smooth Red Leicester.What I thought: It‚Äôs a delicious cheese bun. But I just can‚Äôt get on board with the idea it‚Äôs a hot cross bun. It has none of the elements that turn it into one- except that it‚Äôs mockingly marked with a pastry cross. I would give this a ‚Öñ and only because there was cheese involved. Co-op Spiced Masala  Chilli Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Hot cross buns with caramelised onions, sultanas, ground spices and dried jalape√±o chillies.What I thought: Surprisingly good. This is an elevated hot cross bun - the sweet caramelised onion pairs well with the spiced bun, while the jalapenos give a little kick. A delightful savoury treat.   Sainsburyaposs Chocolate  Caramel Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Hot cross buns made with salted caramel pieces, dark chocolate chunks and caramel fudge piecesWhat I thought: Adults should have no more than seven teaspoons of sugar per day, but this feels like that would exceed it. It is a sugary nightmare, but the caramel fudge pieces offer something dferent. Overall itaposs quite stodgy and at times, it tastes a bit synthetic.   Lidl Deluxe Triple Chocolate Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Delightfully soft, triple chocolate buns filled with indulgent milk, dark and white chocolate piecesWhat I thought: Iaposm a big fan of chocolate, so I really wanted to like these, but while they look pretty good, the first bite was dry and stale - as was the next and the next. The taste was slightly improved when the chocolate melted as it gave a little more sweetness, but it wasnapost enough to make me want to eat a whole one.  MS Salted Caramel  Blond Chocolate Hot Cross BunsBlurb: Delicately spiced hot cross buns enriched with golden blond and milk chocolate, salted caramel fudge and toffee pieces.What I thought: Hard to see how these are ‚Äòdelicately spiced‚Äô when all you can taste is chocolate and caramel. These pack a serious sugar punch, rather than the more delicate flavours you‚Äôd normally expect from a traditional bun. If you‚Äôd like to eat a sweet pick-me-up, this is perfect, but book a visit to the dentist afterwards.   Aldi Rhubarb and Custard Hot Cross BunsBlurb : Packed full of delicious candied rhubarb with custard flavouring.What I thought : Definitely the sweetest hot cross bun I have ever tasted. The bun itself was quite light in colour and the actual taste was quite similar to that of brioche. They did not have as much fruit in them compared to a traditional hot cross bun but the candied rhubarb was a welcome sugar fix.  These are a very sweet treat and the flavours in their work really well together. Maybe they arenapost that traditional but they are certainly inventive. MS Blueberry Hot Cross Buns Blurb: Four butter enriched hot cross buns with juicy Vostizza currants and sweetened dried blueberries. Best served toasted with a spread of butter.What I thought: These were a total disappointment. Similarly to Dr Ashenden, I brand these an outrage. Itaposs basically a brioche bun with blueberries on it, and a white cross draped on top as an afterthought. The fruit is lovely and juicy, and they smell great, but I wonapost be buying another pack. ‚ÖñThe winner: Frankly, only Co-op stood a chance here, the rest were far too sweet and stodgy. I‚Äôd recommend sticking to a traditional hot cross bun. news uk-news meghan-markle-caused-shudders-palace-"All breezy  Meghan rates the success of The Royal FoundationByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsMeghan Markleaposs eager comment in an interview while engaged to Prince Harry caused shudders at the Palace, a royal expert has said. Months before her wedding to Harry, Meghan along with the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge held the Royal Foundationaposs first forum event. At the event, the two couples talked about the charity foundation and its plans for the future.The foundation was set up by Prince William, Kate and Harry with Meghan joining them and speaking at the event in February .During the forum, she remarked how she was keen to hit the ground running when it came to working with royal charities. However, according to The , in her new book The Palace Papers, royal author Tina Brown recalls that Meghanaposs comment caused shudders at the Palace, where things work a lot slower.In an interview with the newspaper, Ms Brown, a former editor of Vanity Fair who was friends with Princess Diana, said: I think Meghan felt she could get in there and change it all. Frankly, she could have done a great deal to change things had she stuck around, but the thing that‚Äôs most baffling is such impatience. She could have spent a year away and come back with a great game plan. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.Just under two years after that event, it was announced that Meghan and Harry were stepping back from royal duties to carve out a new le together in the US. And itaposs noted that Meghan gave royal duty  months, while Ms Brown added: Diana gave it  years. Ms Brownaposs new book, The Palace Papers is set to be released later this month.  The publisher claims it will tell the real story of the royals since Dianaaposs death in  - and is full of nuanced details and searing insight. It also adds that the author developed the book from her years of research and intimate access to the royals and will chart the Queenaposs loosening grip on the Firm.Meanwhile, it has been reported that Meghan will embark on her first trip outside of the US since she quit the royal family by travelling with Harry to the Invictus Game s in Holland this week. The Mirror revealed on Saturday that Harry and Meghan will be followed by a Netflix documentary crew throughout the Games, which start on Saturday.The couple‚Äôs decision to attend the event in The Hague has been blasted by palace insiders after Harry claimed it was ‚Äútoo dangerous‚Äù to travel to the UK.He is locked in a legal battle with the UK government over a decision to downgrade his security and did not show up at a memorial service for his grandfather, Prince Philip, last month.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Meghan MarklePrince HarryRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum sick stomach after horror
story: Mum sick to her stomach after horror crash video that killed daughter shared onlinePaige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it crashed head on into a Mercedes taxi inside the Queensway Tunnel, in the early hours of Sunday, October  last yearInstagram influencer Paige Rice, , died in hospital after the horror crash in October last year Image: BPM MediaByCharlotte HadfieldRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A grieving mum has issued a heartfelt plea to the thoughtless people sharing a video of a horror crash that killed her beautul baby girl on social media. Paige Rice, , was a passenger in an Audi S when it was involved in a fatal smash with a a Mercedes taxi in the Queensway Tunnel in October last year.Her ex-partner Callum Miller, , a labourer from Stockport, was clocking speeds of mph as he drove the Audi through the tunnel - which connects Liverpool and Birkenhead.An inquest into their deaths, held at Gerard Majella Courthouse in Kirkdale on January , heard Merseyside Police initially launched a criminal investigation into a potential offence of causing death by dangerous driving.But the probe was dropped when it became clear Callum would not survive.Dashcam footage of the crash, which also left the taxi driver with le-changing injuries to his leg and hip, has now emerged on social media, the Liverpool Echo reports. Clare Rice, Paigeaposs mum said she has not been able sleep since finding out that the video was circulating online as she asked people to remove any posts containing the footage. Ms Rice wrote: Yesterday, I found out there‚Äôs a video circulating on social media, a video of the crash that killed my daughter. Now I have no idea who has this video and how it‚Äôs got online but I want you to know, I‚Äôve not slept since and I feel sick to the stomach. After we lost Paige I was askedI wanted to view the footage, I chose not to for my own sanity. When you grieve someone who‚Äôs died and in such a tragic way, Your mind chooses what to think about and what to block out.Finding out the video was online has been really triggering for me, moments which I‚Äôd been blocking out to survive my days were now at the forefront of my mind. Why would you want to watch my daughteraposs last moments  I‚Äôm heartbroken, the thought of strangers, people who don‚Äôt know Paige or me watching something so traumatic and distressing. When people post such personal pictures or videos without consent, it can have a serious impact on people‚Äôs lives. Ms Rice said her le has been turned upside down by the death of her daughter as she shared a series of photos of herself with Paige growing up. She continued: I‚Äôm still Paige‚Äôs mum and I still have that protective instinct. I know Paige would hate that this video is online. Look at these pictures, this is my beautul baby girl Paige.  She was taken from us in October, only  years old. No matter how old your child gets, they‚Äôre still our babies. I had Paige at a young age and it‚Äôs Pretty much always been us three. My le has revolved around my children and making sure they never went without. I can‚Äôt tell you how much my le has been turned upside down since loosing my daughter. When you lose a child, just getting through an hour is an accomplishment.  The last five months has been a blur when it comes to time and I don‚Äôt know how I‚Äôm surviving each day with this heartache, a pain you will never know, unless you‚Äôve lived it. To cause added stress and upset is disrespectful and thoughtless. My le will never be the same again. I‚Äôve lost my daughter and my friend and my son has lost his sister and we‚Äôve all lost a massive piece of our lives. Paige left behind many broken hearts, she is loved and now missed by so many people, someone‚Äôs daughter, sister, granddaughter, niece, cousin and friend. We don‚Äôt deserve any more upset. I hope the posts are removed, I‚Äôd be extremely thankful. news uk-news queen-limit-platinum-jubilee-appearances-"Queen reveals she was ‚Äòtired and exhausted‚Äô during bout of CovidByTom Ambrose:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments The Queen could be set to limit her Platinum Jubilee appearances to just a handful of events after admitting her bout with Covid has left her feeling exhausted, according to a royal expert. The monarch had already faced months of mobility issues that saw her pull out of high-profile public events before Buckingham Palace revealed she contracted coronavirus in February.On Sunday Her Majesty spoke about her condition during a video call with the Royal London Hospital to mark the official opening of its Queen Elizabeth Unit. Talking to former Covid patient Asef Hussain and his we Shamina, the Queen said: ‚ÄúIt does leave one very tired and exhausted, doesn‚Äôt it   This horrible pandemic. It‚Äôs not a nice result.‚ÄùThis has led to increased speculation that her Jubilee appearances will be signicantly scaled back this summer, with royal biographer Angela Levin telling the MailOnline she believes the Queen will limit her activity.She said: Itaposs going to be very dficult and I think they will only show her in a few instances, maybe at the service at St Paulaposs. That will be very important to her because she is a Christian. I don‚Äôt think weaposll see her around and about. Maybe sheaposll be well enough to sit and watch horses. It wonapost be her, everywhere. Butshe is there, she will appreciate the fact the public will be wanting to be there and supporting her.  I imagine that the aides are worried thatthe public donapost see her, people may think thatsheaposs not there itaposs not worth us going. Iaposm sure everyone in the Palace hopes that people will turn up to show their respects and say thank you for an extraordinary reign both inand in breadth. The Palace has been approached for comment. The Queen, who had ‚Äúmild cold-like‚Äù ¬≠Covid symptoms, has recently been suffering from mobility issues, forcing her to cancel a number of public engagements. Buckingham Palace announced on Friday that she had decided not to attend an annual Easter church service.Prince Charles will for the first time represent his mother at the Royal Maundy Thursday service at St George‚Äôs Chapel at Windsor Castle, Berkshire.It will be only the fth time she has missed the event in her -year reign. news uk-news queens-right-hand-woman-reveal-"Queen attends London Fashion Week with Angela Kelly in ByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Apr |commentsThe Queen has given her blessing for her right-hand woman to release an updated version of her book where she shares her secrets about working for the Royal Family.Angela Kelly has been the monarchaposs personal advisor and senior dresser, working with her closely every day, for almost  years.In , she released the book - The Other Side of the Coin - which featured never before seen behind-the-scenes photos and insider information about le at Buckingham Palace. And now it has been announced that an updated version of the book is to be released next month to coincide with Her Majestyaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations.  According to the publisher Harper Collins, the updated book will feature new photographs as well as a brand new chapter.Covered in this chapter, Angela will talk about the royal householdaposs isolation during Covid- lockdown at Windsor Castle, which saw her taking on new roles such as cutting and setting the Queenaposs hair.The chapter will also cover Prince Philipaposs funeral, the Queenaposs first public engagement post-lockdown and a look ahead to Juneaposs Platinum Jubilee celebrations. Katya Shipster from Harper Collins said: We are so proud to be Angela Kellyaposs publishers. We wanted to commemorate the extraordinary occasion of the Queenaposs Platinum Jubilee with this beautul new edition, as well as bring the book right up to date following the unprecedented events of the past two years. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .It tells the story of the Royal bubble as well as the s Angela and the Royal Household went to, to ensure the safety of our monarch. There is no better look at what goes on behind the pomp and circumstance than this wonderful book. Ms Kelly is the first member of the royal staff to be given this kind of permission from the monarch to release a book.  Her official title is personal assistant, adviser, and curator , but behind closed doors, she is more importantly a trusted confidante and friend. And it is said that when the Queen tells staff she is stepping out for a bit it is actually royal code for her popping to see Ms Kelly.We are two typical women, Ms Kelly told Thein a rare interview in .We discuss clothes, make-up, jewellery. We say, aposWould this piece of jewellery look nice with that outfit apos, and things like that. Their close relationship has however reportedly caused jealousy among other members of staff, with Ms Kelly joking: I donapost have any more room for knives in my back. In the past, Ms Kelly has only given a handful of interviews but when she has spoken out publicly, she has gushed about her unwavering affection for her boss. She has described how much she adores the monarch and is so proud of her.The updated version of The Other Side of the Coin by Angela Kelly will be released on May .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON QueenRoyal FamilyAngela Kelly" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: real life castaway buys tropical
story: Real-le Castaway buys tropical island for ¬£, so he can live as a recluseBrendon Grimshaw, from Dewsbury, in Kirklees, West Yorkshire, bought Moyenne, a tiny island just half a mile wide in the luxurious Seychelles, for just ¬£,Brendon Grimshaw bought Moyenne for just ¬£, in  Image: Daily MirrorByConnor TealeLucy LeesonRyan Merrield:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsAn ex-newspaper editor bought a tropical island for ¬£, and dedicated the rest of his le to restoring its appearance and nurturing its wildle. Brendon Grimshaw, from Dewsbury, in Kirklees, West Yorkshire, abandoned his high-pressured old le in the face of unemployment - before the age of  - and took an extended holiday. In , he purchased Moyenne, a tiny island just half a mile wide in the luxurious Seychelles, a cluster of islands in the Indian Ocean.The ex-journalist immediately fell in love with his new home, with its tranquil silence and wild tangle of vegetation, Yorkshire Live reports.Brendon lived almost completely alone on the island. Moyenne had been left abandoned for decades, prior to his arrival and was so overgrown that falling coconuts were said to never reach the ground.  It has previously been likened to a tiny rainforest erupting from the ocean. With the help of -year-old Rene Antoine Lafortune, the son of a local fisherman, Brendon set about forging paths through the undergrowth. They also planted trees in an attempt to transform the island. Brendon built a humble wooden home for himself. But to truly transform the island he knew he would need to nurture itaposs wildle back to full health. He gradually introduced giant tortoises to his corner of the Indian Ocean and eventually shared Moyenne with  of the indigenous creatures.  Brendonaposs relentless hard work inevitably attracted the attention of wealthy investors, who viewed the Seychelles as a tropical paradise and an ideal spot for a luxury holiday destination. The aposreal le Robinson Crusoeapos - also since compared to the Tom Hanks character in the  film Castaway - is said to have turned down close to ¬£million for his small island. But he wanted to ensure its future in a dferent way, and not to line corporate pockets. As he had no children to pass the island to at the time of his death, Brendon signed a perpetual trust with the Seychellesapos Ministry of Environment in . The agreement marked the islandaposs transformation into a National Park. To this day, it remains the smallest island in the world to hold that title. Brendon passed away in  and his grave sits alongside that of his father, who came to live with him in later le. His tombstone reads: Moyenne taught him to open his eyes to the beauty around him and say thank you to God. The island is now overseen by the Moyenne Island Foundation and remains largely undeveloped.A restaurant serving local dishes, a small museum dedicated to Brendonaposs le, and two nurseries for giant tortoise hatchlings form the only additions to the area, reports the BBC. No more than  visitors are allowed on the island at any one time, even during peak tourist season.
