House, particularly Miss Hendrie and manager Ellen Mainwood, Mr Satchel, Mr Bruce and all volunteer helpers from the three schools.Miss Hendrie told the Courier: #It has been a joy to work with all the children for the last few months.#Seeing them learn and make amazing animations has been a real treat. I#m so proud of what each and every one of them has achieved.#

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ‚Äúa real dream come true‚Äù.She said: ‚ÄúWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.‚ÄùMeanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ‚Äì The Cheese Lady ‚Äì has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ‚ÄúWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.‚ÄúWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.‚ÄúAlso, I‚Äôm hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.‚ÄùSvetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ‚ÄúWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  That‚Äôs fantastic.‚ÄúAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.‚ÄùFellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ‚ÄúI think we are in a good place.‚ÄúWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!‚Äù

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than ¬£,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ‚ÄúWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.‚ÄúMary has raised a fantastic ¬£, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.‚ÄùLast year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised ¬£, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Roman‚Äôs Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ‚ÄúThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.‚ÄúI‚Äôm walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!‚ÄùPeople can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: rev-basil-clark-not-currently-active-ministry-complaint-made
story: The Very Rev Basil Clark, of Our Lady of Loretto and St Michael Catholic Church in Musselburgh and St Martins RC Church, Tranent, will not be in post while the complaint is being investigated.A spokesman for the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh said in a statement: "A complaint has been made against a priest based in the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh."While it is being investigated, he will not be in active ministry."No further details are being released by the Archdiocese of St Andrews  Edinburgh and the nature of the complaint has not been disclosed.The Courier has so far been unable to reach Father Clark, who lives in Musselburgh, for comment.During his absence, the parish will be administered by Father Andrew Garden of St David‚Äôs, Dalkeith.

title: airbnb-ranks-oxfordshire-town-top-easter-staycation-list--see-full-list
story: The holiday home rental company has rounded up the top  trending destinations that you can visit this Easter break.¬†Whether youre looking for a sun-soaked holiday at the seaside or youre curious to explore a popular spot closer to home, this list might just be the inspiration you need.¬†‚ÄúThe nation is set to enjoy the first Easter weekend without Covid restrictions in two years, and it‚Äôs great to see Brits are exploring up-and-coming areas of the UK to make the most of it," Amanda Cupples, General Manager for Northern Europe at Airbnb said.Dunbar. Credit: Tripadvisor Ms Cupples added: "The top trending destination list provides ample inspiration for those looking to get away and explore a new place over the long weekend.¬†‚ÄúBy visiting these local destinations,¬†Brits are supporting local economies and communities, and for those based in these destinations who are considering listing their Home on Airbnb, now is a great time to sign up.‚Äù:¬†Family friendly properties abroad in Spain, Greece and more for Easter from Vrbo:¬†Travelodge unveils Easter holiday deal with rooms for ¬£ - How to bookSee which East Lothian¬†town made the cut and how it ranked with other popular staycation destinations across the UK.¬†We cant say that were surprised to see sunny Dunbar make the list of Airbnbs top trending destinations to stay this Easter.¬†With no shortage of places to eat drink and unwind, this seaside town has plenty to offer tourists on a little Spring holiday.Find out how you can make the most of your visit on the Tripadvisor website.Its not the only beach spot to have made the rankings either with¬†Prestatyn in Wales¬†topping Airbnbs list.Not to mention,you fancy venturing down south, Lowestoft in Suffolk has also been proving popular with travellers.:¬†Best beaches in Scotland - See the top  according to Tripadvisor reviews:¬†The  best hotels in Scotland according to Tripadvisor reviews¬†Inspire your next trip by browsing the current available listings in these areas on the¬†Airbnb website.¬†Youll find everything from a secluded barn conversion in Burton Leonard to a peaceful cottage with a hot tub on¬†Loch Lomond.¬†Find out more about these properties and others like them by¬†visiting Airbnbs wishlist.

title: brunton-puppet-festival-music-comedy-drama
story: The Brunton is hosting Stories Just In Case, entertaining stories and puppetry for children aged four and over, presented by the Clydebuilt Puppet Theatre on Wednesday.Lempen Puppet Theatre Company brings Flotsam  Jetsam, visual theatre with original music next Saturday .The performance tells a hopeful adventure story about two very dferent creatures that must learn to work together.Other attractions at The Brunton include Irish legends The Fureys, whoto the Musselburgh theatre for a night of music, songs and stories this evening .The band, who have been entertaining audiences worldwide for  years, will sing their classics including I Will Love You, When You Were Sweet , The Green Fields of France, The Old Man, Red Rose Cafe, From Clare to Here, Her Father Didn‚Äôt Like Me Anyway, Leaving Nancy and Steal Away, plus songs from their new CD, The Times They Are A Changing.Jack Docherty , the BAFTA award-winning star of Scot Squad and Absolutely, and one of Scotland‚Äôs favourite comic performers, brings his critically acclaimed play Nothing But to The Brunton tomorrow .A love letter to Edinburgh, the Fringe and summer rain, Nothing But is a tender, playful, darkly comic tale, in which Jack grapples with lost youth, infatuation, fatherhood, sex, secrets and truth. The show achieved rave reviews and a sell-out run at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last year.The Royal Opera House Live screening on Wednesday is The Royal Opera with Giuseppe Verdi‚Äôs La Traviata ‚Äì one of the best-known operas in the world.Set in th-century Paris, courtesan Violetta sings some of the composer‚Äôs most acclaimed arias, including Sempre libera, in her poignant and passionate encounters with Alfredo and Germont.Richard Eyre‚Äôs production for The Royal Opera recently celebrated  years on the Royal Opera House stage and this year s acclaimed opera star Pretty Yende as Violetta. The opera is sung in Italian with English subtitles.Trio Doyenne‚Äì pianist Monika Masanauskaite, violinist Michelle Dierx and Shannon Merciel on cello ‚Äì perform next Tuesdayas part of the Lunchtime Classical Concert series at The Brunton.Audiences can enjoy soup and a sandwich in the upstairs bar before an hour of classical music follows.In the programme next Tuesday is Brahms‚Äôs B minor piano trio and, as an opener, the group play a trio by the early th-century French composer Lili Boulanger, who died tragically young as she was turning into a major musical talent.The National Theatre Live screening on Thursday, April , is Henry V.Kit Harington, who became a global star after playing Jon Snow in Game of Thrones, plays the title role in Shakespeare‚Äôs study of nationalism, war and the psychology of power.Fresh to the throne, King Henry V launches England into a bloody war with France. When his campaign encounters resistance, this inexperienced new ruler must prove he is fit to guide a country into war.Captured live from Donmar Warehouse in London, this modern production, directed by Max Webster, of Le of Pi, explores what it means to be English and the relationship to Europe, asking: do we ever get the leaders we deserve Full information about these events can be found at thebruntonTickets can be purchased directly through The Brunton‚Äôs website or via the box office on   , open from Monday to Saturday, am to pm.

title: haddington-teenager-overwhelmed-meeting-hibernian-heroes
story: Lewis Kerr has been taking part in the Bridge Centre Motorcycle Project and staff at Knox Academy Meadowpark were so impressed with his efforts that they decided to mark his progress.The -year-old was rewarded with a trip to the Hibernian Training Centre at East Mains, near Ormiston.Despite many members of the Easter Road squad being on international duty, he got more than he bargained for during his visit with Paula Lackie, a school and family support worker at the Haddington school.He said: ‚ÄúI have been a season ticket holder of Hibernian Football Club since .‚ÄúMrs Lackie took me up to the training centre for a look around.‚ÄúWe weren‚Äôt expecting to see any players as it was the start of the international break.‚ÄúWe went into the main entrance and we were welcomed by one of the staff members.‚ÄúHe asked me who my favourite player was and I replied: ‚ÄòIt was Martin Boyle but now that he‚Äôs left it is probably Kevin Nisbet or Sylvester Jasper.‚Äô‚ÄúAs Mrs Lackie was talking to the staff member, Kevin Nisbet approached me on a pair of crutches.‚ÄúI asked him for a photo and he politely agreed.‚ÄúMy breathing got quicker in excitement.‚ÄúAs we were about to leave, we saw Paul McGinn and Kyle Magennis in a black car.‚ÄúI approached them and askedI could take a photo with them.‚ÄúI was overwhelmed with excitement and I can‚Äôt thank them enough for taking the time to talk and take pictures with me.‚ÄùThe teenager has been taking part in the Bridge Centre Motorcycle Project : mentoring programme.At the same time as learning motorbike skills, Lewis and his mentor focus on personal development, resilience and le skills.The programme, which takes place over a six-week period where Lewis attends the Poldrate venue every Thursday as part of a certied course, is tailored to Lewis and the personal goals that he has set.Mrs Lackie told the Courier she had noticed a real dference in Lewis since participating in the programme and wanted to mark his progress.She said: ‚ÄúLast week, I thought it would be nice to reward his excellent work with a visit to his favourite football team‚Äôs training ground.‚ÄúThis was very ad hoc and we didn‚Äôt expect what followed.‚Äù

title: young-artists-sought-design-fringe-sea-programme-cover
story: The winning entrant will be featured front and centre on the festival‚Äôs promotional material, including , programmes and posters all over East Lothian and Edinburgh.The competition is open to all primary school pupils in East Lothian and should feature a bright and colourful image that encapsulates the county, North Berwick or their favourite memories of the festival.The winner will receive FBTS show tickets and food from the festival vendors worth ¬£, as well as an FBTS t-shirt.Runners-up will receive a family ticket to one of the FBTS family events, which will be hosted between August  and .Rory Steel, festival director, said: ‚ÄúWe have run this competition over the past couple of years and the team at the festival have been blown away at the standard of entries.‚ÄúThere is certainly a lot of artistic talent amongst East Lothian children and this is a great way to keep them occupied during the Easter holidays.‚ÄùIllustrations should be submitted in a portrait orientation by Wednesday, May , to the festival office, Fringe by the Sea Competition, The Lighthouse, The Heugh, North Berwick, EH PX.All entrants should include name, school and class alongside a contact number.FBTS has already announced several acts to perform at this year‚Äôs festival including Frankie Boyle, Happy Mondays, Texas and The Manfreds.Visit fringebythesea tickets for tickets.

title: macmerry-anniversary-joy-couple-toast-60-years-together
story: Margaret, , and Leslie Somerville, , of Westbank Road, spent an afternoon with family to celebrate reaching the milestone.When asked about the secret to keeping a marriage going for so long, Margaret said that. . . there wasn‚Äôt one!She told the Courier: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt think of anything really we are happy, and we just get on with it.‚ÄùThe couple first met ‚Äúup the dancing‚Äù in North Berwick and sparks flew.About a year later, the pair were married at the Methodist Church in Cockenzie on March , .The couple moved into their first house together in Fenton Barns shortly after, where they would raise their family.Leslie worked in the building trade, primarily with Campbell and Smith, while Margaret worked in a iety of roles but spent most of her time with GGS Engineering as a cook.The Somervilles have three children ‚Äì Yvonne, , Neil, , and Michelle,  ‚Äì and five grandchildren ‚Äì Lee, , Ryan, , Adele, , Connor, , and Shannon, .Margaret told the Courier that witnessing them all grow up and get married were the couple‚Äôs best memories.She said: ‚ÄúThe best [memory] was just seeing the family growing up and getting married.‚ÄùTheir daughter Michelle spoke of how proud she was that they had reached the milestone but also how much they had sacriced for the family over the years.She said: ‚ÄúMy dad was always working constantly to make sure we could go on holiday.‚ÄúBoth have worked all their lives but they have always been there for the family.‚Äú[I am] really proud because they‚Äôve had, like everybody, their ups and downs and the hard times, but they were always there for us.‚ÄúThey‚Äôve been together for so long and kept on going because they constantly niggle at each other!‚ÄùMichelle said that her most cherished memory of her parents was when she had her first child.She said: ‚ÄúFor me, it would be when I had my son, their first grandson, and they were fantastic, and I would probably say it was one of their proudest moments.‚ÄúThey were always there, always babysitting.‚ÄùMargaret and Leslie recently welcomed their first great-grandchild, Ellis ‚Äì and that, Michelle thinks, is one of their proudest moments.She said: ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre over the moon that they‚Äôve got a great-grandson, it was the one thing they desperately wanted.‚Äù

title: tims-tales-blackbirds-gift
story: The sunshine was breaking through the last remaining wisps of morning mist. Signs of spring, my favourite season, were visible all over our garden. The blackbird was perched on the fence and I opened the window so I could hear his song better.I watched him for a moment. He is a regular visitor but he seemed particularly vocal this morning. Then I noticed there was a female blackbird as well. I felt privileged that I could witness their visit to our small rewilded garden, which we have tried to make bird friendly.Then the singing stopped and they both seemed to be peering down at the patch of soil where we have recently planted wildflower seeds and vegetables. The male landed on the soil and began hopping in a zig-zag fashion, stopping every now and then. At first I wonderedthis was a dance to impress the female, but soon realised he was looking for breakfast.Blackbirds love earthworms and I supposed the overnight rain on the exposed soil of our newly seeded flowerbed meant it was a good moment to go hunting for his favourite food. He was looking for worms, but also listening for them, as blackbirds can hear the sound of them moving underground. I find that almost dficult to believe, but apparently it‚Äôs true. It was fascinating and joyous to watch.But I don‚Äôt knowhe caught any worms. My attention was taken by the sound of our kids getting up. School day morning routine beckoned. Time seems to vanish in the drama of it all, and so after I kissed my we goodbye as she headed for work, I quickly got busy making the kids‚Äô breakfast.It was at this moment an emotion overtook me: guilt. I often feel a sense of guilt when I know others are suffering terribly. One solution could be to disconnect from it, not think about it, or even try not to care. After all, we have our own family worries and problems to sort out.But the guilt comes from the empathy I feel and I don‚Äôt want to disconnect from that. I don‚Äôt think I could stop caring evenI tried. The world needs more empathy, not less. But there is a downside to it: it can become overwhelming and even affect my mental health.Guilt in this context is such a useless emotion. It doesn‚Äôt help those who are suffering and it certainly doesn‚Äôt help the person feeling empathy. So as my guilt arrived at the breakfast table that morning, I gave it short shrt and became determined to replace it with two things.The first was to learn the lesson the blackbird had taught me moments before, to enjoy the moment and the gts around me. It put me in mind of a beautul short film of the artist David Hockney, made by Louisiana Museum of Modern Art. It‚Äôs titled The World is Beautul and he talks about the beauty around us and that when bad news is dominating our senses, the arrival of spring is good news. The important thing is to really notice the gts around us, which Hockney says he does with ‚Äúintensity‚Äù.So I took up his advice and, on my walk to school with my son, I made sure I was fully present for him as he talked about monsters, Dr Who and his favourite scenes from Clash of the Titans. I savoured every moment of our connection and conversations.On myto the house, I made an extra effort to notice the beauty of spring‚Äôs arrival and other gts: the diamond-like sparkle of the dew drops on the grass, and the patterns made by the children running and playing amongst them, the dedication of George the lollipop man in keeping us all safe, the brief and faint rainbow in the sky above us, and the shimmer of the sea below the trees in bloom, and the yellow carpet of daffodils dancing in the breeze the birdsong, the smiles and greeting of people, the sense of community, the warmth of the sun the fact of being alive and having loved ones in my le.The walk was only four minutes, but when we notice the beauty and gts we have around us with the intensity that Hockney mentions, then we don‚Äôt measure with time.The second thing was to change my guilt into acts of compassion that can make a dference, no matter how small. Donate, write a letter, send a message of support, whatever. That way, empathy works for positive change for those in need.I already knew all this, but it seems I constantly need to relearn it. And that morning, the blackbird helped me to do so. His song was an awakening gt, his zig-zag hop across the soil a reminder that we should have moments when we pause to look and listen with ‚Äúintensity.‚ÄùAsto confirm this, he was still there on the fence when I ed home. I‚Äôd love to say he had a worm in his beak, as that would have been such a poetic ending, but he didn‚Äôt. His companion wasn‚Äôt there and he flew off as I watched him.He‚Äôd made my morning by making a positive dference in ways he will never know or understand, and not just for me.

title: pictures-thousands-new-trees-planted-butterdean
story: At the end of last month, local school groups and corporate volunteers got out their gloves, boots and shovels to help plant new trees.The trust also ran a community day on Saturday, March , that saw  people participate and help populate the wood with thousands of native trees., Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog! " alt"East Lothian Courier: This is the McCrum family of Tranent.Mum Leigh, Ella , Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog! " class"editor-image"The McCrum family of Tranent.¬† Mum Leigh, Ella , Abbie , Dad Corin and Daisy the dog!¬†Woodland Trust Scotland recently acquired two open fields adjacent to Butterdean Wood, thanks to support from Bank of Scotland. The first was planted last autumn.This time, people of all ages came out on the Saturday to help plant the new trees.Freya Brown of Pencaitland BrowniesGeorge Anderson, of Woodland Trust Scotland, said: ‚ÄúWe are so grateful that our partnership with Bank of Scotland has allowed us to add this new area of woodland.‚ÄúIt will be a marvellous haven for people and wildle but also a carbon store to help in the fight against climate change.Ben Murray, his grandad John Jeffrey and his dad Andrew Murray‚ÄúOver the week we had primary one pupils from Haddington Primary School and Bank of Scotland staff in to get spring planting started.‚ÄúThen on the Saturday,  people came to our community planting day and filled the entire field with native trees.‚ÄúWe hope everyone willto see how their trees are doing over the years.‚ÄùSouth Scotland MSP Craig Hoy was among those helping out on the dayAmong those taking part was South Scotland MSP Craig Hoy, who added: ‚ÄúThe work of Woodland Trust Scotland has been pivotal in creating, protecting and restoring native woodland heritage and fighting against climate change.‚Äù

title: thousands-spent-upgrading-dunbar-high-street-lighting
story: East Lothian Council plans to upgrade the lights over the coming months, after concerns were raised about the number of faulty lights on the street.Councillor Norman Hampshire, ward councillor and council leader, gave the update to Dunbar Community Council last month.He said: ‚ÄúWe have got an agreement to replace all fittings.‚ÄúThey are going to be LED lights and they are looking at dferent options.‚ÄùOne of the issues is that High Street ‚Äì and much of Dunbar to the north-east of the East Coast Mainline ‚Äì falls within the town‚Äôs conservation area.Changes to the look of the street lights would need to receive approval from East Lothian Council‚Äôs planning department.Mr Hampshire said that the design had ‚Äúto match in with the streetscape‚Äù.He said: ‚ÄúThe intention is as soon as they get that then they will replace all the light fittings.‚ÄùIt is hoped that modernising the lights will also lessen the cost of maintenance.A spokeswoman for the local authority confirmed that work was due to take place this summer.She said: ‚Äú¬£, was the estimate for full new replacement.‚ÄúHowever, we have been offered a retrofit solution from the original supplier .‚ÄúIt‚Äôs much cheaper at about ¬£, and there is currently a - week delivery, so hoping to have this completed July August .‚Äù

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-1997-1972-1922
story: ‚ÄòTENT slashing brought terror for children‚Äô was the front page headline on the April ,  edition of the East Lothian Courier.A fun night camping in the back garden turned to terror for three young friends last week, when a thug slashed at their tent with a kne ‚Äì narrowly missing one of the children.The unknown attacker slashed through the fly sheet of the small tent as Martin Runciman, , his cousin, Daniel McFarlane, and Paul Harvey, both aged , screamed with fright.The mindless attack lasted for less than a minute, before the culprit escaped over the garden fence.Later the youngsters found a kne nearby and handed it to police probing the incident, believing it may have been dropped by the man as he fled.Martin, at whose home in Gardiner Crescent, Prestonpans, the attack occurred, has been left shaken by the incident....and  years ago‚ÄòIncrease in Ranco labour force is marvellous news‚Äô said the East Lothian Courier on April , .The news that another  jobs are to be made available at Haddington by American-owned firm of Ranco Motors Ltd., was welcomed this week as a shot in the arm for the employment situation in the County as well as the town.Provost A. F. Spowage of Haddington commented: ‚ÄúI think this is really marvellous news. We had heard some time ago in the Council that this would probably be coming off but we were not sure.‚ÄúThis is really a vote of confidence in the company here. From the employment aspect at a time like this it could not be better. It will help the employment situation in the County and not only Haddington.‚ÄùThe announcement that more workers would be taken on at Haddington ‚Äì where Ranco Motors had premises at Hospital Road and the Dunbar Road ‚Äì came close on the heels of the disclosure that the company‚Äôs Tannochside factory in Lanarkshire is to shut later this year....and  years agoA NUMBER of housebreakings were reported in Dunbar, reported The Haddingtonshire Courier on April , .During the weekend, four cases of housebreaking, extending over three nights, were reported to the police.Two private houses and a hotel in the east end of the town, and a smith‚Äôs shop at Broxburn were entered and ious articles stolen.No trace of any suspicious person could be found until on Monday morning it was discovered that a man had been living unobserved in an unaccompanied house, laying low during the day, and, it was suspected, sallying forth at night.

title: medical-practice-promoting-cold-water-swimming-aid-health
story: Swim-in-the-sea sessions kickstarted on Friday at am and will continue at the same time each week at the Boatshore, Cockenzie.A spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe are pretty convinced about the benefits of cold-water swimming for both our physical and mental health.‚ÄúIt seems particularly helpful in managing feelings of stress, anxiety, panic attacks and low mood‚ÄúThere is also a growing body of evidence that it can help painful conditions including fibromyalgia and might even boost our immune systems.‚ÄùThe surgery recommends attendees bring a towel, warm clothes and a hot drink with them and has posted additional safety advice on its website.

title: david-allan-tributes-paid-former-preston-lodge-head-teacher
story: Headteacher of Preston Lodge High School from  to , he made a major contribution to the le of the school and the community it serves.Mr Allan, described as Preston Lodge ‚Äúthrough and through‚Äù, has been fondly remembered by current and former staff, as well as former students and their families.Born in , David attended Preston Lodge High School himself, excelling in sport he became captain of the senior rugby team before also becoming captain of the cricket team.He also enjoyed a successful athletics career during his years at school, and was house captain of Grange.Mr Allan studied chemistry at the University of Edinburgh before training as a teacher at Moray House, saying at the time: ‚ÄúFor me there was never any choice. It had always been my ambition to teach.‚ÄùFollowing five years at George Heriot‚Äôs School in Edinburgh, Mr Allan ed to Preston Lodge as head of science.It wasn‚Äôt long before he had climbed the ranks, and he was appointed headteacher in .He said then: ‚ÄúI am tremendously excited, but a little frightened when I think that I have achieved the actual job of running the school involving teachers who taught me.‚ÄùThroughout Mr Allan‚Äôs  years in the role, many positive changes were introduced and the headteacher gained a strong reputation within and beyond the community, with his enthusiasm ‚Äúbringing the best out of a whole generation of students‚Äù.A minute‚Äôs applause was held for Mr Allan at a recent Preston Lodge RFC game.A spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe were saddened to hear of the passing of our former president, Mr David Allan, last week ‚Äì a man who gave so much to PLRFC.‚ÄúThank you all for joining our minute of applause at Saturday‚Äôs st XV fixture at the Pennypit. Our sincere condolences to the Allan family.‚ÄùCurrent Preston Lodge headteacher Gavin Clark thanked Mr Allan for all his contributions to the school.Mr Clark said: ‚ÄúDavid Allan was a stalwart of the Prestonpans community and a PLer through and through. He will be hugely missed.‚ÄúAs Preston Lodge‚Äôs headteacher, he shaped and developed a school culture which everyone still benefits from.‚ÄúDavid was a man of clear views and high standards, but was also a man of great personality and humanity. His care for the staff, students and families he worked with made PL what it is today.‚ÄùMr Clark went on to explain that, beyond his time at Preston Lodge, Mr Allan stayed connected to the school, adding: ‚ÄúI was lucky to be able to learn from his insight and wisdom about our community and about PL‚Äôs proud past. His legacy lives on at PL, for sure, and our thoughts are with his family at this dficult time.‚ÄúThank you, David, for everything that you did for Preston Lodge and everyone connected to our school.‚ÄùTributes flooded on to social media, with former Preston Lodge student Audrey Mackay saying: ‚ÄúHe was a truly respected man.‚ÄúAn excellent chemistry teacher and he gained my huge respect as a headteacher by showing fair strictness and understanding which was needed at that time.‚ÄúSorry to hear of his death. He taught me a lot which I didn‚Äôt realise at the time. Thoughts with his family.‚ÄùChris Horton added: ‚ÄúA lovely level-headed man. Our sons liked him too.‚ÄúRIP Davey Allen: you really were a lovely man and a great headmaster.‚ÄúEveryone had respect for you.‚ÄùAnother former student, Mary Johnston, said: ‚ÄúRIP Mr Allan: you got me a job when I left school at , I was there for  years. Condolences to all the family.‚ÄùMr Allan passed away on March .

title: county-man-shortlisted-fisherman-year
story: Fishing is very much in the blood for -year-old Rowan Davies, with a long line of fishing and leboat heritage coming from both sides of his family.The Dunbar resident started in the family business as a -year-old, helping out with landing the catch.By the age of , he was giving up his summer holidays to go out fishing.He officially joined the family vessel Spitfire seven years ago.Now, he has been shortlisted for the Fishing News Young Fisherman of the Year Award.Rowan was nominated for his ‚Äúoutstanding commitment to the job and the boat, giving up his free time to learn and better himself every day‚Äù.On hearing of his nomination, he said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs absolutely fantastic.‚ÄúI can‚Äôt believe it. I‚Äôm over the moon.‚ÄùWith awards in  categories this year, the Fishing News Awards  recognise outstanding achievement across all areas of the UK and Irish commercial fishing industry in .The Young Fisherman of the Year Award, sponsored by Seafish, recognises a fisherman under  years of age on December , , and based in the UK or Ireland, who has demonstrated outstanding skill, commitment and determination to succeed in the industry.Voting is open until midnight on Monday.The winners of this year‚Äôs Fishing News Awards will be announced at a gala presentation ceremony in Aberdeen on May .Visit fishingnews awards for more information or to vote.

title: three-course-meal-served-raise-money-charity
story: Our Community Kitchen has been working for about four years to try to tackle social isolation in Haddington and the surrounding area.The group meets in the town‚Äôs bowling club and is serving up to try to raise funds.Carrot and lentil soup will be followed by either prime roast beef, Yorkshire pudding, roast potatoes and buttered vegetables with a beef and red wine gravy, or vegetarian lasagne with roast potatoes and garlic bread.Sticky toffee pudding with ice cream will be followed by tea and coffee.The meal, which costs ¬£ per person, is served next Sundayfrom .pm.For more information, call  .

title: paul-mclennan-msp-column-keeping-promise
story: This is all about tackling the challenges facing care-experienced young people.The Scottish Government remains committed to Keeping the Promise and creating a care system that places love and relationships at the centre for every child and family who needs support.Last week, I attended a Parliamentary reception for STAF , hosted by Paul O‚ÄôKane MSP.It was a fantastic event and we heard from people in the sector, caregivers, those with lived experience and the Deputy First Minister. The passion was clear from all about getting this right.The Scottish Government has shown that supporting care-experienced young people is a top priority.One example is care-experienced student bursaries, where a higher-rate of student support funding has been made available to care-experienced students in higher and further education.The Scottish Government has also increased the value of eight Scottish social security benefits by six per cent, including Best Start Grants and Carer‚Äôs Allowance Supplement, to keep pace with rising costs. The ambition is clear to support care-experienced young people from the start, through their most formative years and beyond.Family support is one of the five main priority areas for the Promise.I was delighted to hear of the introduction of new Whole Family Wellbeing Funding of at least ¬£m over the course of this Parliament, which will enable the building of universal, holistic support services, available to children across Scotland.These services need to be designed locally, with clear input from carers, and prevent,we can, young people entering into care. I am already engaging with the council in this regard.

title: easter-activities-near-national-trust-events-including-easter-egg-hunts-east-lothian
story: Trying to keep your little ones entertained can be eggs-haustingat the best of times which is why we‚Äôre sharing a little inspiration to help keep them occupied over the break.Here are some of the spring activities that you and the family can get up to including everything from Easter egg hunts to fun family-friendly crafts."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "UK Bank Holidays ","description": "All the bank holiday dates in the UK in ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media yJjFhj poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests yJjFhj.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.eastlothiancourier video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "East Lothian Courier","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.eastlothiancourier sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Here‚Äôs a selection of the National Trust for Scotlands Easter activities that the whole family can try in East Lothian.Newhailes House and Gardens in Musselburgh are open across Easter for lots of family fun.The stunning Palladian mansion is hosting an Easter egg trail across the weekend from April -- with ious times available.Tickets for the Easter Egg Hunt start at ¬£ and can be purchased through the National Trust for Scotland website.:¬†Travelodge unveils Easter holiday deal with rooms for ¬£ - How to book:¬†Easter : Luxury Easter Eggs from Hotel Chocolat, Thorntons, Fortnum and Mason and moreTake a Spring stroll through the Inveresk Lodge Garden, located just south of Musselburgh.¬†Theres a¬†discovery trail for children where they can spot all of the flora and fauna andyou come prepared with your own net, you can go pond dipping too.¬†Alternatively, once youve finished exploring Newhailes House, the th-century designed woodland landscape is ideal for working up an appetite for the delights of the¬†Stables Caf√©.Colourful Easter eggs in Easter crafts set. title: young-musicians-show-talent-contest
story: The Young Musician of the Year competition, which attracted a dozen young people from schools and music schools in the town, was held recently via Zoom.The winner of the vocal section was Kirsteen Brownlee, from the Mansfield School of Music, with her performance of I‚Äôd Give My Le For You by Claude-Michel Sch√∂berg from the musical Miss Saigon.Sam Scott, a drummer from Loretto School, came out top in the instrumental section with the Paul Simon hit  Ways To Leave Your Lover.The runners-up were both pupils of Musselburgh Grammar School ‚Äì Sadie Croosdale in the vocal section, with Requiem from Dear Evan Hansen by Benji Pasek and Justin Paul, and pianist Michael Hoole in the instrumental section with Praeludium by the German composer J.S. Bach.The musicians played and sang a wide iety of music, ranging from classical to ‚Äôs pop legends Duran Duran, giving the judge, Rob Harrison, of Erskine Stewart‚Äôs Melville Schools, a tough task.The musicians attracted ‚Äúconstructive and positive comments‚Äù from him, a club spokesperson later said.She added: ‚ÄúThe club would like to pass on their very grateful thanks to the music teachers, accompanists, parents and, of course, the wonderful competitors who once again impressed hugely with their skills.‚Äù

title: relay-life-coming-dunbar-summer
story: East Lothian‚Äôs first ever Relay for Le will be held at Hallhill in Dunbar on June -.Teams can sign up for the event, which sees team members take turns to walk around the track for a -hour period to signy that cancer never sleeps.Elaine Lennon, chairperson of the Relay for Le Dunbar committee, encouraged people to sign up.She said: ‚ÄúAccompanying this fun, family-friendly and accessible challenge will be a festival-like atmosphere of entertainment for the whole community, who will be invited to join in the fun while cheering the participants on.‚ÄúKey elements of it are the emotive and celebratory survivors lap which launches the event, the reflective Candle of Hope which lights up the track overnight, and the opportunity to fight with us in the battle against cancer by raising and donating funds for Cancer Research UK .‚ÄùRelay For Le celebrates the power of community fundraising in the fight to beat cancer.Teams of family and friends fundraise for cancer research, then unite as a community to celebrate and remember everyone who has been affected by cancer.One in every two people will get cancer in their letime.Cancer has played a part in the le of Elaine, who grew up in Dunbar before moving into Edinburgh.Her brother Greig Hannan was just  when he died from kidney cancer in September .The talented musician played lead guitar in the Setting Sons, a classic punk covers band, and also worked as a postman.The dad-of-three, who lived on the town‚Äôs Ash Grove, also played football for Dunbar United and Cockburnspath FC.Elaine‚Äôs dad, Duncan Hannan, was diagnosed with bladder cancer later that year and will be on hand to walk the survivors‚Äô opening lap by Elaine‚Äôs side, after she was diagnosed with breast cancer five years ago.Speaking about her diagnosis, she said: ‚ÄúI was scared, upset and mainly worried about how mum and dad would cope with even more of this dreadful disease in the family.‚ÄúMy husband Alan and daughter Carrie were my rock, and Carrie even agreed to shave my hair for me to help me take control.‚ÄúSix years on, now, and I‚Äôm feeling fine.‚ÄúCRUK was an incredible help in many ways, from the role they played in discovering radiotherapy and other key treatments.‚ÄúAlso, working for CRUK made me more aware of checking myself and that‚Äôs what found my lump and made me go see about it.‚ÄúThe whole family now take part in fundraising to create more tomorrows for more families.‚ÄùThe county‚Äôs first Relay for Le will get under way at am on Saturday, June .The Candle of Hope ceremony will then take place between pm and .pm as walkers continue throughout the night.For more information, search for Relay for Le on Facebook, visit cancerresearchuk.org or email relaydunbar@gmail

title: cherry-trees-planted-gifford-remember-impact-pandemic
story: The trees were planted on March  ‚Äì the second anniversary of the start of the first lockdown ‚Äì outside the village‚Äôs Tweeddale Arms Hotel.The National Trust came up with the idea to create spaces where people could remember all those who had lost their lives, honour key workers and reflect on the shared experience of the pandemic.Gford Community Council, East Lothian Council and Gford Horticultural Society created the tribute.Roger Wilson, Gford Horticultural Society president, was delighted to be involved, with the trees also to be registered as part of the Queen‚Äôs Green Canopy, which is marking the Queen‚Äôs Platinum Jubilee.He said: ‚ÄúThese cherry trees will bloom each spring around the time that the pandemic first changed our lives.‚ÄúThey will be a permanent reminder of those incredibly challenging times and a symbol of how our community came together to help one another.‚Äù

title: vet-column-taking-pet-holiday-plan-long-way-advance
story: These last two years have really taken their toll on our ability to go on holiday, but hopefully this summer we should be able to make our way to sunnier places without too much red tape. Unfortunately, I still have a job to do and won‚Äôt be holidaying for a few months, but it doesn‚Äôt stop me dreaming of sun and sea. I do love the south of France and hopefully I‚Äôll be heading there soon.But what about my pets  When I‚Äôm away for a short spell, I like someone to look after my pets in their own home. They are relaxed in their own environment.However, when on a longer holiday, my pets are looked after extremely well by boarding kennels and cattery in East Lothian. Cats are not usually the best travellers but you can try using calming cat pheromones to relax them. Your vet can advise you on ‚ÄòFeliway‚Äô cat calming products for any journey. My dog Lucy, on the other hand, loves travelling and adores going to the boarding kennel. She gets so excited when she knows she is on her way to the kennels.But whatyou want to take your pets with you on holiday  In Britain today, pets can travel by road, rail, sea or air. Each form of travel presents its own unique set of problems.The Highway Code is very specic about animals in cars. They should be under control in vehicles and unable to distract you while you are driving. If you want your dog to be loose in the car, he should be separated from you, and thus an estate vehicle, SUV or hatchback with a strong dog guard is ideal. Alternatively, a crate or cage can be used, the dimensions of which should be comfortable for the animal.Travel, or more correctly motion sickness, affects many dogs. It is due to the effect of the motion on the organs of balance located in the inner ear. Signs are usually excessive salivation, restlessness or excitement. Consult your veterinary surgeon as there are several prescription medicines that are extremely effective for this condition. Excitable dogs can be tranquilised but make sure you do not give too much, which may result in your pet becoming very drowsy, since the dose depends largely on the temperament and amount of excitement.Remember that even the most well-behaved dog can take fright at the sight and noise associated with a railway station and trains. Make sure that the collar and lead are strong and secure.Today, dferent railway companies have ying conditions regarding the transport of pets and therefore you should always enquire prior to your trip. Cats should be transported in secure carriers at all times. When travelling on the underground with your dog, remember it must be carried up and down any escalators. If you have a large dog, seek other means of access to the .Many ships and ferries today have permanent kennels into which your dog must be placed for the duration of the trip. The provision of a familiar blanket or toy helps to ease the tension of the journey for your pet.International Air Transport Associationregulations regarding carrier size apply to all international flights. Remember the container will be your pet‚Äôs home for theof the flight and also for an appreciable time prior to and after the flight after you have checked in and until he is collected after the flight. The carrier should be large enough for your dog to stand up and turn around freely. It is useful to use several thicknesses of newspaper, plus an acrylic dog bed of the VetBed type as bedding. A familiar article in the container helps to calm the animal. It is always worthwhile checking with the airline regarding their particular requirements.Not only has Covid- had a marked effect on travel, Brexit certainly has in respect of travelling overseas with your pets. Previously, for travel to EU countries, we vets could issue passports for your pet to travel with you to Europe. This is no longer the case.If you are considering travelling to an EU country with your pet, please start to plan long before your trip. Animals, specically dogs, cats and ferrets, require an Animal Health Certicateto travel to an EU country, including Northern Ireland. Any other pets require an Export Health Certicate or,you are travelling to non-EU countries, you will require a specic certicate issued in combination of DEFRA and the country you are travelling to.If you are travelling to an EU country, your pet needs to be microchipped and registered to you in the UK. This has to be read and confirmed by a vet prior to your pet being vaccinated against rabies.Recently, Mr Andrew Finlayson came to our Tranent surgery with his beautul greyhounds Celt and Lassie for their rabies vaccines. I checked their microchips and their paperwork prior to giving their vaccines. The AHC can only be issued more than three weeks after this rabies vaccination. The vet must be a registered official veterinary surgeonin order to be able to complete the certicate. The certicate cannot be issued until within  days of your travel from the UK date. Your vet needs to check your pet at this time.If you are travelling to Northern Ireland, Eire, Malta, Norway or Finland, your pet needs to be given medication against tapeworms between one and five days of you travelling. At Dunedin Vets, we combine this with the examination for the AHC.Each AHC is unique to your pet or pets. Up to five animals can travel on one certicate. The certicates are only valid for one journey from the UK. You have to state the country where you are entering the EU and there only certain designated ports or airports you can travel to. There is a specic AHC for each EU country and each one issued has its own unique certicate number, for your pet or pets. The AHC is valid for up to four months you mustto the UK before this time is up, but you can travel around EU countries during this time.These AHCs are long documents which have to be completed accurately with all the correct details, which owners have to provide in advance to the veterinary surgeon who completes them.If you are considering taking your pets to the EU this summer, contact your veterinary surgeon as soon as possible to ensure all the required paperwork is in order. We want to avoid disappointments at all costs.If you are wanting to travel further afield, contact DEFRA as soon as you know. A recent Export Health Certicate for dogs travelling to Dubai took almost six months to arrange.Plan in advance and hopefully everyone can have a lovely summer holiday.

title: dunbar-park-new-home-french-sport-petanque
story: Visitors to Lauderdale Park will be able to try their hand at the sport of petanque.The sport, which involves trying to score points by having boules closer to the target than the opponent, dates back more than  years.Now, after work between ious groups, a petanque piste has been created in the town, similar to that found in Haddington and North Berwick.Stuart McCombie, who has represented Scotland in petanque, is behind the idea to bring the sport to Dunbar.He said: ‚ÄúI used to play petanque many years ago at ious levels with ying degrees of success.‚ÄúI retired to Dunbar three years ago and there are no petanque facilities within Dunbar.‚ÄúFor the last of couple of years, I have been playing in Haddington.‚ÄúThey have got a beautul piste set up beside the river and the church.‚ÄúI play there with the UAand it was not until I moved here and joined that I was playing regularly again on a Wednesday.‚ÄúThey also play on a Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday and it is a long-established nice group of folk.‚ÄúI looked round and North Berwick have got a small piste by the tennis courts but there‚Äôs nothing in Dunbar.‚ÄùDunbar already has its own French connection, having been twinned with the town of Lignieres for nearly  years.Discussions took place between Mr McCombie, Dunbar and District Twinning Association, Dunbar Community Council and Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership . An appeal was put out on social media to check levels of interest in the facility being created.Mr McCombie told the Courier he was ‚Äúquite taken aback‚Äù by the feedback and decided to move forward with the plans.Funding was sourced from both the community council and DELAP, with work to create the piste in Lauderdale Park well under way.Mr McCombie said: ‚ÄúThe building is near completion.‚ÄúThe piste is now almost up and running and I‚Äôve had the first throw, just testing the surface.‚ÄúIt is a fantastic setting, a beautul setting. I did not think for a moment we would get inside the walled garden of Lauderdale Park.‚ÄùMembers of the public will be able to play the sport whenever there is not an organised event being held.Anyone without their own boules can hire them for ¬£ ‚Äì which covers everyone involved in the game ‚Äì from the park‚Äôs cafe.Disabled access has also been created at the piste, with an official launch expected to coincide with Dunbar Civic Week, which runs from June  to  this year.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, was delighted to see the plans moving forward.She said: ‚ÄúSeveral dferent options were considered and the conclusion was Lauderdale Park was the best.‚ÄúIt is protected, it has a wall, a cafe, when children are playing in the garden the parents can play petanque.‚ÄúThe other big thing is that it is entirely accessible to anybody. Little kids can play, adults can play, disabled people can play and I just thought it was fun.‚Äù

title: outlander-heading-east-lothian
story: John Muir Country Park, near Dunbar, was converted into an -century battle camp on Sunday, with residents spotting rows of identical old-fashioned tents.Other period pieces were also spotted, including horse-drawn carts, cannons, old-fashioned woven bags for sand or grain and other smaller props.The area remains cordoned off to the public, with cast and crew not having arrived on the site as of yet.The period drama has become an international sensation, following the history of Scotland from the Highland clearances to the Jacobite rebellion and beyond.Actor Sam Heughan has been spotted filming already in Fe and Edinburgh, leading many to believe he will soon be visiting East Lothian as well.More details about what historical battle will be filmed in the county remain unknown, but locals will be hoping to get a glimpse of their favourite actors as they eagerly await the next instalment of the series.

title: met-office-easter-bank-holiday-scotland-weather-forecast
story: It‚Äôs not all bad news though, the weather is set to clear up towards the weekend and it should certainly start to feel a little warmer than it has of late.While it might not be time to pack away your umbrella just yet, spring-like weather is on the way.If you havent already heard, its warming up in the run up to #Easter, but just how high will #temperatures climb  üìàFind out in our updated weather for the week ahead üëá pic EfHeVdpPIt is a rather wet and chilly start to the week rain is expected across most of Scotland today and tomorrow. Expect highs of only - ¬∞C.From Wednesday the weather should start to pick up as warm air spreads northwards, although there will still be the odd shower in places.Another dry day for most parts on Thursday and feeling warmer still with highs of around  ¬∞C.Friday could see temperatures reach as high as  ¬∞C but rain will start creeping back into most regions too.And it‚Äôs not good news for Easter egg hunts as despite Saturday predicted to bring much of the same more settled weather, there is likely to be a distinct turn for the worse come Sunday.For the following week, there is predicted to be a northwest-southeast split likely, with the northwest remaining more changeable with strong winds and rain at times.So while its not all bad news, a heatwave is perhaps overstating the milder weather expected in the coming days.

title: north-berwick-rugby-boys-just-edged-yorkshire-tournament
story: The county youngsters took on English opposition in a competition hosted by Sandal Rugby Club, Wakefield.As well as the hosts, teams from Gravesend Rugby Club in Kent and Surreys Old Cranleighans Rugby Club also took part.The North Berwick boys ended with a record of two wins, two draws and one defeat to just miss out on top spot.Coach Iain Macintosh said: "It was a successful tour and the boys - and the dads who accompanied them - had a great time."Although the lads finished runners-up to Gravesend, who were a physically bigger outfit, it was generally commented on that North Berwick had played the best rugby."Some injuries went against us but we punched above our weight and look forward to hopefully touring again in future. And thanks to Mike Hetherington at Morrison Personalised Wealth Management for sponsoring the boys tops."Despite the Covid pandemic, the under-s have welcomed more boys to their ranks as the squad has increased in size from  to  this season."This has all been down to the lads¬†enjoying their rugby and inviting along their mates," added Macintosh.Three years ago, the same group won the Scarlets Invitational Rugby Festival in Wales.North Berwick Rugby Football Clubs under-sline up before the start of their tour games in Wakefield, Yorkshire. Pictured areLewis Scott, Oscar Mackenzie, Grfyn Williams, Jake Hetherington, Adam Little, Stan Watson, Charlie Gill, Cameron Fyfe, Ethan Mulligan middle row: Kier McMullen, Jacob Jolly, Daniel Smith, Louis Napier, Gregor Macintosh, Ross Napier, Rhoan Fraser, Fergus Kinnaird, James Hendry and Ethan Glancy. At the front are tour mascots Moray Macintosh and Milo Fyfe.¬†

title: wordle-294-april-9-wordle-word-hints-todays-answer
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter S¬†and ends with the letter R.It has two vowels.It can describe a set of items that can help an inidual ascend or descend to another floor in a building.What is today‚Äôs Wordle answer, Saturday, April  If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†¬†¬†The Wordle for April ¬†is STAIR.¬†¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.

story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter S¬†and ends with the letter D.It has two vowels.A small group of people with a task.What is today‚Äôs Wordle answer, Monday, April  If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†¬†¬†The Wordle for April ¬†is SQUAD.¬†¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.In a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.

title: full-list-scotland-bank-holidays-2022-including-jubilee---see-dates
story: With the Queen celebrating her Platinum Jubilee, the UK will mark the occasion with an extra bank holiday in June.¬†Scotland usually benefits from more bank holidays than the rest of UK we also have¬†January  while other countries do not.In this bumper year for bank holidays, here are all the  dates in Scotland...Monday January   Tuesday January   Friday April   Monday May   Thursday June   Friday June   Monday August   Wednesday November   Monday December   Tuesday December  Easter Monday is not a nationwide bank holiday in Scotland, but certain councils do observe Easter Monday, including¬†Edinburgh, Falkirk and Dundee.¬†Local councils in Scotland have the power to make certain days local public holidays.Bank holidays are a devolved issue in Scotland, meaning dferent powers¬†allocate the days off in Scotland and England.¬†While Scotland does celebrate holidays¬†including Christmas, Boxing day and Easter Friday on the same day as the rest of the UK, others¬†are on dferent dates.¬†Only Scotland marks January  with a bank holiday, and although¬†Englands summer bank holiday takes place on August  , Scotlands¬†comes at the beginning of the month, on August ¬†.¬†

title: met-office-easter-bank-holiday-scotland-weather-forecast
story: It‚Äôs not all bad news though, the weather is set to clear up towards the weekend and it should certainly start to feel a little warmer than it has of late.While it might not be time to pack away your umbrella just yet, spring-like weather is on the way.If you havent already heard, its warming up in the run up to #Easter, but just how high will #temperatures climb  üìàFind out in our updated weather for the week ahead üëá pic EfHeVdpPIt is a rather wet and chilly start to the week rain is expected across most of Scotland today and tomorrow. Expect highs of only - ¬∞C.From Wednesday the weather should start to pick up as warm air spreads northwards, although there will still be the odd shower in places.Another dry day for most parts on Thursday and feeling warmer still with highs of around  ¬∞C.Friday could see temperatures reach as high as  ¬∞C but rain will start creeping back into most regions too.And it‚Äôs not good news for Easter egg hunts as despite Saturday predicted to bring much of the same more settled weather, there is likely to be a distinct turn for the worse come Sunday.For the following week, there is predicted to be a northwest-southeast split likely, with the northwest remaining more changeable with strong winds and rain at times.So while its not all bad news, a heatwave is perhaps overstating the milder weather expected in the coming days.

title: letters-sunak-easily-help-poor-wont
story: It is not a debt in the domestic sense. Money is created by the government and the dference between government expenditure and taxes raised is added to the ‚ÄúNational Debt‚Äù under double-entry accounting rules. It is a debt to the Bank of England which is in turn owned by government so ‚Äúrepayment‚Äù would simply deflate the economy.Banks create money under licence from the government. To maximise the economy there should be full employment at decent wages. If banks create insufficient money to achieve this in the private sector then government should do so by spending in the public sector.The only limit to public expenditure is from the onset of wage-driven inflation which government can address by reduced expenditure and increased taxes.Current inflation is due largely to the rise in international commodity prices. No amount of interest rate fiddling by the Bank of England can address this.There is no reason why Rishi Sunak cannot help the impending poverty and hardship for those at the bottom of the social scale. Only political dogma, economic ignorance and characteristic meanness of spirit prevents this. He did so when Covid hit so why cannot he do it again John Moreland, Killearn.COST OF LIVING WILL BE KEY FACTORREBECCA McQuillanputs forward some interesting analysis regarding voting patterns and the forthcoming local elections. The cost of living crisis is going to impact on every household in the country as she says, but it will disproportionately affect the vulnerable who include those on benefitswho received a lower-than-inflation increase from the Chancellor.Ms McQuillan mentions recent opinion polls one of the findings was that % of voters felt Finance Secretary Kate Forbes should be doing more in the midst of the crisis, sentiments I am sure Ms Forbes would agree with. However, the Scottish Parliament has no borrowing powers, its hands are tied and is dependent on Rishi Sunak ‚Äì whose response to the cost of living crisis was to give every household a ¬£ loan, to be paid back, and to reduce household council tax bills by ¬£ per year. All very well, butyou are exempt from paying council tax, you may well be missing out on ¬£ andyou are living in fuel poverty, paying back a loan could be the straw that breaks the camel‚Äôs back.This cost of living crisis is a real one for millions of hard-working families, millions who depend on benefits and millions who have been grateful for the Scottish Government‚Äôs mitigating measures in the form of its welfare fund, which has increased massively during the pandemic. The Scottish Government has prioritised tackling child poverty, as Ms McQuillan alluded to, with the Scottish Child Payment due to more than double this year to ¬£ a week.The cost of living will certainly be a factor in the local elections ‚Äì how could it not be  Voters will have the final say and they have given a clear verdict over the last decade and half here in Scotland. At no time during this time has Scotland voted for a Conservative government at Westminster, or for that matter, a Labour or LibDem majority in Scotland, and with the present opposition in Scotland I don‚Äôt think that is about to change any time soon.Catriona C Clark, Falkirk.LET DOWN BY OUR LEADERSTHINGS are not working in our country at the moment, nor have they been for several years. I agree with Kevin McKennas columnwith regards to Scotland. Boris Johnson should now not be the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, and those in his own sycophantic party who voted him into that very important position should hang their heads in shame.Rishi Sunak, Sir Keir Starmer and others are not fit to hold the positions in which they find themselves ‚Äì the former because he is currently living up to the oft-quoted phrase "there are three kinds of lies lies, damned lies, and statistics", and the latter because, as Lawrence Pertillar says in his poem Wishes to be Liked", "Nor will I ever believe one I suspect, To have a leadership position.But cannot make a decision. With kept wishes to be liked."I am so, so angry about the political state of our country, and indeed the world, that I spent time tracing a copy of a poem called Parable of the Talents by the American Octavia E Butler, which I wish to repeat here:"Choose your leaders with wisdom and forethought. To be led by a coward is to be controlled by all that the coward fears. To be led by a fool is to be led by the opportunists who control the fool. To be lead by a thief is to offer up your most precious treasures to be stolen. To be led by a liar is to ask to be told lies. To be led by a tyrant is to sell yourself and those you love into slavery".Sadly the last sentence cannot be heard by the Russians who are living under the rule of Putin.Walter Paul, Glasgow.BUCK STOPS WITH THE VOTERSI WOULD disagree with Nicola Sturgeons mealy-mouthed acceptance of blame while tying herself in knots with the double negative ‚Äì "I didnt not say to sign the ferry contracts" ‚Äì and "we are a collective therefore the buck stops with me".I say this, not in her defence, but because she is simply exploiting the gullible electorate who have voted her and the SNP back into power despite her previous "judge me on education" Curriculum for Excellence lying in tatters, and they may vote for her again. No, the buck stops with them, not Ms Sturgeon.Fool me once, shame on you fool me twice, shame on me. But it seems she can fool some of them all the time.Voters should remember this the next time they or a loved ones consultation or medical procedure is cancelled or comes too late, when they cannot get an appointment or procedure this side of Christmas. Many still seem unaware it is the Scottish Government that has full autonomy over the NHS in Scotland but clap like performing seals when the First Minister deflects this as the fault of a big bad posh Tory in Westminster.No, its not Ms Sturgeon the buck stops with us.Allan Thompson, Bearsden.CREDIT TO THE PM WHERE ITS DUESTEWART F Falconer , asserts that there is not one thing that Boris Johnston can be proud of.I will give off the top of my head just two examples. The first was his swt decision-making when this dreadful Covid virus first raised its head and showed it was a truly deadly danger to mankind. Whilst other countries dithered and procrastinated, especially the EU members, Mr Johnson acted by investing billions to find and secure a safe vaccine from scratch. Had he waited like everyone  who knows how many extra thousands would have died or been seriously ill and of course as a result of which, the NHS would have fallen over.The second is the leadership role the Prime Minister has taken in Ukraine in terms of sanctions and aid. It is on record that its President acknowledges the vital role undertaken by the UK Government in supplying the defensive armaments that has helped to mitigate the still-dreadful death toll being suffered by the Ukrainian people.So yes, I agree with the sentiments expressed in the letter of April  from Allan Sutherland which so upset Mr Falconer. Partygate, Wallpapergate and the rest of the gates still to be unearthed can wait their time to be answered, but in the meantime give credit where it is due to this Prime Minister.James Martin, Bearsden.It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. We also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of Scotlands conversation with itself.We are lucky at The Herald. We are read by an informed, educated readership who can add their knowledge and insights to our stories.¬†That is invaluable.¬†We are making the subscriber-only change to support our valued readers, who tell us they dont want the site cluttered up with irrelevant comments, untruths and abuse.In the past, the journalist‚Äôs job was to collect and distribute information to the audience. Technology means that readers can shape a discussion. We look forward to hearing from you on heraldscotland

title: letters-behind-sad-demise-glasgow-airport-aviation-leader-also-ran
story: That reminded me of the senior staffs enthusiasm for the continued expansion and development of the airport when I met them when working with Renfrew County then the Renfrew Division of Strathclyde.As one deputy manager of "airside", who became a friend, said, " an airport doesnt keep developing, its dead".I wonder what can be said of the shell of Scotlands link to the world.All US carriers gone, Virgin Atlantic gone, but just from Glasgow ‚Äì yet Glasgow was their first move from England. They are now in Edinburgh, serving a much smaller local population, yet all are extending their route network from there.Look back at Glasgows former daily and some seasonal routes ‚Äì Chicago, Newark, JFK, and Orlando ‚Äì and some earlier ones. All have or are ing to EDI and some new ones. Is that just the start Maybe it was greed. After all, Ryanairs boss pulled most routes because he felt landing fees were excessive. Did that encourage the departure  Other features, parking charges and the appalling herding of car drivers makes the whole experience a chore when once it was an excitement.It surprises me that people have not yet looked into the demise of this once-signicant international airport and asked its owners why.John Taylor, Dunlop.LEARN MORE ABOUT UKRAINEI HAVE been reflecting on how we, the UK citizenry, can get involved in the fight on the side of democracy, for all its shortcomings, against totalitarianism. Obviously many can donate generously to charities relieving some of the suffering of the Ukrainians and some are in a position to take in refugees from that benighted country.However. Andrey Kurkov, once described as being ‚ÄúUkraine‚Äôs most famous and successful living writer‚Äù who currently has a weekly slot on BBC Radio , Letter From Ukraine, when asked what we can do to help Ukraine recommends we ‚Äúfind out more about Ukraine. If you really want to know why this is happening read about our history‚Äù.I myself have just finished reading The Ukrainian Night: An Intimate History of Revolution by Marci Shore of Yale University. I did not find it the easiest of reads due to the plethora of Slavic names but it is well worth the effort based as it is on the personal reflections of participants in the Maidan Revolution of February . A more straightforward historical account is The Conflict in Ukraine: What Everyone Needs To Know by Professor Serhy Yekelchyk, a Ukrainian-Canadian historian of Ukrainian and Russian History.Anything  we can do  Yes indeed, write to The Herald Letters Pages with our thoughts on Ukraine.John Milne, Uddingston.WHEN WILL RUSSIANS LEARN THE TRUTH THOSE of us living in countries within Nato membership and their allies, and in fact many observers throughout the world, are looking on with horror and despair at the human misery, destruction and carnage which have occurred since the Russian invasion of Ukraine. One has to appreciate that most of what is going on there is subjected to a process of disinformation at the hands of the Russian state through its ious media outlets.One asks the question, how long can the Russian people remain unaware of the following facts: the vast numbers of Ukrainians, mostly women and children, having to leave their homes and to seek safety from attack in other countries the killing by Russian military of many civilians, including children the wanton destruction through air strikes, artillery bombardment and tank assaults of many residential areas the obstruction of humanitarian access in many areas the eradication of potential witnesses to atrocities attacks on hospitals We learn that President Putin wishes to have some kind of success to announce at the military celebrations on May . On that date Russia marks the surrender of Nazi Germany. One is left to wonder how disinformed about the despicable conduct of the Russian military forces in Ukraine the thousands attending that celebration in Moscow will be. It may not be likely to happen before May , but surely the day will come when the Russian people will be faced with the truth.Ian W Thomson, Lenzie.LET THE UN OBSERVERS INAFTER reading about, and seeing television reports, on apparently-substantiated Russian war crimes in Ukraine in the areas now retaken beyond Kyiv, I dread to think what other horrors will surely follow. I have also noted that International Criminal Court prosecutors representatives are monitoring the atrocities found, so that the crimes may be veried and hopefully prosecuted at a later date. My heart, however, goes out to the residents of Mariupol in particular, who must be going through a living hell.Surely there must be some way that Russia can be made to allow UN observers in to see just what is going on in the town, especially since Russia insists that no war crimes atrocities are taking place in the whole conflict by their troops. and more help be given with safe passage to the elderly, mothers and children, out of the town to safe areas in Ukraine George Dale, Beith.NUCLEAR IS NOT THE ANSWERDAVID Bonemight be too young to remember when the South of Scotland Electricity Board planned to construct a nuclear power station at Chapledonan just two miles north of Girvan in the early s. At the time there was a huge local campaign against this proposal, which thankfully was successful.Would Mr Bone like to start a local campaign to have a nuclear power station in the Girvan area  I doubt it. In his letter he infers it is the SNP alone which is telling him there is a worldwide climate emergency. I have to ask: was Mr Bone hiding under his duvet during COP With regard to nuclear power, of which Mr Bone admits he has limited "technical knowledge", anyone just has to google "Windscale" to see why it is a really bad solution to the energy crisis the world faces.Alec Oattes, Ayr.It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. We also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of Scotlands conversation with itself.We are lucky at The Herald.
