title: glasgow-kiss-tales-online-dating-womans-perspective
story: The fields of literature and journalism are lined with the soiled reputations of men who have tried to convey physical intimacy in print.Too often these eye-piercing accounts are transactional and mechanical like how you imagine a Which Guide To Sex might be.Often you‚Äôre left unsureit‚Äôs a sexual encounter that‚Äôs being described or a new event in the modern pentathlon.And so you approach an interview assignment such as this with a degree of trepidation.I‚Äôm meeting Sophie Gravia, the young author of what might turn out to be one of the defining literary works of Scotland‚Äôs collective lockdown experience.This -something Glaswegian wrote A Glasgow Kiss from the collected accounts of her on-line dating experiences and those of her friends.It started le as a lockdown project from a series of Facebook blogs, written anonymously.Before long they were being shared widely by womenfor whom Sophie‚Äôs dating experiences struck several chords.They are raw, unflinching and very, very funny.The book, though fictionalised, features Zara, a young Glaswegian health worker whose online dating adventures could have been scripted by Quentin Tarantino and Bette Midler.But they‚Äôre characterised by the seasoned Glaswegian‚Äôs capacity to find humour in the most absurd and socially awkward encounters.And amidst all the unrefined concupiscence and gleefully abandoned foundation garments there is tenderness too and the eternal struggle of a young woman seeking reassurance and validation about her looks and experiences.This being The Herald, I‚Äôve chosen the comparatively subdued aftermath of one of Zara‚Äôs bedtime rendezvous which she discusses with her friend, Ashley.‚ÄúSo, how big was he,‚Äù she screeched as she walked through the door into the kitchen, holding the Chinese bags in her hand.I burst out laughing. ‚ÄúF***ing big. Like ‚Ä¶ this big.‚Äù I pulled a rolling pin out of the cutlery drawer.‚ÄúLucky! And was he generous ‚ÄùThis confirms all men‚Äôs worst nightmares of how women describe these occasions.The full account of the previous evening‚Äôs exertions are outrageously funny and gloriously manky.In all the spilling and leaking and splashing, though, there‚Äôs humanity and compassion as one girl struggles through shame and self-doubt to find what everyone is looking for: love and a little tenderness.‚ÄúI was really touched by the messages I was getting from other women when I first started posting my blogs. They were telling me that they‚Äôd been waiting for years for someone to describe how it really is for them in real le.‚ÄúThere was a time when people tended to be judgmental about dating websites, as though it was for desperadoes. But it‚Äôs totally mainstream now.‚ÄùI ask herit‚Äôs not fraught with a greater degree of peril for women than it is for men. Are they taking a bigger risk Several of my female friends have relayed tales of meeting blokes who think that the simple act of agreeing to go on a date is a contractual guarantee of sex.‚ÄúI‚Äôve never agreed to date someone with whom I haven‚Äôt had a prolonged period of chatting beforehand. Therefore, you can usually tell who the roasters are. Are they over-affectionate or too complimentary about the way you look ‚ÄúAndyou‚Äôre only agreeing to have a coffee then that sets its own boundaries.‚ÄúWhen I was younger I was probably quite naive about all of this, but you learn from experience. I think you can get a sense of someone from the way they dress and their chatthey‚Äôre bad news.‚ÄúMy friends call this ‚ÄòThe f***-boy vibes‚Äô.‚ÄùThis is one of several revelatory locutions with which Sophie acquaints me during our conversation. I strive to appear knowledgeable and seasoned about all of this and affect an insouciant man-of-the-world vibe that soon crumbles.I‚Äôm treated to some other new concepts. One of these is ‚Äúdropping a pin‚Äù.Sophie explains this is a safety mechanism where her friends can electronically embed her location on their smartphones in case anything untoward unfolds.Another one is the ‚ÄúTinder-walk‚Äù. This, Sophie explains, became one of the big features of Scotland in lockdown while people like me were watching old football videos and trying to decipher cookery books.Yet this Tinder-walk malarkey possesses a reassuringly vintage aesthetic. ‚ÄúEveryone got a dog and went on Tinder walks during lockdown,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt helped to ease us all through the social restrictions and was a way of keeping the flames of romance enkindled.‚ÄùHeather Suttie, the Scottish events and PR specialist, was thrilled when she first read A Glasgow Kiss. ‚ÄúIt just seemed to be what a lot of us had been waiting for,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt remember laughing so much at a book ‚Äì and crying too.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just so honest and it could only have been written by a Glaswegian because it‚Äôs got that honesty and directness that‚Äôs usually missing from fiction that deals with sex and relationships.‚ÄùSuttie is founder of BookFace, an international, online book club that holds monthly events in Glasgow with modern authors. ‚ÄúWhen Sophie appeared at one last month the response from women and men was overwhelmingly positive. Yes, some of the scenes are outrageously graphic, but they‚Äôre leavened with humour and honesty.‚ÄùThere are several astonishing aspects to A Glasgow Kiss. It‚Äôs been written by a first-time author who had not the remotest idea of how to break into the publishing world and yet has secured her a two-book deal featuring the further adventures of Zara.And as well as hitting top spot in the Erotic Fiction charts, Waterstone‚Äôs made it one of their books of the year. Yet, she‚Äôs still looking for a literary agent.Perhaps the most startling is that Sophie wrote the book while juggling the demands of being a full-time nurse in a busy Glasgow hospital during lockdown with the responsibilities of being a single mother to two children.‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really stop to think about that,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWriting the book probably helped me cope during the pandemic.‚ÄùAnd while the majority of the responses to the book have been from women, quite a few blokes responded too.‚ÄúI can honestly say that all the responses from men, including from some former internet dates, have been very positive. They all got the humour.‚ÄúOne messaged me last night and said: ‚ÄòF*** me, it was like reading an old scuddy mag when I was a lad. If you ever feel like ditching the halo just give me a shout and I‚Äôll take you out‚Äô. I mean, where did he even get his hands on the book ‚ÄùAny worries she may have harboured about the reactions of friends and family were ill founded.‚ÄúI‚Äôd only initially told a few of them and they were all so supportive. I was a bit more anxious about my family‚Äôs reaction, to be honest.‚ÄúThey‚Äôre all pretty committed and traditional west of Scotland Catholics, but my mum says she‚Äôs very proud of me. She hasn‚Äôt read it and I don‚Äôt really want her to. But she knows what it‚Äôs about. And my family have also said that, of all of them, I was the one with no filters.‚ÄúI recently bumped into one of my gran‚Äôs friends, a woman in her s. She waved over and said: ‚ÄòI bought your book. I sat down with it at  o‚Äôclock last week and I didn‚Äôt stop til am.‚Äô And she‚Äôs the holiest wee woman ever. She‚Äôs lovely.‚ÄúAnd then she said: ‚ÄòYour granny would have been so proud of you‚Äô. ‚ÄúI was also a bit worried about how it might be received at my workplace. And then I saw that some of my patients were reading it. One of them was sitting in our dialysis unit reading it and asked me to come over and sign it for her.‚ÄùRecently, on the gogglebox, there have been some howlers posing as provocative television drama that are about as edgy as Classic FM.You find yourself unconsciously casting A Glasgow Kiss even as you‚Äôre reading it, as it‚Äôs perfect for a six-part comedy drama. The second book in the series will be published in August and by then Sophie hopes to have found an agent.There‚Äôs a message from the author at the front of the book. It says simply: ‚ÄúThis book is for any girl who has ever wondered why she isn‚Äôt enough.‚ÄúJust open your eyes and raise your standards. I see you.‚Äùl A Glasgow Kiss, by Sophie Gravia, is published in paperback by Orion Books, ¬£..It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. title: nadine-dorries-presenter-kirstie-allsopp-clash-channel-4-privatisation
story: The pair exchanged messages on Twitter after an opinion piece by Ms Dorries was published in the Mail on Sunday, addressing the Government‚Äôs decision to push ahead with plans to sell off the channel.Ms Dorries wrote that former Conservative prime minister Margaret Thatcher, who set up Channel  in , had ultimately wanted it to be ‚Äúfree from the constraints of the state‚Äù and described opposition to the move as ‚Äúlazy, overwrought and ill-informed rhetoric from the Leftie luvvie lynch mob‚Äù.Allsopp, who presents property show Location, Location, Location on Channel , responded on Twitter, questioning whether it was ‚Äúreally ministerial‚Äù to describe those contesting privatisation as a ‚Äúlynch mob‚Äù while ‚Äúat the same time complaining about having been accused of fascism‚Äù.Sharing an article about the US Senate passing an anti-lynching Bill, she added: ‚ÄúThis piece might make you think twice about using the term.‚ÄùThe Government confirmed last week that it will proceed with plans to privatise Channel , which has been publicly owned since it was founded in  and is funded by advertising.Allsopp responded to the announcement by tweeting that ‚Äúno true Conservative would sell Channel ‚Äù and that ‚ÄúLady T will be spinning in her grave‚Äù.Replying to her posts on Sunday night, Ms Dorries suggested Margaret Thatcher‚Äôs memoirs, The Downing Street Years, proved she intended Channel  to be sold.She also said Channel  could not be preserved in its current state because of ‚Äúdecreasing advertising revenue and decreasing investment in new content‚Äù.The Tory MP added: ‚ÄúThere is of course the bonus a sale will bring to the entire sector which is that the proceeds of sale will be invested back into people from all backgrounds, especially those from left-behind communities because talent is everywhere, not just in the SE.‚ÄúWe will invest in skills in order to benefit from incoming demand due to our booming film and TV sector due to the favourable tax benefit relief and funding this gov has put in place to encourage film industry to regard Britain as its home.‚ÄúI also love C, especially Location Location, but as I say in my article, it‚Äôs time to look to the future. The channel‚Äôs salad days are in the past. Being owned by the Gov is restrictive. Time for C to fly the nest towards a very exciting future.‚ÄùMs Dorries also apologised to Allsopp after spelling her name incorrectly.She said: ‚ÄúApologies, I know your name is spelt Kirstie, @KirstieMAllsopp. My autocorrect disagreed, I should have double checked!‚ÄùPlans for the sale will reportedly be set out in a White Paper later this month and will be included in a new Media Bill for next spring.A string of Tory MPs and peers, including Sir Peter Bottomley, former Scottish Conservative leader Ruth Davidson, chairman of the Digital, Culture, Media and Sportcommittee Julian Knight, and former cabinet ministers Damian Green and Jeremy Hunt have publicly questioned the plans.Sir Peter, who represents Worthing West, said he opposes the sale ‚Äúbecause I am a Conservative‚Äù.On Monday, Lucy Powell, Labour‚Äôs shadow culture secretary, dismissed the suggestion the sale of Channel  would help the regions.She tweeted: ‚ÄúSelling off C to a foreign media giant is the opposite of levelling up. It will cost jobs in Yorkshire and across the North where C has been investing for years.‚ÄúApprenticeships, HQ and support for independent productions companies are all at risk.‚ÄùIt should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. We also hope it will help the comments section fulfil its promise as a part of Scotlands conversation with itself.We are lucky at The Herald. We are read by an informed, educated readership who can add their knowledge and insights to our stories.¬†That is invaluable.¬†We are making the subscriber-only change to support our valued readers, who tell us they dont want the site cluttered up with irrelevant comments, untruths and abuse.In the past, the journalist‚Äôs job was to collect and distribute information to the audience. Technology means that readers can shape a discussion. We look forward to hearing from you on heraldscotland

title: elderly-aberdeenshire-residents-sent-wrong-vaccine-centre-covid-booster
story: NHS Grampian admitted that around , people who are aged  and over have been given the wrong details about their vaccine centre following an ‚Äúunexplained blip‚Äù in their booking system.Aboyne residents were told that they would need to make a -mile trip to Inverurie to receive their jab instead of at the nearest clinic in the village.The health board has now confirmed that the issue has been resolved and that they are contacting those who were affected by the blip to rebook their appointments.A spokeswoman from NHS Grampian said: ‚ÄúOn Tuesday we became aware some citizens in Aberdeenshire had not been given appointments at their nearest clinic.‚ÄúWe estimate approximately , people have been given appointments at clinics other than their local centre. We have already started phoning people directly to rebook their appointments.‚ÄúThere is no evidence of similar issues in Moray or Aberdeen City we are working closely with the national appointing team to understand why this happened and how it can be avoided in future.‚ÄúIf anyone has received an appointment at a clinic that is not closest to where they stay or is not convenient to get to, they do not need to wait for us to get in touch they can call the national helpline on    and rearrange.‚Äù¬†It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. title: lockdown-star-louis-back-screen-camera-installed-new-osprey-nest
story: Woodland Trust Scotland has operated a nest camera each summer since , and the footage became a hit during the first pandemic lockdown, clocking up , views.But Louis moved to a dferent nest last year, leaving fans unable to follow his progress, so technicians installed another camera at his most recent home to catch his every move.Trust spokesman George Anderson said: ‚ÄúLouis landed on nest two this morning and has been busy excavating and rearranging sticks.‚ÄúHe seems to have very definitely chosen to go with the nest he used for the first time last year. Fingers are now crossed for theof his mate, Dorcha.‚ÄùSince a camera was first set up in , funded by players of People‚Äôs Postcode Lottery, it has gained a substantial fanbase of people following the family le of ospreys Louis and Aila as they raised their six chicks.But in  only Louis ed, and he eventually followed a new female to another nest in the forest. As a result, the original camera nest lay empty for most of the summer.Mr Anderson said: ‚ÄúLouis and his new mate Dorcha raised two chicks, so it was a successful year for the ospreys, but a disappointing one for their internet fans.‚ÄúWe wanted to give ourselves the best odds of seeing a full summer of activity this year, so we fitted a second camera to Louis‚Äô new nest.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a few kilometres away from his original tree. Depending on osprey activity, we may revert to follow just one of the nests as the season progresses, butwe are lucky and both nests are occupied, we will keep streaming from both.‚ÄùIn the hours after histo the nest, Louis‚Äô mate Dorcha also ed to her Loch Arkaig home.The Trust says that Louis gted his other half a fish upon her .Installing just one camera in the forest is a technical challenge, with no visitor centre nearby with wi-fi and electricity to plug into.All of the camera kits are powered by solar  and a signal is beamed across the loch before it enters the Locheilnet system and goes out across the world.It should have been a safe space for informed debate, somewhere for readers to discuss issues around the biggest stories of the day, but all too often the below the line comments on most websites have become bogged down by off-topic discussions and abuse.¬†heraldscotland is tackling this problem by allowing only subscribers to comment.We are doing this to improve the experience for¬†our loyal¬†readers and we believe it will reduce the ability of trolls and troublemakers, who occasionally find their way onto our site, to abuse our journalists and readers. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: face coverings to remain legal requirement until april 18
story: coronavirusFace coverings to remain legal requirement until April March ,  at : pmDue to the #very high level of infection# from COVID- and the resultant pressures on the NHS, the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, has announced that the legal requirement to wear a face covering indoors will remain until Monday, April .In setting out the context for this decision, Ms Sturgeon referred to the most recent Office of National Statistics COVID infection survey which found that one in  people in Scotland had the virus ‚Äì the highest level of infection that has been recorded so far in these surveys.‚ÄúThe volume of people in hospital with COVID is causing very signicant pressure for a health service that has been dealing with the pandemic for more than two years now,# she said. #That means we cannot be complacent.‚ÄùDespite the high rates of infection, the First Minister found some cause for optimism from the daily data, suggesting that the peak of the current wave has been reached and that the infection rate is perhaps stabilising.Nevertheless, the legal requirement to wear a face covering will remain for places of worship or for events like weddings or funerals until Monday, April .As of Monday, April , it will become guidance, rather than a requirement, to wear face coverings on public transport and in shops and other indoor spaces.Ms Sturgeon said: ‚ÄúThis phased approach strikes, I think, a sensible balance between our desire to remove this one remaining legal measure and the common sense need for continued caution, not least for the sake of the NHS while this wave of infection does subside.‚ÄùIn addition, for the period until Easter, everyone will continue to be asked to take to lateral flow tests twice a week, and to take a daily test for seven daysyou are a close contact of someone who has tested positive. People are also being advised to take a test prior to visiting someone who is vulnerable.If you develop symptoms, you should continue to get a PCR test.On vaccination, the First Minister said: ‚ÄúThe advice to everyone, of course, remains as important as ever ‚Äì please do take the opportunity to get vaccinated as soon as you are able and make sure you get all doses of vaccine that you are eligible for. This remains the most important thing any of us can do to protect ourselves and others.‚Äùcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

story: newsHoy Head s while the Graemsay goes on refitApril ,  at : pmIt#s a case of one in, one out, for the south isles ferries.The Hoy Head has ed from refit and has resumed sailing the Houton, Flotta, Lyness route, which had been covered by the Thorsvoe.While the Graemsay has gone for refit and the Stromness, Graemsay, Moaness route is being covered by The Nordic Sea.A spokeswoman for the council said: #It is hoped that the Graemsay will be back in service the last week in April.#However nothing is straight forward, due to prevailing weather and predicted tidal heights, on Wednesday April , the vessel has had to cancel all scheduled arrivals and departures from Moaness, while all sailings to Graemsay are under review.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new cathedral vestibule complete
story: The transformation of St Magnus Cathedral#s west door vestibule is now complete, giving access through the main door for the first time in two years.Moderator of the Church of Scotland, Lord Jim Wallace, will be performing a sermon in the Cathedral on Palm Sunday, April , and has been asked to give a short dedication, which will be followed by a blessing from Cathedral Minister, Reverend Fraser Macnaughton.Custodian and visitor services officer, Fran Hollinrake, had the privilege of opening the main door on Tuesday morning.‚ÄúI was so delighted to be given the honour of unlocking the main entrance doors after two years‚Äô closure due to COVID and the restoration works,# she said.#The new vestibule has been signed off and means it is available for use so that everyone can enjoy this, not only practical new entryway, but also its magnicence.‚ÄùThe restoration and the new vestibule have been made possible with funding from the Society of the Friends of St Magnus, and the work was carried out by local firm Casey Construction Ltd, under the watchful eye of the Cathedral‚Äôs Historic Buildings Conservator, Meredith Macbeth.Elaine Grieve, chairwoman of the Society of the Friends of St Magnus Cathedral said: ‚ÄúThe Cathedral is so precious that it is hard to contemplate making any changes for fear they won‚Äôt do the building justice.#However, in this case, what an absolutely wonderful transformation the vestibule has made to the entrance of the building. The craftmanship is outstanding and we now have an addition which befits this treasured building loved by so many near and far.‚ÄùThe Cathedral is managed by Orkney Islands Council on behalf of the people of Orkney.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: oic election full candidate list revealed
story: Campaign season is now officially under way for the Orkney Islands Council election, after the full list of candidates was declared this Wednesday evening.Voters across Orkney are set to head to the polls on May , to elect the  councillors who will represent them for the next five years.Membership within the OIC chamber is broken up into six electoral wards. These wards, and their candidates are as follows:East Mainland, Burray and South Ronaldsay Kirkwall East Kirkwall West and Orphir North Isles Stromness and South Isles West Mainland Anyone aged  or over that day, resident in Orkney and registered to vote, will be able to vote. Letters have recently been sent to all properties, listing electors who are currently registered to vote andthey have a postal vote in place.Anyone not included on that letter can register to vote between now and Monday, April . Anyone registered to vote but not listed as a postal voter can apply to vote by post which must be ed by pm on Tuesday, April , or sooner.For full coverage of the election as we head towards polling day, pick up The Orcadian, available in shops and online from Wednesday each week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsOrkney to bloom in new series of BeechgroveApril ,  at : amThe latest series of Scotland‚Äôs premier gardening programme Beechgrovewill follow the toil and soil of an Orkney garden. vw, px"  The series introduced the a new strand ‚ÄòBeechgrowers‚Äô last year, which followed the sprouts and doubts of six gardeners across Scotland.This year the Beechgrowers are back, with six new hopeful horticulturalists, including Orkney based Sanne de Koeijer.Sanne, who is described as #a student, studying¬† Culture and Heritage with Gaelic studies. She grew up gardening with her grandparents in the Netherlands, and likes the idea of growing to feed yourself.#She has a  x  plot at a local community garden and the series will follow her green fingered venture.Beechgrove Executive producer Gwyneth Hardy said: ‚ÄúOur Beechgrowers ‚Äì including Sanne #¬† are all raring to go this year to share their gardening experiences, tips and occasional disasters.‚ÄúThere is a big emphasis among this year‚Äôs Beechgrowers on growing your own food, but they all promise to have a wealth of gardening stories to share across the board.‚ÄùViewers will be introduced to Sanne in episode two which is due to be aired on April .The new series of Beechgrove will air on Thursday‚Äôs at .pm BBC Scotland and will be repeated on Friday at . on BBC , the first episode will go out ion April .The programme will also be available on the BBC iPlayer.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: kenny-shiels-world-cup-qualification-out-equation-northern-ireland
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Northern Ireland Women manager Kenny Shiels has conceded defeat in the quest to make it to next year‚Äôs World Cup ahead of taking on free-scoring England.The Green and White Army retain a miniscule chance of overhauling the Lionesses at the top of Group D but are just three points behind second-placed Austria in the battle for a play-off spot with three games to go.However, with minnows Luxembourg, Latvia and North Macedonia providing little competition for the top three, Shiels has thrown in the towel regarding making it to the finals in Australia and New Zealand following Friday‚Äôs - loss away to the Austrians.The -year-old is instead viewing Tuesday‚Äôs game in isolation and says it would be an ‚Äúunbelievable achievement‚Äù to defeat England in front of an expected crowd of around , at Windsor Park in Belfast.‚ÄúThis is not a must-win game because qualication is out of the equation,‚Äù said Shiels.üíö ùïÑùîª-ùüô ùïßùïöùïìùïñùï§ #GAWA #ANewDream pic iUEewjWk‚Äî Northern IrelandApril , ‚ÄúIf we won by five goals, that would be dferent. But we‚Äôre being realistic and we‚Äôre not expecting that to happen.‚ÄúIf we were to beat England, it would be an unbelievable achievement in itself, in isolation to the group.‚ÄùEngland have a  per cent qualying record and are almost certain to top the group after hitting a remarkable  goals without reply.Northern Ireland were beaten - at Wembley back in October having been level until the th minute.They are eight points adrt of the leaders, while last week‚Äôs damaging - defeat in Wiener Neustadt put Austria in pole position to claim the runners-up spot.Shiels‚Äô side complete their campaign away to Luxembourg and Latvia in September but, before then, are scheduled for another meeting with England on their major tournament debut at this summer‚Äôs European Championship.Captain Marissa Callaghan says Northern Ireland will take a positive approach against Sarina Wiegman‚Äôs visitors, with one eye on the future.‚ÄúThese are the games you dream about,‚Äù said the -year-old midfielder. ‚ÄúEvery player is looking forward to it and will give it their all.‚ÄúWe have fantastic players in our squad: game changers and goal-scorers. Who knows what can happen ‚ÄúBut the big thing is it‚Äôs going to be great preparation for going forward and we have a lot to look forward to.‚ÄúWe took them on at Wembley, so why not take them on at Windsor  We know England are a fantastic side but so are we.‚ÄúWe go out with a positive attitude, we go out to win games, score goals, defend for our lives, we‚Äôre taking this occasion on. I think it‚Äôs fantastic for the whole country.‚Äù

title: scientists-crack-egg-forging-evolutionary-puzzle
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Researchers have finally shed light on the century-old mystery of how some birds can mimic the eggs of several other species in order to trick them into raising their young.The study suggests birds may inherit their ability to forge the appearance of their hosts‚Äô eggs from their mothers.This mimicry dupes host parents into accepting a parasitic egg as their own rather than throwing it out of the nest.Around the world, many birds sidestep the responsibilities of parenthood by laying their eggs in the nest of other species.While this lestyle, called brood parasitism, has advantages it also presents challenges such as how to convince the other species to accept a foreign egg.Many birds who engage in the practice achieve this by mimicking the colours and patterns of their host‚Äôs eggs.However, some winged animals exploit the care of several dferent host species whose eggs all look dferent.Scientists have long wondered how a single brood-parasitic bird species can do this, and how these forgers can pass this ability on to their young despite interbreeding between birds raised by dferent hosts.Now genetic research by an international team led by Professor Claire Spottiswoode from the University of Cambridge‚Äôs Department of Zoology and the FitzPatrick Institute of African Ornithology, University of Cape Town, and Professor Michael Sorenson at Boston University, has made a major breakthrough, and their findings may be bad news for the egg forgers.The research reveals that female cuckoo finches inherit their ability to mimic the appearance of their hosts‚Äô eggs from their mothers, via the female-specic W chromosome ‚Äì comparable to the male-specic Y chromosome in humans.According to the scientists, this maternal inheritance allows cuckoo finches to sidestep the risk of inheriting the wrong mimicry genes from a father raised by a dferent host.It has also allowed distinct lineages of cuckoo finch females to evolve specialised egg mimicry of several dferent host species.The researchers suggest such mimicry tricks host parents into accepting a parasitic egg as their own rather than throwing it out of the nest, and so has been crucial to the success of these African birds.However, they believe this long-established system of maternal inheritance may come back to haunt the cuckoo finches.Dr Spottiswoode said: ‚ÄúIn this particular coevolutionary arms race between species, natural selection has created a double-edged sword.‚ÄúWhile maternal inheritance has allowed cuckoo finches to exploit multiple host species, it‚Äôs likely to slow their ability to evolve counter-adaptations as their hosts evolve new defences.‚ÄúIn particular, parasites face a daunting challenge because some host species have inevolved an astonishing ersity of egg colour and pattern ‚Äòsignatures‚Äô, that help hosts to distinguish their own eggs from parasitic mimics.‚ÄùThe study, published in PNAS, focused on the genetics of egg mimicry in the cuckoo finch, a species which adopts a brood-parasitic lestyle and exploits many species of warbler across Africa.The data was collected at a study site in southern Zambia.Cuckoo finches in this area trick four dferent species of grass-warbler to devastating effect.If host parents fail to detect and remove a parasitic egg in their nest, the young cuckoo finch typically outcompetes the hosts‚Äô own hatchlings, which soon starve to death.But in their fightback against the forgers, grass-warblers have become skilled quality controllers, rejecting eggs that dfer from their own in colour and pattern, and all four species have evolved the ability to deposit unique signatures onto their own eggs to enhance their detection of intruders.The study argues that selection from host defences drove cuckoo finches to transfer control of egg appearance to the maternally inherited part of the genome at least two million years ago.

title: lockdown-star-louis-back-screen-camera-installed-new-osprey-nest
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Lockdown sensation Louis the osprey has ed to Loch Arkaig Pine Forest in Lochaber ‚Äì settling on a nest with a newly installed camera.Woodland Trust Scotland has operated a nest camera each summer since , and the footage became a hit during the first pandemic lockdown, clocking up , views.But Louis moved to a dferent nest last year, leaving fans unable to follow his progress, so technicians installed another camera at his most recent home to catch his every move.It looks like Louis the osprey has arrived at the second nest at #LochArkaig!Tune in to our #OspreyCam and follow osprey family le unfold this summer! https:t.co UEuTCbtNP@PostcodeLottery https:t.co knYbrUWB‚Äî Woodland Trustüå≥April , Trust spokesman George Anderson said: ‚ÄúLouis landed on nest two this morning and has been busy excavating and rearranging sticks.‚ÄúHe seems to have very definitely chosen to go with the nest he used for the first time last year. Fingers are now crossed for theof his mate, Dorcha.‚ÄùSince a camera was first set up in , funded by players of People‚Äôs Postcode Lottery, it has gained a substantial fanbase of people following the family le of ospreys Louis and Aila as they raised their six chicks.But in  only Louis ed, and he eventually followed a new female to another nest in the forest. As a result, the original camera nest lay empty for most of the summer.Mr Anderson said: ‚ÄúLouis and his new mate Dorcha raised two chicks, so it was a successful year for the ospreys, but a disappointing one for their internet fans.‚ÄúWe wanted to give ourselves the best odds of seeing a full summer of activity this year, so we fitted a second camera to Louis‚Äô new nest.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a few kilometres away from his original tree. Depending on osprey activity, we may revert to follow just one of the nests as the season progresses, butwe are lucky and both nests are occupied, we will keep streaming from both.‚ÄùIn the hours after histo the nest, Louis‚Äô mate Dorcha also ed to her Loch Arkaig home.The Trust says that Louis gted his other half a fish upon her .Installing just one camera in the forest is a technical challenge, with no visitor centre nearby with wi-fi and electricity to plug into.All of the camera kits are powered by solar  and a signal is beamed across the loch before it enters the Locheilnet system and goes out across the world.

These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Easter weekend could bring the hottest temperatures of the year so far with highs of up to C in some parts of the UK, forecasters have said.Warm weather is set to continue throughout the week, with dry conditions expected for most of the country ahead of the bank holiday.Met Office meteorologist Annie Shuttleworth said despite the heat, the North West will also experience some lingering cloud, making eastern areas the best destination for sun-seekers over the weekend.‚ÄúIf people are travelling for sunshine, then further eastern areas are more likely to see that brighter weather,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúI think in the main for the bank holiday weekend, we‚Äôll see temperatures quite widely above average across the UK and hopefully they could be very warm in the South East in particular. vw,vw,px, px"The Met Office has said sun-seekers have the best chance of beach-going weather in eastern parts of the UK this weekend ‚ÄúWarmer than average certainly, but nowhere near heatwave criteria.‚ÄúIt will definitely be warmer than the week we‚Äôve just had and last week.‚ÄùIf you havent already heard, its warming up in the run up to #Easter, but just how high will #temperatures climb  üìàFind out in our updated weather for the week ahead üëá pic EfHeVdpP‚Äî Met OfficeApril , The warmest temperature of the year so far has been .C, meaning the highs predicted for the South East on the weekend would set a new record for .‚ÄúWe‚Äôll see temperatures generally come up through the week. Todaywe‚Äôre seeing highs of , then from Thursday onwards temperatures could reach , , quite possibly ,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúAcross southern and eastern areas we‚Äôre more likely to see some sunshine and clearer skies in the afternoon.‚ÄùSome drizzly rain is expected later in the week across the North West along with the cloud, but it is not likely to cause disruption.

title: sharif-sworn-pakistans-new-pm-week-drama
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Pakistan‚Äôs parliament has elected opposition politician Shahbaz Shar as the new prime minister, following a week of political turmoil that led to the ousting of Imran Khan.Mr Shar took the oath of office inside the stately, white marble palace known as the Presidency in a brief ceremony.But his elevation will not guarantee a peaceful path forward or solve the country‚Äôs many economic problems, including high inflation and a soaring energy crisis.Mr Shar, the brother of disgraced former prime minister Nawaz Shar, won with  votes after more than  lawmakers from Mr Khan‚Äôs Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf, or Pakistan Justice Party, resigned and walked out of the National Assembly in protest.Those  votes ‚Äî two more than the required simple majority ‚Äî are enough to pass laws in the -seat assembly. If Mr Khan‚Äôs followers take to the streets, as he has vowed, it could create more pressure on lawmakers and deepen the crisis.Mr Khan, a former cricket star whose conservative Islamist ideology and dogged independence characterised his three years and eight months in office, was ousted early on Sunday.He lost a no-confidence vote after being deserted by his party allies and a key coalition partner.In a show of strength and a precursor to the political uncertainty ahead, Mr Khan rallied hundreds of thousands of supporters on Sunday night to protest over his ouster, describing the new leadership as an ‚Äúimposed government,‚Äù charging they colluded with the US to oust him.His backers marched in cities across Pakistan, waving large party flags and shouted slogans promising tohim to power. The crowds were dominated by youths who make up the backbone of Mr Khan‚Äôs supporters.The political drama began April  when Mr Khan sidestepped an initial no-confidence vote demanded by the opposition by dissolving parliament and calling early elections.The opposition, which accuses Khan of economic mismanagement, appealed to the Supreme Court. After four days of deliberations, the court said Mr Khan‚Äôs move was illegal and the no-confidence vote went ahead, leading to his ouster.Mr Khan has demanded early elections ‚Äî the balloting is not due before August . He has tapped into anti-American sentiment in Pakistan, accusing Washington of conspiring with his opponents to topple him. That conspiracy theory resonates with his youthful base, which often sees the US war on terrorism after   as unfairly targeting Pakistan.Mr Khan claims Washington opposes him because of his independent foreign policy favouring China and Russia. He was criticised for a visit he made on February  to Moscow, where he met with President Vladimir Putin as Russian tanks rolled into Ukraine.The US State Department has denied any involvement in Pakistan‚Äôs internal politics.

title: lace to compete at crufts for fifth time
story: A Sandwick woman and her seven-year-old dog will compete at Crufts in a Scottish team this week # for the fth time together.Sally Sanford and Lace, her Nova Scotia Duck Tolling Retriever, will take part in the rally event on Thursday at the NEC in Birmingham.The pair are part of a Scotland team who will face Wales, Northern Ireland and four English regional teams in the inter-regional rally competition.The rally course sees dog and handler work as a pair to navigate a course of between  and  dferent exercises.Ms Sanford said the competition was always #a step-up#.#You#re asking the dogs to do stuff that isn#t that complicated for them, but it#s the handlers who need to be able to multi-task, to concentrate in the moment and navigate their way around the course.#You need your head in the game.#But she said that was one of Lace#s strengths, and said he had finished second in his event previously.The pair are hoping for another strong showing, but with Crufts taking place for the first time since March , she said there were some uncertainties.#None of us know how busy Crufts is going to be this year,# she said.#I would be lyingI said there wasn#t a degree of trepidation.#She said that she was excited for theof the #enormous# event, though, and hopes Lace will be able to inspire Scotland to better their previous best performance of third...Pet pooches are being given the chance to test their agility and obedience without even having to leave their own gardens ‚Äì proving that lockdownSandwick resident Sally Sanford will be appearing at the Crufts dog show this week as part of the Scottish rally team with her Nova ScotiaA dog lover from Bigton says that making the final in the Kennel Club‚Äôs Eukanuba Friends for Le competition at Crufts  would mean the#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: new coxswain for lerwick lifeboat
story: A new full-time coxswain has been appointed to the Lerwick leboat.Twenty-nine-year-old Stephen Manson starts in the role today , replacing Darren Harcus who has taken up another coxswain#s role within RNLI.Mr Manson originally trained as a vehicle mechanic and has been recently employed on workboats in the salmon industry.He has been part of the volunteer crew on the Lerwick leboat since October , and will now take up a full-time role at the station.After undertaking training in the coming months he will take command of the leboat during future launches.Mr Harcus, who has been Lerwick coxswain since , has been appointed full-time resilience coxswain for the north of Scotland # providing relief coxswain work wherever he is needed.Lerwick leboat operations manager Malcolm Craigie said: #I‚Äôm delighted that Stephen and Darren have both been appointed to these full-time roles # they‚Äôre both experienced and capable members of our leboat crew.#We rely on full-time crew members to train and support our volunteer crews and to keep the leboat ready for launch  .#..Volunteer lesavers put their navigational skills to festive use by mapping out a Christmas tree design.Tributes have been paid to the brave lesaver Billy Deacon on the th anniversary of his tragic death. title: power out at da street during cruise ship visit
story: Da street in Lerwick was hit by an unexpected power cut on Monday afternoon., which can hold over , passengers, is visiting Lerwick today .But shops along the street lost power just after .pm, with SSE saying the outage was reported to them at .pm.SSE said it had engineers working to restore the power shortly afterwards, and power was restored at around .pm.The company said at one stage as many as , customers across  Lerwick postcodes had been affected by the outage.The cause of the power cut was a fault on a high-voltage cable, SSE added, with engineers now investigating the fault.SSE said: #We would like to apologise to our customers who experienced a loss of power this afternoon and thank them for their patience whilst our engineers worked to restored power as safely and quickly as possible.#..SSE has presented two cheques totalling ¬£, to Shetland Foodbank. title: tobar an dualchais what can proverbs tell us about
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineIn recent years, interest in this concept has been growing exponentially, with a iety of groups recognising its importance as a sense of place and belonging or identying it as the rootedness us modern people are understandably desperate for. which Edward Dwelly noted in his dictionary.The Place of one#s birth.Heredity, native or hereditary temper, spirit or blood.Visage, countenance.Hereditary right. could be one of the cornerstones of a reconstructed Gaelic worldview. The identity of a person could undoubtedly be forged by the place of their birth and the community of that place, particularly at a time in the past when populations were less mobile.The traits of a person‚Äôs parents manest in their physical appearance their spirit, likes and dislikes, and sometimes even interests or inclinations might appear hereditary ‚Äì not just from mother and father but perhaps from an ancestor remembered only by name and special characteristic, like poesy or craft skill..The failure by clan chiefs and other landed gentry to recognise this customary right held by the people since time immemorial underpins the Clearances, while demands for its recognition echo through much of the collective action undertaken against this violence, trauma, and dispossession. as far back in history as I can.The world and society these people lived in was so dferent to ours today, making context crucial to understanding the words being used and the philosophy from which they derive.Aside from the multitude which are in still in use today, there are published proverb collections as well as countless sound recordings, many digitized and made easily accessible by Tobar an Dualchais.By their nature proverbs cut across boundaries of class and gender, their survival relying upon oral transmission, on being commonly known in a community and thus reflecting its values. They are that memorable phrase we hear our elders say once they have explained its meaning to us, we are unlikely to forget it.Theyto us often and roll off the tongue.One of the most important collections of Gaelic proverbs was published in  by Alexander Nicolson .However, Nicolson was merely re-printing a collection made by Donald Macintosh, a Perthshire-born clergyman, first printed in Edinburgh in . Nicolson called the collection ‚Äúa genuine product of the past‚Äù with Macintosh merely acting as collator and translator. of Islay, perhaps coined in the times when the MacLeans, MacDonalds, and later Campbells feuded over the island the second one is a rhyme about the MacAlpines, their former seat in Dunstaffnage, and their ancient claim to the throne of Scotland:When the natives forsake Islay, farewell the peace of Scotland!Children of the native kings, Who reigned down at Dunstaffnage, Who first the crown of Alba owned, And still have native claim to it..It also tells us that there are always grave, far-reaching political consequences whenever an indigenous population is forced to abandon its home.as a hereditary right can last for centuries. The strength of attachment to people and place shines through both.Blood is stronger than breeding., ‚Äòblood is thicker than water‚Äô, and perhaps it should come as no surprise to us that a society which places strong emphasis on ancestry and blood ties should have so many proverbs reinforcing such beliefs..Sad is the inheritance of a bad disease.This proverb is the perfect reminder that not everything we inherit from our ancestors is good. Psychologically and spiritually, we inherit their trauma physically, as the proverb reminds us, we may inherit their medical conditions.By accepting the full extent of our inheritance ‚Äì strength and weakness, the beautul and the ugly ‚Äì we grow closer to our ancestors and empower ourselves to heal from what they could not.has always been characterised by plurality and complexity, reflecting the complex G√†idhealtachd to which it belonged.For centuries, fostering children has been an important feature of Gaelic society, and for all the influence that DNA can have on us, the nurture we receive during our formative years has just as much ‚Äìnot more ‚Äì influence on who we become within our community.In a changing world, it is inspiring to see people across the G√†idhealtachd connecting with the cultural ‚Äòmycelium‚Äô of their place and rooting themselves in it, whether it is their ancestral homeland or adoptive home.can be a wellspring of transformative energy for place-based revitalisation.Sometimes it seems to burst like lightning, explosively cleaving through adversity. But it is also the stream ‚Äì the carrying stream ‚Äì slowly weathering stone, flowing ever on from generation to generation.

title: editorial budhmor decision must be
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineJust  weeks‚Äô notice has been given to families to make new arrangements for their loved ones, and while staff have apparently been offered alternative positions, there is considerable anger and upset among workers who have served the home and those who have lived in it with diligence and compassion over many years. adds our voice in support, and in doing so raises further questions about the provision of care for the region‚Äôs elderly.Not so very long ago there were residential care homes in just about every district of Skye and Lochalsh # in Staffin, Struan, Dunvegan, Uig, Broadford and Dornie.But changing regulations on facilities and staff were not sufficiently accompanied by support for the owners to make the transition the new rules demanded of them. It is now surely a matter of huge regret for our communities that so many small-scale care providers # despite their good reputation and obvious appeal in rural parts of the country ‚Äì have been allowed to wither on the vine and disappear. on standards which followed the Covid outbreak in April and May .Budhmor‚Äôs owners are not a shadowy offshore conglomerate trying to put profit before care ‚Äì but CrossReach, the social arm of the Church of Scotland. Despite their benevolent roots, the modern pressures facing the sector, they say, simply make it too dficult to keep their Portree home open.The building needs too much work and they don‚Äôt have the money to pay for it.The only option, families were told, is closure ‚Äì with the suggestion that the  residents could all be accommodated nearby in a refurbished and expanded Home Farm.It is not dficult to understand why families are so aggrieved at this proposal.Things may well have improved at Home Farm since the horrors of Covid, but have all the lessons been learned The blanket national policy of shting patients from hospitals to care homes in the frantic weeks of early  was a huge factor in the devastating Covid death toll that followed.Yet now, with the pandemic still not behind us, families in Skye are being told they should accept the transfer en masse of their elderly relatives to the very home so ravaged by coronavirus when it was proven to be over capacity and understaffed.At Budhmor, they managed to keep the home safe from the worst of Covid-. Relatives of residents will tell you that was no fluke ‚Äì but down to good standards, diligent management and conscientious staff.There will be some truth in the financial and staffing pressures that CrossReach cite in their reasons for closure. But two years on from the outset of Covid, should the sector not be doing all it can to preserve and build on the success of an institution which proved such a good example during the pandemic, rather than bowing to the bottom line and accepting its loss.There is also the matter of an options appraisal on health and care needs in the north of Skye, currently being prepared by NHS Highland.Closure must at the very least be halted until this review is complete ‚Äì andthis requires support for CrossReach, our Government should find it.In the longer term what we really need are alternative models to those that are currently governed by economies of scale than on inidual or community needs. An agenda of rationalisation and centralisation has taken hold of far too many of our public services and is ultimately driving decisions like the closure of small care facilities offering a homely, personalised environment in favour of a vast, but possibly distant one many miles from an inidual‚Äôs home community.No-where has this been more obvious, or dangerous, than in the west Highland health and care sector.We should start the fightback by backing Budhmor care home, and keeping it open.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220407newsthe people you are visiting may be particularly vulnerable
story: The public has been urged to keep wearing face coverings when visiting hospitals, care homes and other health and care settings. The appeal from the Chief Medical Officer comes with reports of a decline in wearing of face coverings by visitors. Professor Sir Michael McBride said: ‚ÄúThe COVID- Omicron iant is extremely infectious and, despite best efforts, can spread quickly in health and social care settings. ‚ÄúPlease remember to wear a face covering when you are visiting. The people you are coming to see may be particularly vulnerable to the virus - as may other patients or residents. ‚ÄúAlso, do not visityou have symptoms of respiratory infection.‚Äù The Chief Medical Officer added: ‚ÄúWearing a face covering remains an important way to protect others, as well as yourself. Public health advice continues to encourage their use in everyday le. That also includes on public transport and in any indoor busy setting - especiallythey are not well ventilated.‚Äù

title: education minister visits ballymena primary school
story: EDUCATION Minister Michelle McIlveen paid a recent visit to Ballymena Primary School.During the visit on March  the Minister spoke to members of the student bodies active within the school which included the School Council, Eco-Council and Digital Leaders. She witnessed children engaging in ICTlessons, in play sessions both indoor and outdoor and spoke extensively to staff on the Special Needs team. The pastoral and Mental Health programmes within the school were of interest to Minister McIlveen as well as how children had found theto face-to-face learning after Lockdowns. The Minister also enjoyed seeing a class making toast around the fire pit as part of their Forest School activities and was shown the continual development in children‚Äôs outdoor learning in the school which the staff were finding to have had a positive impact upon their well-being and academic achievement.The Minister was initially due to visit Ballymena Primary School as part of their ceremony to celebrate an outdoor play award called TOPS back in October . Due to ious Assembly commitments the Minister had been unable to visit until now and was keen to honour a promise made to visit what was the first primary school of the town established back in . Minister McIlveen was pleasantly surprised by the extensive, bright and modern interior of the school which was not immediately evident from outside and complimented the children on their behaviour, enthusiasm and sense of responsibility. The children of the school were happy to welcome Minister McIlveen and staff were delighted to be able to share some of the developments and progress made within the school due to the hard work and dedication of the staff.Principal, Mrs Ritchie said: ‚ÄúWe were so pleased to welcome the Education Minister to Ballymena Primary School on Wednesday as a way of celebrating all of the continued hard work and advances within the school. ‚ÄúThe Minister was happy to engage with the children and staff and asked interested questions around child development and we were keen to display as many aspects of our educational provision as time would allow.‚Äù

title: daria through to miss ni final
story: A former pupil of Patricks College in Ballymena has made it through to the final of the Miss Northern Ireland competition.Daria Gapska, a -year-old childrens nursing student, recently ed to the college for a presentation to Year  on her chosen charity Braveheartsni.Daria was one of two finalists to be crowned at the first live Miss World Northern Ireland Heat of  in Nu Delhi, Belfast in front of an an astute judging  which included Managing Director of ACA models and Event organiser Victoria Withers. The event saw girls from across Northern Ireland compete for their place at the Miss World Northern Ireland final.Daria was crowned as Miss Nu Delhi and Poppy Smith a  year old Biomedical Science student from Portadown was crowned as Miss Belfast. St Patricks College congratulated their former pupil on her success in the competition.The school said: ‚ÄúDaria has chosen Braveheartsni as her charity. It is a charity very close to our hearts as founder, Shealyn Caulfield is also a past pupil. ‚ÄúDaria did an excellent presentation on the charity to our Year  pupils and will present this to other Year Groups next week.‚ÄúWe wish her all the best with her preparations for the Miss Northern Ireland final.‚ÄùBraveheartsni is Northern Ireland‚Äôs only charity supporting the needs of teenagers and young adults with Adult Congenital Heart Disease.The charity has grown from the strong volunteer ethos of HeartbeatNI who are also a local volunteer charity who support families with children with congenital heart disease.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newscurry s fun park opens in portrush
story: AFTER months of waiting, Currys Fun Park in Portrush is finally open! The eagerly anticipated successor to the popular Barrys Amusements opened its doors for the first time on Saturday amid great excitement. Hundreds of people young and old filed through the doors all afternoon as the magic ed to Portmagic - and just in time for Easter. The good news is that Currys is now up and running, boasting all the old Barrys favourites and adding some new ones too. And for those with old Barrys tokens - no, you cant use them, but you can help the RNLI by dropping them into collection boxes dotted around the complex. The fun park has chosen the charity as its partner - a thoughtful gesture given the important work volunteers do in the waters off the north coast. But for now, after two years of zero craic because of the pandemic, all roads lead to the Port and what promises to be a fun-filled holiday period. Happy days.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220410newsfamiliar faces on this week s rare breed
story: UTV‚Äôs hit farming series, ‚ÄòRare Breed - A Farming Year‚Äô, s on Tuesday th April at pm. The families are bringing in their ious harvests and making preparations for next year. It‚Äôs October, and on the shores of Strangford Lough the Elliott family rear turkeys. The family have years of experience looking after the birds and yet Mark and Olive are still fascinated by their behaviour. Olive comments that they are ‚Äòextremely inquisitive‚Äô. While Mark is making sure the turkeys are well fed, his mum Olive can‚Äôt help giving them an extra treat. She comments too, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt do without my family, I have to be so nice to them at the minute!‚Äù Mark points out that they have been receiving orders for Christmas since August, which is ‚Äòabsolutely nuts.‚Äô Near Kilcoo in the Mourne Mountains, Aine Devlin is preparing her flock for the most critical part of her farming year- breeding season. Aine is keeping an eye on her rams to make sure they‚Äôre doing their job. She coats their chests with paint to see which ewes they have been with. Aine laughs, ‚ÄúThis is his cologne for the girls!‚Äù For her AI is not the way to go as the ewes would then all lamb on the same day on the mountain. She loves this time of year and is proud of the part she plays in the economy. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs better than buying produce from down the road from your neighbours and local communities ‚Äù she says. Outside Crossgar, Richard Orr is thinking ahead to next year‚Äôs wheat crop. It‚Äôs all about the planning and attention to detail to make sure the groundwork is done right. He‚Äôs conscious of the environment, saying, ‚ÄúThe major thing in the world is carbon footprint. Chemicals have made farming easy, and modern machinery has damaged the structure of the soil - we need to rebuild that.‚Äù Meanwhile, just outside Portadown it‚Äôs all hands on deck for apple harvest at the McKeever family farm. There isn‚Äôt a high yield this year but sometimes things not going to plan can be a blessing. Pat talks about the seven to eight weeks of hell and this year pickers have been hard to get. Peter comments, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs half the battle when you have good people around.‚Äù On the Donegal   Londonderry border, potato farmer Jamie Rankin and his team are coming towards the end of their harvest. He enjoys the early starts and says, ‚ÄúWhat you do before dinner time‚Äôs your day‚Äôs work.‚Äù While it‚Äôs a job Jamie enjoys, it also comes with challenges as winter months close in. The bad weather has led to reduced yields and a late harvest, but he‚Äôs very proud to have produced a good crop. UTV‚Äôs Mark McFadden narrates the series. Sponsored by Moy Park, ‚ÄòRare Breed ‚Äì A Farming Year‚Äô continues on Tuesday th April at pm on UTV.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220411newsapril showers keep them shorter
story: Spring has finally sprung and with rising energy costs there is no better time to dust off old habits and create some new ones that are good for your pocket and the environment. Start by thinking how much water you are using each day. Whether you are washing your hands, cleaning endless amounts of dishes or getting through that mountain of washing, you start to realise just how important water is and the sheer amount we use. NI Water‚Äôs Environmental Outreach  Learning Officer, Anna Killen, explains how we can save water by looking at everyday habits, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs amazing to think that each day each person uses around  litres of water! However, saving water can be really easy, there are simple things we can all do that can make a huge dference. ‚ÄúDid you know that the average time people in Northern Ireland spend in the shower is  minutes, over % of people still overfill the kettle and less than frac of people have a waterbutt ‚Äù  ‚ÄúWe want that to change and it‚Äôs easy, start by looking at small changes for example, your kettle, since working from home it has have been working overtime, but just fill with as much water as you need. Overfilling can use twice as much energy and water, each time you boil. ‚ÄúWith rising energy costs, it might be time to think about reducing the time spent in the shower, hot water costs money! Why not try the  minute shower challenge, put on your favourite  minute song and seeyou can finish before the end.‚Äù To help you embed with these new habits and ‚ÄòGet Water Fit‚Äô, complete our online water audit at https:www.getwaterfit or take part in water saving challenges and receive your free water saving items including  minute shower timer, toothy timers and swell gel bags for the garden. Some water saving tips:  Turn off the tap when brushing your teeth - A running tap can use  litres ofwater per minute.  Use a bowl for washing vegetables - Then you can reuse this water for plants.  Make full use of your washing machine - Half load programmes on washing machines use more than half the water and energy of a full load, so wait until the machine is full before switching it on.  Fix leaking taps - A dripping tap can waste more than  litres of water per week.  Keep a jug of water in the fridge, instead of letting the tap run cold. NI Water are encouraging customers to sign up to its free text alert service which keeps them updated about anything that may impact on their water supply or any of our other services in the area.here https:www.niwater register-for-keeping-you-informed

title: new belfast transport hub to be named belfast grand central station
story: Artist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueArtist impression of the new Belfast Transport Hub which will be situated on Translink property near the current Europa Buscentre and Great Victoria Street Stations.Niamh CampbellTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast‚Äôs new transport hub will be officially named Belfast Grand Central Station, Translink has confirmed.Work on the south Belfast station began in February and is expected to open by .¬†The major infrastructural scheme led by Northern Ireland‚Äôs public transport provider stretches across , sqft, replacing the existing Europa and Great Victoria Street bus and rail stations.¬†When completed, it will become¬†the largest integrated transport hub on the island of Ireland.The hub will provide  bus stands, eight¬†railway s and an enhanced walking and cycling connectivity across the city.When the ¬£m project was announced in , Translink said the project would create  new jobs.Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon, who visited the project‚Äôs building site earlier this year, described it¬†as ‚Äúexciting‚Äù and said it will be a ‚Äúgame changer‚Äù for Northern Ireland.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up ‚ÄúI have been clear that we need to see an increase in the use of public transport and encourage more people to consider active travel options so that we can tackle the climate crisis,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúTo achieve that we need to have the right infrastructure in place.‚ÄùAnother project running alongside the Transport Hub at Weavers Cross close to Sandy Row will also regenerate the .m square foot brownfield site in the area.Ms Mallon added: ‚ÄúWith an expected annual footfall of over  million, this important NI Executive flagship project will bring a host of benefits to support the economy.‚ÄúIt will improve connectivity for everyone in Northern Ireland and beyond, and will be a key driver of social, economic and environmental wellbeing for the local and wider community.On Thursday, Translink tweeted that the new Grand Central¬†is being ‚Äúcelebrated with community engagement, through an innovative ‚ÄòIt‚Äôs Grand‚Äô Story Board at Europa Bus Centre‚Äù.¬†The new station is also only a stone‚Äôs throw away from the Hastings-owned Grand Central Hotel, which opened on Bedford Street in .The name itself is full of history, as the city‚Äôs first Grand Central Hotel¬†was opened on Royal Avenue in June  by Downpatrick man John Robb.He had originally planned to develop a huge central railway terminus on the site ‚Äì¬†based on New York#s famous Grand Central Station ‚Äì¬†but failed to get support¬†from local politicians at the time.It closed its doors in  when the Troubles broke out and¬†was later taken over by the Army in  for use as a base, eventually being¬†demolished in the late s. The site is now home to the Castle Court shopping centre.The train station formerly known as Belfast Central, which is located on Bridge Street in the Laganside area of the city, was renamed Lanyon title: p and o ferries set to restart larne to cairnryan route following inspection
story: PO at Larne port . FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePO at Larne port .Garrett HarganTwitterEmailApril   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFerry company PO has announced that services between Larne and Cairnryan in Scotland will restart on Sunday morning.Its vessels were grounded last month after PO sacked around  seafaring workers over a Zoom call and replaced them with low-paid agency staff.The company faced widespread criticism from workers and trade unions over the dismissals.A spokesperson for PO Ferries said: ‚ÄúOn Friday, the Maritime and Coastguard Agencycompleted its most recent inspection of the European Causeway, and have confirmed it is safe to sail.‚ÄúWe are delighted that we will be able to restart full services between Larne and Cairnryan from am, Sunday th April.‚ÄúPO is pleased to play its part in supporting customers to move vital goods between the Northern Ireland and Scotland.‚ÄùOn Thursday the Maritime and Coastguard Agencysaid it was carrying out a reinspection of the European Causeway at PO Ferries‚Äô request.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up An MCA spokesman said: ‚ÄúAll inspections have to satisfy the Maritime and Coastguard Agency that the ferries fulfil the requirement of the Port State Control regime and are safe to put to sea.‚ÄúThere are no further inspections of PO Ferries at the moment but we will reinspect at the appropriate time.‚ÄùEarlier this week PO said the Larne route and others would resume this weekend.Rival ferry company Stena Line has been absorbing some of the business from would-be PO customers, on its Belfast to Cairnryan route.One worker said staff at the business were ‚Äúworking their socks off‚Äù to cope with the big jump in demand.The business was thought to be meeting between  and % of the demand from PO customers.It had erted one ship, the Nordica, from the Holyhead to Dublin route to service the demand.As well as members of the public, PO also provides services to commercial customers such as Asda and Marks  Spencer.Most
